review_text: A man goes back in timeto figure out the mystery of a serial killernamed Mallari.Halos lahat ng pwede mong makita sa isang horror thriller film ay inilagay nila rito. Nakakatuwa dahil kaya pala natin makaisip ng ganitong konsepto na siksik sa iba‚Äôt ibang elemento.Hindi lang siya basta patayan, habulan, sigawan. Maraming pasabog sa kwento na tila walang hangganan. Sunod sunod ang mga plottwists sa dulo at wala itong hingahan.Piolo Pascual gave his usual good acting. You can see the distinction among the three characters he is portraying. Gloria Diaz was graceful. Geraldine Villamil was terrifying. The performance of JC Santos was impressive and applaudable, serving as one of the film‚Äôs highlights.The color grading, scoring, sound design, and cinematography altogether gave a thrilling atmosphere. The movie‚Äôs original song, composed by Quest and interpreted by juan karlos, is a powerful appropriate soundtrack.Mallari‚Äôs greatest strength still lies on its concept. The effort to be a different kind of horror film was seen and appreciated. If watching ùòîùò¢ùò≠ùò≠ùò¢ùò≥ùò™ means getting better horror stories, then count us in.Let ùòîùò¢ùò≠ùò≠ùò¢ùò≥ùò™ be the start of something new.READ FULL MOVIE REVIEW HERE:www.goldwinreviews.com/post/mallari

Hilarious... Uncomfortable... And one unique hell of a ride!Mallari, though not perfect, still offers an enjoyable horror flick that has FILIPINO smeared all over it, be it 1800s, 1940s, and the modern times... and even has the legendary monsters we all grew up hearing about... but of course with a unique twisted flavor! Piolo Pascual devoured not once but thrice with his triple role! The twist was a lil predictable but executed just fine making this whole experience satisfying enough for me! Also plus points for the #kapampangan represent! Janella Salvador did such a serve too!Do note that despite this being based off a serial killer, it is highly fictionalized, so if you're expecting a biopic, you'll surely be disappointed!I'm glad to see that ph cinema is alive and well! it was packed üòç

It's ok. It mostly resorts to ineffective jump scares, the movie isn't that scary and there are also a few dull moments. Even the audience sa sinehan aren't reacting sa mga ibang nakakatakot na eksena and no one seemed enthusiastic or something. Piolo and JC Santos are amazing though, pati narin si Janella. I like the twist din and impressive din ang ibang visuals/cinematography. May isang CGI scene lang na hindi masyadong maganda. Ayun. I still recommend it though kasi ang ganda ng performances nila, lalo na sila Papa P at JC.

An entertainingly insane, if at times, clunky murder thriller that is more compelling with the crazy plot threads and character motivations and choices, and far less so with incredibly cheap scares and a mix of beautiful cinematography and design and underwhelming visual effects.Performances are strong all around, esp Piolo Pascual being able to somehow have a incredible range playing three versions of himself. One scene with him in a church talking to demons is more compelling and scary then the litany of pointless jumpscares that didn't add much at all.
Writing is all over the place but Piolo's performance held the movie together. It's also fun to watch in a jampacked cinema.
Don‚Äôt know what to feel about this film but it‚Äôs actually good.
Easily one of the better Filipino horror movies we have. Good concept, decent execution, just wish our special effects were better.

The CGI was horrific and the horror was average. But I really liked the plot.The concept was quite similar to Attack on Titan, but in this case, instead of past holders of the ‚ÄúAttack Titan‚Äù, the protagonist can communicate with his ancestors.JC‚Äôs acting was incredible. The scene where Lucas was fighting with Jonathan was so cool.The scene where Severino was dancing with his mom with the epic music at the end was beautiful.I really wish they did better with the CGI though.

Gusto ko lang sabihin na hindi ikinahiya ng film na ito ang transphobia & criminalization ng sex work - baka kasi kailangan lang din masabi sakaling may nakikinig, so yeahhh‚Ä¶nakalulungkot.Anyways, the concept could have been a top tier religious horror/suspense/slasher/thriller (heck even camp) but it was horror only during the sigawan moments. After that nothing was sustained. I left the theater na walang baon pauwi. I learned nothing new abt Fr. Severino Mallari, what was his real motive labas sa fiction‚Ä¶or idk ü§∑ which was real and documented (ang ganda sana i-explore). Di ko rin maiwasan ikumpara sa Seklusyon ni Erik Matti which was for me, an eye opener to the horrors of the Catholic church. That film perfectly blended horror + criticism on the Catholic church. I remember leaving the cinema with lots of questions on Catholicism. Dito wala, purely entertainment. Pero yun nga, gets ko kasi ito ay MMFF at hindi Cinemalaya (pero MMFF din naman yung Seklusyon kaya lang that was a different time I guessss huehue).So sana ibang direction naman ang tahakin ng Severino ni Dennis Trillo (looking forward to that).PSLove the gays beside us screaming ‚ÄúGo Valentina!‚Äùüìç MMFF 2023, SM Lipa

Let‚Äôs get the good things out of the way: Piolo Pascual is terrific portraying multiple characters, each of his character given just enough time to be fleshed out in a 2-hour runtime. The production is gorgeous, a really big step up here for Filipino cinema.I admire the concept of this film, has so much potential to showcase a unique Filipino horror experience with a touch of history and historical fiction. The history side of things was handled pretty decently, but unfortunately the horror itself is the singular thing holding this film back, relying on the usual cheap jumpscare tactics, with lackluster use of its unique atmosphere to build up dread and tension.This film could‚Äôve been so much more than what we have, but at the very least I‚Äôll give it this: it is a step-up from the generic Filipino horror rubbish that we get every year.6.5/10

sobrang needy and clingy nung sisiw parang ako lang emei wish it didn't resort to cheap jumpscares too often just to fill the run time because it's the last thing it needed. the dread, creepy atmosphere is already there that cabrido has crafted the backdrop of these three characters quite nicely. the film had A LOT of creative freedom and shied away from being historically accurate and became a non-linear multiverse folk horror that might've been easily given me the ick, but i still appreciated how it became its own thing as it progresses, which leads as to why i still think it worked for me; it is committed on what it wanted to be and its theme of greed for power is clearly understood. piolo proved his acting prowess once again playing three generations of mallari, a tour de force performance.Metro Manila Film Festival 2023

Initially gave this four stars after leaving the theater, but after giving it some thought I‚Äôm taking it down to 3.5 üò≠Mallari (2023) boasts impeccable set design and costumes that make each time period feel robust yet still feel lived in. Pascual and Santos‚Äô performances carry a lot of the weight of this film for me with Pascual delivering in all three roles and Santos‚Äô grit as Lucas. Janella Salvador‚Äôs Agnes also packed a punch despite her somewhat short screen time. Apart from Pascual‚Äôs portrayal of each Mallari, the film‚Äôs choice of anchoring each era to the conflicts that affected the Filipino of its period. The feudal tensions of the 1800s and the CIA Aswang psy-op gave more body to the time periods presented. The burden each Mallari carried through time eventually made that ending make sense to me. Greed, on both systemic and intimate levels, drive the motivations of each character. Considering all of this, what made Mallari (2023) fall flat for me was its horror aspect. I am no expert on the horror genre and seeing this film made me want to read up on it haha lol but I found that the jumpscares eventually felt cheap, predictable, and unnecessary. The CGI also faltered during one scene with Do√±a Facunda, though it warrants a pwede na from me kasi di naman siya ganun ka-distracting. So ayun! Also the girl who played Felicity looks like she knows what an iPhone is so medyo di bagay sa time period. Anyways, fun movie! Folk catholicism in Filipino horror is always so interesting.

A smorgasbord of horror genres that worked well!Watching Mallari is an journey and the ride paid off really well. The film had such an interesting oremise and promise that accounted for a fictional spin on a historical event that shaped the town of Magalang, Pampanga.Pao Orendain's lenses played such a big role in making sure every beat was felt and audiences were immersed. From the colos and light8ng used up to the choreography of the camerawork, it was a feast fornthe eyes. The overall production design was superb as well. Having three eras worth of costumes, props, sets is a hard task but it was executed really well. Everything felt too realistic and you can't deny the time out into crafting each set.But of course, the acting performances of the cast are the highlight. Piolo Pascual delivered such a great take on three distinct personalities from three different time periods. From the murderous priest, steadfast documentarian, up to the persistent doctor, all Piolos had their own personalities and nuances. Best actor calibre performance.JC Santos and Gloria Diaz also shone in their roles by delivering really strong and powerful performances. As usual, JC Santos was amazing and undoubtedly a strong contender for Best Actor with this performance. Meanwhile, Gloria Diaz was eerie, creepy, and committed. Last time I saw a strong Gloria Diaz performance like this was way back in "Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo" & its sequel and "Nasaan Ka Man."Special shoutout to Paps Raffy Tejada! Again, giving life to roles he's portraying. He's a breath of fresh air amidst the eerie fele8ng this film gave off. Kuddos.Kuddos to Direk Derick Cabrido for successfully mounting such a great film. It's one of the best Filipino horror films in modern times!

Aside from being an intense and original folk horror, MALLARI is a provocative portrayal of how greed, obsession of power, and complacency allow evil to thrive. Religion, imperialists, and landlords‚Ä¶ they create monsters. Piolo Pascual gives the performance of his career, and JC Santos proves once again that he is a one of a kind talent. There are times when the script‚Äôs expository dialogue makes the film cringey, but Mallari is still a powerful, thoughtprovoking film.

What makes this so impressive is that everything transitioned seamlessly. The plot might look ambitious and crowded, yet it was never blurry and compromised. JC Santos is a favorite for me ‚Äî that exact moment of his was significant and breathtaking.

cons : ang daming jumpscare, unnecessary eh para lang matawag na horror emepros : ganda ng transitions and delivery. angas din ng cinematog like fr, kada pov na kuhanan angas as fuck. alsoooo, oks sakin 'yung ending idk sa iba pero ok n eun na ganern n lng .

The story is a filmmaker's dream, inspired by the events of Fr. Severino Mallari's killings, it's a complex and expansive story, going back & forth through 3 centuries worth of lore. It's also an opportunity for some gorgeous production, showcasing 19th & 20th century dialect, environment, and aesthetic, which this film brilliantly executed. The storytelling itself left something to be desired, where more proper character exploration were more than welcome. The killings as well is something that is promised but weren't fully delivered.It's worst aspects are it's delivery of horror, its plot twist, and ending. It has the worst standards of Philippine horror filmmaking, or rather, the standard is the worst, relying solely on loud sounds and jumpscares. They could've saved it with the make-up & design, but it's not enough. The plot twist can be seen a mile away, being able to call it out by a single scene. And lastly, without a doubt it's worst liability, is it's ending. It tries to be smart, aiming for shock value, but instead comes across as self-indulgent, and downright idiotic. It's a classic horror trope that thinks it's clever, but rather dumb.The concept and ambition is worth checking it out, but it really just can't shy away from the worst tendencies and shortcomings of Philippine horror clich√©s, which is a real shame as it has everything going for it to be a trailbrazer & change mainstream Philippine cinema for the better, but i guess for now, this will do, and i hope it's enough to spark more films like these.

the first act was messy af, thank god the succeeding acts managed to hold up...the movie didn't have to rely much on jumpscares. the story of fr. mallari in itself was already chilling enough. that was enough for the "scary parts" to revolve around it.trust me, the parts with real live humans were way scarier. *that* chasing scene was even scarier. the jumpscares already drained the viewer's energy to the point that they can no longer react well to the parts that actually mattered.overall, though, i liked the folk horror film this story became. for a more historically accurate take on this i'll wait for the tv series.AV-wise, everything is perfect. i've become a fan of piolo and jc santos now.

A very ambitious attempt in holding a story of three generations of the Mallari clan, adding Filipino folklore as part of its speculative writing, Mallari struggles to land smoothly. It‚Äôs a mystery/psychological thriller/folklore tale mashed into historical account of the very first Filipino serial killer.Almost all tropes from recent horror films, such as the Insidious, The Conjuring, and even The Nun series of films, appear in this film. Filipino filmography-wise, it has a touch of Nocebo and Ang Mga Kaibigan Ni Mama Susan.Despite it being so convoluted, the film managed to deliver a horror film that showcases the talents of its ensemble‚ÄîPiola Pascual cementing himself as one of the actors in the industry to not underestimate.Personally, these kinds of stories are my jam. And yes gwapo si Papa P.

The plot of this film was promising, they could've focused only on the astral projection ability of the Mallari clan and build something on that alone but what happened was, they stuffed so much subplots to cut the loose ends. As the film progressed, the aswang element was added, then the caretaker element, then the curse (sisiw) inheritance, and so on. It became less interesting to me because of those subplots. I was expecting it to be a psychological horror like The Shining but the subplots kind of ruined it. Still, this film offers something new and leaves a lot of room for discussion, there is so much to unpack. Again, I really think the subplots were employed to remove the plot holes and I think they are successful in accomplishing that objective but at the expense of a better storyline.

"Walang Diyos Sa Gabi"Mallari is a horror flick that is surprisingly good. There are elements that you would not expected to be added in this film. It has shockingly many twists and turns in this movie. If you thought this is a typical slasher/ serial killer movie, then think again. The cons of the movie is many annoying and unnecessary jumpscares. The beginning is also confusing and some characters are cringe to watch but the middle point of the movie will definitely recover what they did to the beginning. Also, the cinematography and performances of main characters is surprisingly good and it is worth to watch. Masasabi ko lang na may pag asa pa ang pelikulang Filipino pagdating sa horror. Dapat tayo wag mawawalan ng pag asa at least we are improving and learning from the mistakes. P.S. I nominate JC Santos for Best Supporting Actor and Gloria Diaz for Best Supporting Actress char hahaha.P.S.S. The trailer is just a tip of an iceberg.
JANELLA SALVADOR AS FINAL GIRL. WE LOVE TO SEE IT.

There is a point somewhere in the fuzzy third act of Mallari where a character named Agnes confronts one of the Piolos [there are four] in this movie, where she tells him: ‚ÄúI knew you before as a doctor. Now you‚Äôre telling me you‚Äôre a fortuneteller.‚Äù I felt her confusion so hard. Because this movie is exactly like that: it does not know what it wants to be.Because what is this? A movie about a historical serial killer? A movie about a crusading documentarian during the American colonial period? A movie about a lovelorn doctor? A movie about aswangs or manananggals? A movie about American military propaganda against the Huks? A movie about rural beliefs? A movie about social justice? A movie about the servant class eating the rich [or at least the sinful]? A movie about proto-TikTokers? [See Felicity‚Äôs final filmed confession.]A movie about ... time travel?When the time travel element was introduced, that was when I finally decided to just suspend all my longing for this movie to make sense, and just surrender to the horrendous absurdity of it all.Fact was, I was so ready to do that already the first instant Mallari wanted to underline its horror elements [mostly through cheap jump scares] by announcing them with screeching music that bludgeons the viewer to pay attention and be scared. [Screeching music. A ghost!] But it doesn‚Äôt help that they mostly announce ghouls who just stand there ‚Äî and do absolutely nothing of consequence. The movie does this ad infinitum that by the time we reach the 999th jump scare, you‚Äôre just ... numb with boredom.Which is sad, because the story of Fr. Severino Mallari ‚Äî the 18th century Filipino priest who is marked in our history as the country‚Äôs first recorded serial killer ‚Äî is already so rich with narrative possibilities. Just following that story, even if the filmmakers have to embellish it to make up for the lack of concrete historical data, would have sufficed. But screenwriter Enrico Santos, perhaps fearful that he didn't have enough material to constitute a screenplay, opted to fictionalize by making this a story about a curse transcending generations, threading it all with the very hoary device of ... time travel. That‚Äôs what you call a choice.A lot of the narrative elements of the film was certainly a CHOICE: killing off Mylene Dizon in the first few moments was a choice [hello, Drew Barrymore in Scream!], and then bringing in her cowering boy to the last few minutes to round off this story with an arrest was a choice; a priest spouting off ‚Äúwoke knowingness‚Äù and then the film proceeding to demonstrate the ‚Äúkill the gays‚Äù trope was a choice; having exactly three paintings of distant ancestors hanging in an old house as shorthand for character introductions was a choice [the other ancestors don‚Äôt matter to this family?]; Elisse Joson‚Äôs acting as a bitchy Felicity was a choice; the predictability of JC Santos‚Äô character arc from the moment he encounters Didi was a choice; the lack of serial killing was a choice; the humanizing of the serial killer was a choice; demonizing St. Bartholomew [and then making a post-script to deny this] was a choice; Piolo‚Äôs bad wig and fake beard were a choice; having characters do mouthful expository dumps as dialogue at crucial moments of high drama [to explain away gnarly narratives] was a choice ‚Äî but that one with Gloria Diaz explaining the existence of a time-traveling descendant with a knife to her throat was icing on the cake; the fact that there‚Äôs only one kind of moon ‚Äî a full moon always bathed in red ‚Äî was a choice.I was so excited to watch this film, and purposefully made it the first MMFF entry I would watch for 2023. I left the theater wondering what could have been if the screenplay was better. Sayang.

Oh God! That is a torture. An insufferably patchwork of clich√©s from the different genre canon that should combine to form a distinctive ‚Äúsomething,‚Äù but only ends up feeling like a fanfic writer trying to ape what he believes to be art. It‚Äôs all terribly vapid, fake, manufactured, devoid of any true artistic sincerity and only trying to create the image of an artistic jack of all trades. Such an absolute disappointment considering what it can achieve.

From MMFF‚Äôs past horror movies, I‚Äôm definitely watching the next year‚Äôs entry. Maybe many people are disappointed about the ending or Jonathan‚Äôs decision rather, but may we not forget that it was all because of Jonathan‚Äôs purpose on why he went back on that house‚Äîto save Agnes, his love of his life, from death. Love is indeed the most twisted curse of all. Mallari truly SERVED. There were no dead scenes as every scene was making me cover my ears‚Ä¶

The screenwriter deserves massive credit. Well conceptualized and executed. Cast was great. Whoever played the original Maria Capac deserves accolades. Cabrido nailed the tone and pacing. Thank you for taking time and not rushing the narratives. I can feel the chemistry between Cabrido and his editors.Major credit to Janella who plays Agnes for her subtle but impactful portrayal.JC Santos should get a ton of awards for this, for the following year. So controlled yet effortless.Awards giving bodies shouldn‚Äôt sleep on Gloria Diaz‚Äô performance here. That was brave and sharp in delivery.Awards giving bodies shouldn‚Äôt sleep on Gloria Diaz‚Äô performance here. That was brave and sharp in delivery.

‚ÄúAng isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon‚Ä¶ minamahal‚Ä¶ at mga pagkakamali.‚Äù (A person is made up of all of his decisions, beloveds, and mistakes.)i am usually hard to please when it comes to horror but Mallari was a pleasant surprise. the plot, particularly, piqued my interest: an origin story inspired by the very first documented Filipino serial killer, who happened to be a small town parish priest.Cabrido could easily make this a docu-style retelling but no. he took the material up a notch, made it an intergenerational story of the Mallaris, time-travelling in vignette storytelling, to unlock and reconcile each other‚Äôs past. honestly, that‚Äôs inextricably hard to land and i applaud the film just for this alone. the picturesque cinematography is just cherry on top. the vfx choices aren‚Äôt its strong suit. sometimes, i also question the relevance of its rather abundant jumpscares. that‚Äôs forgivable, at least for the most part. but you can‚Äôt dismiss how fresh this film was; how it was able to build such a unique tension with the audience made it bridge all of the mentioned shortfalls. overall, this film is a bloodcurdling picture of love‚Äîa curse in itself‚Äîas to what lengths it would take to love someone, even if we‚Äôve become the monster ourselves. would you still call it love‚Ä¶ or a curse spellbound?[Metro Manila Film Festival 2023]

"demonyo ka man, demonyo ka naman namin" is giving "you're a mess, but you're my mess" piolo futher proves he's truly a topnotch actor of this generation!!! his three-generation mallari may have the glitz and glamour, but JC SANTOS KILLED IT IN HIS ROLE!!!! ang satisfying panoorin ng scenes nila ni piolo together huhu give him all the supporting actor award now pls

Isn‚Äôt loving someone also a curse? If they did the usual and conventional type of biopic, it would have been a lot better tho. Nonetheless, I like this film to an extent, so much potential. I just hoped they explored the psychological and emotional turmoil Fr. Mallari has gone through as well as how he was persecuted and convicted. It would have been nice to see Mallari‚Äôs point of view and constant agonize and suffering going through his thoughts and with the people around him. Honest take is: real life stories are much scarier than the typical jump scares. I also don‚Äôt feel the astral projection and time travel thingy and not to mention, the sudden manananggal and werewolf scene we all didn‚Äôt see coming. However, we could not just deny the fact that Piolo and John Carlo did carry the film all throughout. They were spectacular and eerie. The real story is in itself something that would keep us at night. Focusing on the series of sudden murders in 1810 as well as the human leeches of his life would help us retrospect better the unfortunate era. After all, Mabuhay ang Pelikulang Pilipino. Kudos to Team Mallari.

Ang ganda ng konsepto ng pelikulang 'to.At first naguguluhan ako kung saan ito papunta but once the threads started to make sense talagang nabibilib ako how well-crafted the mystery surrounded this movie.For a Filipino horror movie, napaka-husay ng production design at cinematography nito. Makikita mo mismo ang kaibahan ng tatlong timeline dahil dito.Piolo Pascual delivers distinctive performances, consistently adapting to the story's different timelines. From an innocent to killer gaze, talagang matutunaw ka kay Papa P.The film's strength was showcased in the third act of the movie. Serving the final conclusion in each needles they've build up at the start of the movie. Maaaring minsan bumabagal ito at tila nawawala sa momentum ngunit naibabalik nila ito kada nasasagot ang mga itina-taas nitong mga tanong.What I don't like about Filipino movies is they always tend to hold back with the ending---luckily, Mallari doesn't!Alam ng Mallari ang storyang gusto nitong italakay at tuloy-tuloy nila itong inilatag. The movie never lose their focus and I really enjoyed it despite the cliche jumpscares and some bad scene choices.

Gorgeous production on this, but this movie is pretty dumb. It's hard to talk about without giving too much away, but we can start with the horror aspects of this, which largely involve jump scares that don't actually lead to anything. Like, I guess the ghosts are just there to play pranks on the characters, like they were TikTok influencers.But here's an example of something dumb: at one point, the main character is handed a film reel that he's been looking for by a girl who apparently just had an encounter with the ghost. To be clear: this is a film reel that holds vital information regarding the very reason he's gone back to his family home in the first place, potentially giving him the answers he's been looking for in order to prevent some future disaster.In the next cut, we see him sweeping in the garden. Guess it wasn't that important after all.Full review on Spot.ph

Convoluted and highly derivative. It seems like whoever developed the story for Mallari was inspired by too many TV shows and movies available on Netflix (Dark, the Fear Street series, Inception, and the Insidious franchise, just to name a few) and decided to create a film that captures the best elements from each, just packaged in a different manner. Unfortunately, what they ended up with is a film facing a serious identity crisis. It desperately wants to tell so many stories but fails to dive deeply into most of them. I left the cinema feeling disappointed because I was really looking forward to watching this.Top-notch acting from Piolo Pascual and JC Santos, though.

Mallari takes place in the nineteenth century in Magalang, Pampanga. Following the crimes of Father Severino Mallari, back in the day, he used to serve the church and champion the needs of his poor countrymen. He was known as a priest who had a heart for the needy. Everything was fine until an unfortunate event took place: his mother got ill.Mallari is a film beautifully created, packed with scenes that will keep you on the edge of your seat. It was both visually and audibly beautiful.The actors were outstanding in terms of portraying their characters. JC Santos was remarkable in this flick. Piolo Pascual made another outstanding performance that will surely entertain you and make you love him more as an actor. Elise Joson was equally commendable for her short yet very effective portrayal. Janella Salvador spiced up the movie's last act with some flavor and intensity. Enrico Santos and Derick Cabrido's screenplay and direction were a match made in heaven. The cinematography, color grading, production design, and sound design were all remarkable.If you are looking for an entertaining and outstanding horror film, Mallari is definitely for you.

Mallari (Derick Cabrido, '23)MMFF4.5 / 5 stars"There is no God at night,"I was very excited when I heard the news about this movie, considering that it was distributed by Warner Bros. PH. It's just refreshing to see Piolo Pascual on the big screen again (He's also in GomBurZa movie, by the way). It was a messy puzzle piece in the beginning. I'm not that impressed with the opening sequence since I expected a little more brutal, but the middle gets a little more interesting, and the third act is the kick and punch that I've been waiting for. Though the movie had jumpscares that felt tired, the production design, the sound design, and the cinematography is just AMAZING!! Piolo and JC Santos really delivered. The premise is really interesting as this is the only recorded serial killer priest in the Philippines. The elements added to it were very interesting but kind of failed to really play with it l, but all in all, I can say that I'm still proud of the output. Give Piolo Pascual the Best Actor!!!

i watched this today in person and i can tell you it was worth it! i don't usually watch horror films before but now i enjoy the genre so i tried this out for a change and it didn't disappoint me. the only documented serial killer in the Philippines is Juan Severino Mallari from Magalang, Pampanga. i am also kapampangan and i liked how they atleast tried to showcase our culture even in just glimpse like they tried to speak our language as the scenes were re-enacted and set in pampanga.the movie isn't perfect but it was really good and i could see the effort all throughout the film. what a beautiful production! some scenes may be a bit questionable BUT i liked how it also involved the humor of today's society, the way the culture of the past was portrayed like it was a re-enactment of past events in our history, and most importantly the filipino myths. god! i appreciate that it wasn't a slowburn also, it was just like getting hit by an axe on the head immediately. i am OBSESSED with this film, i just want to say what an entry!(p.s we are not a clan of killers as a quote from the film) except the mallaris.

Was never a fan of horror/thriller films kasi mabilis talaga ako matakot at mapraning but ever since nalaman ko yung story ni Fr. Mallari at nung may rumor na gagawin siyang pelikula hindi na ako nagdalawang isip na ito ang unahin kong panoorin mag-isa. Afterall, im a sucker for history talaga at istorya ito first documented serial killer priest sa Pilipinas. Ang ganda na napakita nila ang tatlong magkaibang time period sa pilipinas at mas lalo ko pa ito nagustuhan kung paano nila ito tinahi at na overlap dahil sa ***tooot***. Huling-huli nila ang atensyon ko rito kudos! Epektibo ang mga jumpscares, may iba rito na ramdam mo na agad pero meron rin na di mo akalain na may gugulat. May mga cliche scenarios na sa tingin ko naman ay hindi mawawala sa isang thriller film pero sa tingin ko naman ay naging smooth pa rin naman ang panonood ng pelikula. Medyo disappointed nga lang ako sa ibang dialogues na sa tingin ko ay mas better na i-reword o isulat. Masaya na nalahad sa pelikula na ito ang iba‚Äôt-ibang issue at kultura sa Pilipinas. Nandito ang ibang topic katulad ng classism, imperialism, greediness. Isama na rin natin na napakita rito ang iba‚Äôt-ibang myths at folklore na kinalakihan natin. Kudos sa editing. Grabe ang linis at ang ganda ng mga cuts ng bawat seq. Ang ganda ng mga biglaang cuts at transitions na nakadagdag ng pagkagulat sa mga manonood. Isa pang hinahangan ko ay ang production design. Wala ako masabi dahil ginawa nila ito from scratch. Taas talaga ng respeto ko sa kanila üôåüèªAnd to Piolo, GRABE KA TALAGA. Sobrang galing niya rito at hindi na ako mabibigla kung ibigay sakanya ang Best Actor Award. Napakadaming karakter ang kanyang ginampanan sa pelikula na ito at SLAAAAY si phiepasaur sa lahat. Pinakapaborito ko sigurong karakter niya ay si Fr. Severino. Tangina. Tangina lang. Kitang-kita mo yung pagiging banal at pagiging creepy niya at the same time. May isang scene talaga ako roon na pinakapaborito ko at di ko malilimutan. Lumabas nang sobra ang galing ni Piolo sa aktingan. Kitang-kita mo ang pagiging takot, pagkalito, at pagiging desperado niya. Grabe galing. Kay JC rin! Grabe sanay ako makita siya sa mga cliche romance films pero masaya ako na ibang character ang na portray niya rito. Bagay sakanya ang mga ganitong genre at character!Overall na enjoy ko ang pelikula, i just wished na sana mas nag focus ito sa lumang panahon pero gets ko naman na kailangan ng spice para mas maging kakaiba. Congrats sa Team Mallari! Also, shet sexy ng warner bros sa opening! Dazzerb naman ang hype and recognition ng film na ito.

These jumpscares are really lazy filmmaking to me. They're all so predictable, which is what makes Mallari, an otherwise decently constructed and handsomely produced film, a disappointment. There's little to no attempt to mislead or create an eerie atmosphere through score; sometimes, maybe being too loud isn't always the best choice for a scene. Also prolly why a lot of people didn't find it scary. Janella also a little awkward as Piolo's girlfriend. Some wonky vfx. Other than that, I like the rest, even Miss Gloria Diaz. Intriguing story held together by good editing choices and a committed central performance.

A promising concept centered on the Philippines' first serial killer who is a priest, but ultimately wasted by filling it with multiple ideas. The movie spans tropes from thriller, sci-fi, folklore, historical, romance, even family drama genres. Many interesting threads woven together, sure, but the design of this script could have been less busy so we could appreciate each one ‚Äì personally, I would have liked more of a story behind the dark magic stuff so that it would be less of a twist in the final act and more of a creepy world long hidden in the shadows. Also, since the main character is a priest, a peek into the social climate of the church-centered 1800s provincial barrio would have been interesting (though I guess we already have Gomburza in the MMFF lineup to show us something like it). This is a horror movie with high-quality visuals, so you'd think the scares should at least be good. But no, they're all cheap jumpscares carried by a loud score or sound. I will admit that being in a packed theater contributes to a better viewing experience. People were really into it, screaming at the right parts, laughing at the right parts, anticipating with bated breath the (sometimes predictable plot twists) at the right parts. Mostly, it's thanks to a solid cast led by Piolo Pascual as three different characters and his friend Lucas played by JC Santos. Technically, aside from a particularly bad CGI scene, this is a decent feat for the Philippine horror genre. If only it were more focused.Full review here.

+ Though being a Filipino horror-flick filled with cheap unearned jumpscares, the inspiration of classical Manananggal folklore, and having Philippines' first and only recorded serial killer as it's backbone, "Mallari" attempts to create a mythology around Fr. Mallari and their cursed bloodline, and succeeds only because it's clear that Warner Bros. really poured money into this. Plus points on it's creativity and ambition but its faults of overstaying it's welcome is prevelent. The messy pacing, editing, and story makes for a complicated albeit entertaining watch ‚Äîcarried by Piolo Pascual. Maybe Fr. Mallari's silhouette is enough to make this a memorable, maybe somewhat Hollywood 90s campy, horror film but, really, to hope for that is foolish. Still, I'll consider this a step in the right direction towards a future of more and more creative, challenging, and entertaining stories. Welcome to the Philippine entertainment industry Warner Bros.

Satisfying to see how it all came together but i feel like the film was too full circle that some parts were just predictable.I loved how mallari explored Filipino folklore because istg mfs be sleepin on that shit. Mallari excels as a mystery/thriller, skillfully interweaving Fr. Severino Mallari's story with Filipino mythology, delving into themes of love, sacrifice, and the supernatural. For those seeking heart-pounding horror and intense scares, this might not cater to your expectations. Piolo Pascual's outstanding portrayal of three distinct characters remains a highlight, although some supporting actors struggle to match his depth, impacting the film's overall cohesiveness. Additionally, attempts at modern dialogue occasionally feel forced, aiming to resonate with contemporary audiences but often missing the mark.However, it falls short in certain technical aspects, with some special effects momentarily disrupting the immersion. Moreover, the excessive use of predictable jump scares might disappoint those seeking a more nuanced and suspenseful thriller experience. While the narrative's non-linear structure converges effectively, some scenes in the first act might feel eye-roll-worthy. Despite these initial hiccups, Mallari gains momentum over time. The clever interweaving of timelines culminates in a gripping third act, redeeming the movie's earlier flaws. Noteworthy performances, including JC Santos's compelling contribution, complement the film's exploration of mythology and folklore.Ultimately, Mallari remains a captivating watch for enthusiasts of intricate storytelling, showcasing Pascual's remarkable acting abilities. As it navigates through love, sacrifice, and the supernatural, Mallari's imperfect yet engaging portrayal leaves an indelible mark, resonating with those fascinated by the depths of human experience and the enigmatic allure of Filipino folklore.Peak Filipino cinema is back on the menu.

Mallari, the 3rd film I‚Äôve seen this MMFF 2023.. Maybe I was expecting it to be good but it left me pretty disappointed.Pros: Sound design was pretty effective. I think JC Santos and Piolo Pascual‚Äôs acting was effective.Cons: Convoluted story made it hard to understand. I like non-linear storytelling, but in this case, It wasn‚Äôt executed properly. The dialogues were cringey. Aside from JC and Piolo, the supporting cast didn‚Äôt help in elevating the movie. I don‚Äôt know if its bad writing or the actors didn‚Äôt give the script justice. The insertion of humor is unnecessary and didn‚Äôt add anything to the table. I wish that they have stick to a specific storyline of the 1st Pinoy serial killer instead of adding storylines involving Filipino mythology and creatures. It guises itself to be complex but ended up dumbing the whole thing out. Visual effects could be better.
the only thing redeemable about this movie is Papa P on a tank top

Ang daming gustong sabihin, pero wala namang impact. I'd appreciate it more if they just focused on one timeline and on the killer aspect. It relies on jumpscares too much. The dialogues are also awkward - trying too hard.The acting of JC Santos was so good though!

The nonlinear structure, intercutting with three different timelines, finding the connection with its sometimes steady or stagnant pacing, finds its way nowhere near home. A must-be realization for Enrico Santos, the screenwriter.The killing never stops, but producing a big project with magnificent visuals with, no disrespect, a very disappointing writing shall stop. Forty-five minutes into the cinema, the film finally makes sense that the intro is trying to foreshadow ‚Äî manlalakbays.No question about it. However, the use of jump scares to prolong the first act of the film is way too traditional or 2000s. Those do not contribute nor give any hint at all on why Piolo is in search of answers to their three generations of Mallari‚Äôs story. Admittedly, the first hour can be shortened to 15-25 minutes. Remove the jump scares. Just do not feed anything information through visuals; then that alone is enough for the audience to feel the genre. A bummer, still, is the used dialogues to tell a piece of information about either the timeline of the present or the story of past Piolo generations. It could have used the very evident big budget to convey information through visuals instead of throwing lines. Imagine, the film is visually pleasing and plausible, but it does not give anything or help in the progress of the plot. Such, such a waste of opportunity.The detour part of this journey is beauty ‚Äî production visuals and cinematography.All-in production design. The worlds, as in three different timelines, are well put together. No one dares to refute or even question its costume or the artistic choice; the use of wardrobes and prosthetics. It speaks so much about how the audience accepts the world is shown, displayed, and given to them. Not an easy task to build a world that the audience can easily comprehend, but Mallari does it, and mind you, building THREE TIMELINES. Moreover, the sound design and music score need recognition. Although the need for a revisit in sound mixing due to its inconsistent loudness is a must, it still is a world-class quality. These perfectly and exactly convey the emotion of the characters, as well as the atmosphere of different sequences. Neither a riser nor a drone are instruments or techniques used in the film. An example is the use of bells as a score while killing the landlord in 1812.Feels bad for Piolo Pascual in a good manner. He looks exhausted by performing three characters with different distinctive personalities but conveys it justly and rightly. He may soon retire after pulling off such a performance in Mallari. No one can do that.Despite the negatives, the film counters its flaws through a good, well-thought mise-en-scene. The job of director does well in directing, putting all together by using each department‚Äôs strengths while masquerading its lows.In simple terms, the film is in the right hands, the right job, and the right driver. Writing aside due to its being subpar, all goes well. The audience just needs to learn and get used to it.

Mallari successfully weaved an intricate tale of horror w/ a dash of sci-fi & folklore. It's heart however, which is a tale of love, is actually what prevented me 4m giving it a higher score. It set back its own visual myth by excessive jump scares and didacticism.Pasimplehin natin, minurder ni Enrico Santos yung sarili niyang script sa dulo with cheesy declarations na para bang bigla akong nanood ng Cathy Garcia Molina film. Yung shift gear ni Derrick Cabrido to borderline campy sa dulo eh magegets mo, ito parang tinamad o nilagnat nung sa dulo. Even though it draws inspiration from Insidious and Suspiria, it has managed to be unique and memorable. Di ba, mga ka-sisiw?

The concept of having three generations of Mallari, delving on folklore and catholicism is the strength of this film. Although it was based from the true story of Fr. Severino Mallari's serial killing, it was fictionalized by creating a generation of Mallari to show how love and curse overlap over the course of time. Is curse inevitable, is anything done for love be justified, are the existential questions that can be seen with the acts of the three main characters. However, despite its good points, it has to be said that it has dumb and unnecessary parts for the sake of being called horror, like most horror films, of course. It holds so much potential. Maybe that's why it's ambitious for wanting a lot to happen. Glad that transitions are good in the middle because the beginning seemed shaky to me due to its overuse of jumpscares (that are, by the way, predictable). Also, I see that it has to involve folklore, but does it really have to include the scene of Facunda transforming into a manananggal (just one of the many weird stuff)? The belief of killing to save more lives is enough to incorporate it. As to script, it's as if there's not much research on language use. As a Kapampangan, the sudden switch from Filipino to Kapampangan to Filipino again didn't seem natural, as if it was only used to show it explored the setting but failed nonetheless. The usage of Tagalog as to period is a bit inappropriate as well.Overall, the attempt to tell the story of the first serial killer in the Philippines in a creative way is something I can appreciate. I just wish it's more psychological.

While the writing and handling of multiple timelines can sometimes feel jarring, it was redeemed by its dark tone, atmosphere, twists, and a story that feels unique and very ambitious. Piolo Pascual is excellent in portraying the three lead characters. But the real surprise here is JC Santos, who gave an impressive performance as Brother Lucas. The rest of the cast gave it their all, too. The theme song for this film by juan karlos and Quest is *chef's kiss* üëåüèª

Padre Severino Mallari is the first document serial killer from the Philippines with 57 victims under his name. It was believed that his mother was cursed thats why Mallari resorted to unaliving to counter the black magic.What really left an impression for me from this film is the line saying, we are all Severino. Parang sinasabi sa atin na lahat tayo ay may bersyon ng sarili nating halimaw. And this clearly seen in the movie. His mother‚Äôs curse had its own form. Years later the curse takes on a different form when it moves to its next body. And along those lines we discover how intergenerational trauma is passed on.At the same time it lets us explore the deep end of what we can do when we are pushed to the brink. How much of ourselves we are willing to sacrifice in order to save a loved one. Blurring the lines between right and wrong. At napakagaling ni Piolo Pascual having to portray 3 different characters struggling along those lines.Hindi ako as much a big fan of jump scares but i appreciate it when done well. But not so much on this movie and the sound design made it a bit more cliche. Although i greatly appreciate the score though, mas nadagdagan ang tension and atmosphere ng mga scenes na nakakatakot. This film excels in a lot of its technical aspects, from cinematography, production design, costumes and editing. And it makes it worth the cinema ticket to watch this on the big screen.Was really impressed at Mallari. Shoutout sa katabi ko kanina sa cinema na di ko kilala na tumalon sa kanyang upuan after one of the jump scares.

This movie is only a fun watch if you are in the cinema with everyone laughing and screaming. Production design is also great.But by itself without spoiling anything the film is both obtuse/confusing and over explained at the same time.Also it feels kinda lazy in the way it portrayed the local filipino villagers as this evil pagan force that is against the "good" of the catholic church and manipulates people to do evil things.It's like it wanted to show the desperation of these people and how they fight back- but decided not to resulting into this demonized portrayal of local culture and beliefs which sucks.

i looooved watching this pero i have a lot of totz....obviously anlaki ng budget az andaming partner/sponsor pero i think that was kind of its downfall also?like for example dahil may pambayad, nagcast ng napakalaking star na si papa p. i dont think this role was for him and sobrang nakulangan ako sa acting niya for 2/3 of the duration. honestly the muchachas ate him up sa mga scenes nila together. love them ang talented nila <3and then isa pa yung chemistry nila ni janella salvador. first of all, ang weird lang kasi parang super different generations sila ng actors, and second of all wala lang talaga silang chemistry like nde ko maramdaman na totoo yung nangyayari sa screen!tapooos finally may budget for matinding cgi and actually bet ko ang pagkagawa dun sa eyeless ghosts (literally my #1 fear) KASO ginamitan rin nila ng cgi si ms gloria diaz and di siya kasing ganda nung ghosts. feeling ko lang mas effective ang practical fx sa ganun especially since parang matandang kandila na natutunaw na ang look na habol (similar to the matanda sa X). seeing poor editing really takes you out of the experience :(sa screenplay side naman, i think visually, maganda ang kanyang ginawa sa larger plotline kaso yung dialogue talaga medyo nakakatanga. hindi ko magets bakit may napakagen z na dialogue. para ba maemphasize na yun yung modern timeline? i think it would have worked without that though kasi napakaiba naman ng costume and set design ng 1940s timeline???? ewan iritado lang ako sa masyadong chronically online dialogue kasi it really dates a film and kind of yun nga.... takes me out of the experience.ang weird rin ng representation sa lgbt+ community. i think they were trying to be woke pero why naman ganun pagkasulat sa kanya? a flighty gay person who everyone knows is a sex worker catering to foreigners......?!?!?!? yan pa lang naaalala ko for now so might edit pag meron pa. overall i enjoyed it pero this really would have been better with another lead actor. though some things are very similar sa The Dream Thieves by Maggie Stievfater, i think medyo original naman ang kanyang idea :)

I could have given MALLARI a perfect score of 5 but to call it a cinematic from hell masterpiece is a big no. The narrative seems to be my reservation here. Not really a fan of time travel except for SOMEWHERE IN TIME where the narrative is neatly tied up and HAPLOS. There are times that it's rather confusing and how I wish D Cabrido divided the time frame from the first time Fr MALLARI appeared in 1800s to 1940s ended with the present times. What was served on the plate was a palabok about the Filipino mythological creatures and to tell more about it will spoil the fun. Find out how Donya Facunda played by Gloria Diaz the mother of Fr. Mallari lived for so long. The Gregorian chant, music, production design are all top notch! And that was one helluva performance of Piolo Pascual. Two scenes that stand out for me his dance sequence with Gloria Diaz and his breakdown scene where you can spot also the evil side of him.Btw that house in Pampanga and the image of St. Bartholomew really creeped me out! All in all an excellent Pinoy horror flick and I'm glad Warner Bros distributed it.

"Ang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang desisyon"8. "Walang Diyos sa gabi" was on-loop in my head when I got home.9. So right now, nasan ang sisiw??10. This is Piolo Pascual in multiverse of madness.

It's no wonder that the huge studio outfit Warner Bros. Pictures Philippines distributed Derick Cabrido's timeline-jumping horror flick. After all, it's riveting and perfect for mass consumption. "MALLARI", partly-historical, partly-fictional, horrifies with its convoluted yet easy-to-follow storylines of three generations amid murder, mystery, and supernatural folklore. Piolo Pascual brilliantly plays three different characters that are well-meshed in its narrative. Its thrilling score and effective jump scares (although I wish there's more slow burn approach) make a good form that we don't usually experience in most Pinoy horror films. However, there's that miss of questionable mesh on time travel and astral projection and the pitfalls of telling vs. showing narrative technique that makes the execution a bit dull. The third act redeems itself with its intense buildup and that eerie final frame serving a nod to the endless horrors of society.San Bartolome. Do√±a Facunda. Magalang. Di ba, isang sumpa ang magmahal? (Isn't loving a curse?). 3.5/5 folks!

Nakamamahanga at nakakakilabot. Nakamamangha kasi kaya pala nating gumawa ng ganitong klase ng pelikulang makakasabay sa agos ng modernong pagkekwento. Nakakakilabot dahil ang kwentong ginamit ay may hango sa katotohanan at nakaugat sa mga bagay na kinatatakutan ng mga Pilipino.This film reinvents how Filipino horror stories were told. Marami ng pelikula ang patungkol sa mga kwento at paniniwala ng mga Pilipino pero ibang klaseng takot ang naramdaman ko rito. They utilized those elements properly and effectively.Ang pelikula ay isang malaking paglalakbay. Ginawa nila tayong manlalakbay dahil sinama nila tayo sa pag-aalam ng misteryo at sikreto sa likod ng pamilya Mallari. Sinigurado nila na mararamdaman natin ang kanilang mararanasan, makikita, at malalaman.Nakadagdag din ang magandang cinematography sa pagbuo ng intriguing na atmosphere. Nakapagbigay kilabot ang scoring para mas matakot ka pa lalo. Paniniwalaan mo ang kanilang mga practical effects na ginamit. Ilan lamang ang mga ito sa nakapagdala sa atin sa kanilang mundo. Each timeline has its distinct feel and tone, at napanindigan ito ng mga tao sa likod at harap ng kamera para masiguro na iba-iba sa pakiramdam ng manonood ang bawat panahong pinapasukan nila. Dinadala nila tayo sa iba't ibang panahon at mararamdaman mo talaga ito.Piolo Pascual definitely gave his A-game into this performance. He knew how to give that flare and nuance that will make his three portrayals different from each other. Kaya ka niyang palungkutin, pakabahin, at takutin. He is deserving to get recognition and appreciation because of his performance. He deserves that best actor award. Magagaling din ang mga ibang karakter at bagay ito sa mga artistang gumanap sa kanila. Janella Salvador had this sense of style na siya lang makakapagpamalas. Geraldine Villamil knew how to evoke terror. Elisse Joson blew my mind with her polished attitude. Ms. Gloria Diaz gave something that we never see from her until now. But out of all of the supporting characters, Jc Santos provided the most shocking performance. Dapat mong abangan ang kanyang pagganap dahil madadala ka sa kanya nang sobra.Most importantly, ang pinakanagustuhan ko sa pelikula na ito ay ang kanyang mensahe. Hindi lang siya about sa kuro-kuro ng sambayanan kundi pinakita rin dito ang mga hirap ng pamilya at ano ang makakaya mong ibigay para mapuna ang mga ito.This is a historical story of a family trying to escape from the terrors of the past that continue to creeps the present and that could greatly affect the future. With all that in mind, they knew how to tie all of it together in a jaw-dropping ending. Marami ang hindi ko inakala sa pelikulang ito. Hindi ko inakala na ganito ang kanyang kwento. Hindi ko inakala na sisigaw at matatakot ako nang sobra. At higit sa lahat, hindi ko inakala na makagagawa ang Pilipino ng ganitong klase ng pelikula. This is a film made by Filipinos based on Filipino horror stories that all Filipinos should be proud of. This is the new standard for Filipino Horror.

Two Piolos wrestling each other? Now that‚Äôs cinema!(Spoilers incoming)This almost worked. The 1800s sequences, in particular, are the film‚Äôs shining moments. It was creepy and almost compelling ‚Äî the occult infiltrating Christianity/the oppressed tearing down the elite from the inside are proof that this should‚Äôve been a period piece.Still, this particular section of the film is also riddled with sins. The crux of it (showing how Father Severino started with his murder spree) was believable but was not strong enough. You mean, Father Severino is so downtrodden in faith that he resorted to do‚Ä¶that? In one request? The film didn‚Äôt even allow the character to explore options or resist. A film about a crisis of faith? What! A missed opportunity. He was just a piece of this convoluted puzzle. And when his faith was shattered. No one batted an eye. His relationship with his mother wasn‚Äôt explored enough nor who Father Severino really is ‚Äî again why this should‚Äôve been a period piece that began with his childhood.Well, this was tooled to be commercially successful and how else to fulfill that but peppering with deadly tropes ‚Äî time travel, astral projection, love is also a curse shenanigans, innocent ghosts who also like scaring people for the heck of it, a dozen of jump scares, and TikTok humor? Don‚Äôt get me wrong. This was so much fun! Especially with a packed theater.Mallari, unfortunately, hacked into many elements but only managed a minor cut.

from the get-go, mallari works with an interesting premise: the first documented serial killer in the country. it takes the story a step further by introducing two other timelines, with characters that interact through lucid dreaming. the story is weaved together spectacularly, as the threads among such time periods felt smooth and weren‚Äôt forced. the concept is set up nicely, providing sufficient suspense to keep one hooked throughout the movie. i guess my most major issue with it is its framing‚Ä¶

While it does, at points, play like a pastiche of the most well-known genre tropes (not just horror), I am willing to overlook that nature of Mallari as what we get here, beyond the clich√©s, is a very meaty and layered story with pensive meditations on the bounds of a person‚Äôs love and familial loyalty. As the film was running I was thinking of how they were going to resolve the story and while I couldn‚Äôt, at the time, pinpoint how I would want the story to wrap up, I could very well list a handful of ways how I wouldn‚Äôt want the film to end and, without spoiling anything, I think they really stuck the landing with that ending.We may have different tastes and what we look for in films may be different but, Mallari, as a whole, is a film that just works, at least for me. I definitely recommend seeing this.

Gorgeous production; it definitely surpassed my expectations a little bit, considering that it was a locally-made film. This is noteworthy as I don't watch them that often.However, it is also different from what I expected. I was anticipating something of a biopic, telling the story of the first-ever recorded PH serial killer. The direction that the movie took was a bit different, but it's fine, as it was still interesting.For me, the jump scares were not that effective. Considering that it is a high-budget and relatively costly production, you would expect great ones, but most of them were just cheap jump scares carried by loud sounds. The film also focused on too many genres, such as family, horror, comedy, and fantasy, to name a few. I wish those concepts were not overloaded so that we could focus more on the lore.The character of Lucas (JC Santos) was not that convincing, given that he had a huge role. It felt lackluster due to his character's development.The pacing and direction were mediocre at best. There were some highs where the theater was excited about what events might unfold next, screaming and just being hyped. However, there were also disadvantages, such as in the first act where the film was kinda hard to follow.On a positive note, the concept itself was enticing since it's about horror (my favorite genre), and the Philippine mythology was also showcased well.Piolo Pascual also looked great and proved himself to be a versatile actor. His supporting cast also did really well, providing twists and more diversity.All in all, the concept was interesting; it just was not executed to its fullest. Elements were overloaded, and it was a bit hard to follow, but the cast was great, and the production is definitely a level up from its predecessors.

Piolo Pascual's portrayals of the three characters are mostly inconsistent and lacking nuance. There are scenes where his Johnrey and his Jonathan are almost alike. When his Severino and his Jonathan meet in one of the crucial scenes, the former seems to have become the latter. He is also Jonathan. Or Piolo. There's one scene, though, where he transforms completely. Regardless of how the scene is set-up and built to be this important, his portrayal of this character is utterly diabolical. So good. I won't spoil. You'll know what I mean when you see the film. It is JC Santos who is consistently impressive in the film. His evolution comes to a riveting performance deserving of recognition. Watch out for this one scene where he outshines his co-actor. The film could have done more in terms of VFX. Its score could have been tempered for a more dramatic effect, but despite what the film lacks, it achieves something remarkable for the genre. Enrico Santos wrote a screenplay that weaves an interesting mix of the horror and the time-travel narrative. The script is complemented with well-paced execution and engaging scenes. Overall, Mallari is a compelling watch--a Pinoy genre film not easy to forget.

Initially, I wanted to watch this film because it was my surname (which doesn't happen often) and because of the premise (how do they make a film out of the country's first serial killer who was a priest?) I liked the way the narrative was told, the interconnected timelines and astral projection concept was explained well. However, it did leave a lot of questions; why did the Mallari family have this ability? It kinda took away from the whole historical‚Ä¶

MALLARI How far will you go just to keep your loved ones alive? One of the best horror films I have ever watched. It is a three-timeline story that is all being connected by a single superstition. The story revolves around Fr. Severino Mallari, a true-to-life priest from Pampanga in 1812 and is the first ever documented serial killer in the Philippines. Then fictional characters Johnrey Mallari, a documentarist in 1948, and Jonathan Mallari, a doctor in the present day.‚Ä¶

The commendable cinematography paints a visually arresting landscape, showcasing a keen eye for detail in every scene. However, the film's occasional dependence on excessively loud sounds for an eerie effect raises concerns about its subtlety and may potentially overpower the audience's senses.While the narrative unfolds, numerous unnecessary jump scares seem to be sprinkled throughout. The inclusion of cheesy dialogue exchanges between Agnes and Jonathan, these moments, rather than enhancing the story, feel gratuitous and detract from the overall viewing experience.Despite these drawbacks, this film manages to reach a level of acceptability. However, there are certain parts that leave some viewers questioning the subtlety of its approach.Undoubtedly, Johnrey is my bias. He's the only one tunay, palaban, at makabayan <3[By the way, opting for a late-night cinema screening at 10:45 PM added a dimension to the viewing experience.]

Mallari highly delivered the fright taking this historically accurate character and building this disturbing world that bridges both "sci-fi" and Philippine folklore. It had the mass appeal of a true horror flick (including the character's dumb decisions) but still made sure that there were no loose ends. Even with these merits, it suffered a few mishaps. In the performances, Piolo did his best portraying these three separate individuals from different timelines but it did not help that JC Santos outacted him in almost all of their scenes together. The 3 characters also needed a bit more distinction but still a commendable performance nonetheless. But probably the biggest blunder is how it was overscored. The source material I believe can shine by itself without us being dictated by the score on where to get scared. And the "manananggal" too was a choice. But again, the future is bright or shall I say darker üòà if this is the direction our horror flicks will go to.

"Walang Diyos sa gabi."MALLARI has reached a spot that the other recent Filipino horror films cannot touch. At first, I was a bit skeptical on how the three timelines will be showcased properly in a 2-hour film yet the movie surprised me on how cohesive it is. The plot is out of this world for a typical horror film but it surprisingly accomplished its goal. In a very well manner at that. The scoring and the continuous shots are also superb, creating an eerie atmosphere throughout the duration of the film, especially in the intense scenes. However, some special effects didn't work but I'll let it pass as the story and the actors really did well to compensate for it.Lastly, I want to say that:Felicity, you are a mother to many!

An exceptional horror-thriller film about extreme determination, but for the wrong reasons. I'm so happy that the Philippine entertainment industry has come out of its cocoon and is now ready to conquer the larger global market for entertainment content. Mallari is such a stunner. Editing made a seamless integration of time jump elements. The acting is superb; Piolo is exceptional in his portrayal of the three Mallaris. His short portrayal of the demonic hallucinations, though, was chef's kiss. The screenplay kept me thinking about how the movie would end, even until the last 5 minutes. My main takeaway from this movie is that peace as a goal, when achieved by killing socially undesirable people, is diabolical. And while we may have our own personal thoughts of unaliving bad people for the sake of a better society, it is our demons that are speaking for us. Fundamentally, the movie is a satirical expression of our human follies, including extreme desire, sanctimony, and lack of good judgement.

‚Äú‚ÄòDi ba‚Äôt isang sumpa ang magmahal?‚ÄùMallari does not only showcase the story of the infamous Fr. Severino Mallari, but also delves into the lives of men from succeeding generations of his clan. The first descendant, Johnrey, a documentary filmmaker in post World War II Philippines, and the second being Jonathan De Dios, a doctor and the lead protagonist of the film. The two descendants of Fr. Severino try to discover their family‚Äôs darkest secret, which most likely has contributed to the killings and disappearances in Magalang, Pampanga.All three generations of the Mallari clan are played by Piolo Pascual, which is perceived to be difficult parts to play. However, Pascual was able to to help distinguish one generation from another and yet was able to establish the connection between all three characters.What also is depicted in the movie is the presence of important female figures in each of the Mallari men‚Äôs lives: Dona Facunda, Fr. Severino‚Äôs mother played by Ms. Gloria Diaz, Felicity, Johnrey‚Äôs wife played by Elisse Joson, and Agnes, Jonathan‚Äôs fiancee played by Janella Salvador. All three actresses gave the three women their respective well-defined characters which was able to show how each Mallari‚Äôs love for these women had urged them to take greater lengths, even if it will cost them their own morals.JC Santos does an excellent job in portraying Brother Lucas in the likeness of Brutus from Shakespeare‚Äôs Julius Caesar, as he showcases his character‚Äôs loyalty and later betrayal to Pascual‚Äôs Dr. Jonathan.The film may remind one of Luca Guadagnino‚Äôs Bones and All (2022) with its presence of common themes such as gore and manslaughter. It is also important to note how both Carido and Guadagnino have commonly used manslaughter as a dark metaphor for love as a motive of sacrifice and self-discovery, which the former has executed very well and evidently in Mallari (2023).It also bears similarities with Edgar Wright‚Äôs Last Night in Soho (2021) not just with the presence of gore and manslaughter, but also with the key theme of time travel, which the two Mallari descendants have used in order to learn about the dark secret of their family for this film.The film had a well-organized flow of events, as well as a smooth transition in between time periods. It was able to give me and other viewers proper context and a good idea on how to let the story unfold and think about what could happen next. However, Jonathan‚Äôs arc was very anti-climactic towards the end yet it established his arc as an anti-hero.Another thing to love about this film is that not only did it have Gothic themes and the use of the Catholic faith, which are associated as Western literary and cultural elements, but it also incorporated the use of Filipino folk medicine and faith healing, which are indigenous Filipino cultural elements, as important parts of the film.In conclusion, Mallari (2023) was a great watch, and it definitely deserved the accolades. Not only did it bring justice to a dark love metaphor, but it also presented and promoted Filipino culture through folk medicine as key horror elements. It is a must watch for traditional Filipino horror movie buffs and those in need of a fresh face to Filipino horror films.[Metro Manila Film Festival 2023]

It's actually a well made film if going to be compared to the last two decades of modern Filipino cinema. It's also fine if it doesn't go to the realistic, intimate retelling of the Philippines first ever recorded and controversial serial killer ala Fincher's Zodiac and instead went into a fantastical route ala Burton's Sleepy Hollow; cinema's main purpose afterall, first and foremost, is to entertain audiences and bring them into the realm of unknown. I would even recommend this as one to see among the current available selection of what to watch in the latest Manila Film festival. Great cinematography, high quality production design, star-studded amazing cast. Expected jump scares, usual of horror films. I just can't really go with the last act though when it devolves into bad CGI fest over practical makeup and effects.

For Mallari, The presence of a tangible threat stems from our protagonist‚Äôs dream, and the fact that he can see.. zombies? It deeply fails to create a sense of narrative urgency it needed until about halfway through, where suddenly it livens up its form and picks up a lot of heat. Mallari was kind of a swing and a miss but, well, it was a glorious swing nonetheless. I always complain about majority of the mainstream Filipino movies because they always seem so uninspired. They're usually either tired recreations of frustratingly melodramatic stories I've seen a million times over or they're copies of recently popular movies produced by other countries with a better film scene. So I have to commend Roderick Cabrido and the rest of the filmmakers who worked on‚Ä¶

The concept was great but there were so many ideas introduced that it all got so convoluted. I came for a biopic of Padre Mallari but I got manananggal, kulam, etc. Although it was great that they added Filipino Mythology on the plot, it still feels like there were tons of ideas thrown around that it got so jarring. I love the idea of astral projection and time travel as it is not often seen in Filipino Horror movies, however, I feel like it got too much that you'd think this is not about Padre Mallari anymore. Also, I don't also feel any chemistry between Piolo and Janella. They feel more like Uncle-Niece whenever they're together. And although, it's been instilled multiple times that Jonathan (Piolo) is obsessed with Agnes (Janella), I still don't feel it. Like they were not able to translate it on screen. Also the theater in Evia fucked up the sound system so all through out the film, I was in a sour mood.Furthermore, It's been a while since I've actually watch a Pinoy Horror film so I was amazed by the camerawork. I think this could've been great as a series rather than a movie to fully tackle what they wanted to portray.

MMFF Marathon Disclaimer:I went in blind to all MMFF entries this year, no idea on it but the poster, didn't even check the genres. So expect me being surprised on most things.I liked it just because I love Piolo Pascual and JC Santos (most of all JC, but let's talk about that later) but I gotta admit storytelling of this has lots of room to improve.It had a lot of jumpscares from ghosts that didn't lead to anywhere. I expected some payoff on the ghosts other than who they were, which was obvious on the getgo.When it was a slasher horror by the first act I was engaged gotta admit, but when the second act started and the time-traveling sci-fi direction went on the film kinda lost me. And when it went more fantastical by the third act by introducing witchcraft and a literal "manananggal" it lost me completely.As this is inspired from real events, I wish they just added upon the plot inspiration since that is an interesting story itself. I was just put-off on the closing title cards where they debunked their own story just to clarify the real story, because it kind of defeated the film. I feel like they accepted that the past 2 hours were fictional but then opening titles said it was inspired from true events.On the brighter side I saw a LOT of improvements here. Color grade was stellar, and lighting design. Night scenes were still visible (ehem hollywood for making night scenes literal darkness), also the VFX and make-up for the spirits were BEAUTIFUL, the "manananggal" part, not so much. Also, the production design. Set served. The amount of detail put into that was STELLAR, I was nitpicking even the wax drips of candles and they were accurate and realistic, very well-thought.Also, Piolo Pascual delivered on different nuances of different eras which made his performance very distinct. Without reintroducing who is who even with change of wardrobe, I knew who he was just by posture and speech. But what impressed me more is JC Santos, both sides of the coin in the soft-spoken to the gnarly side he delivered. The plot twist was underwhelming but his performance gave it a bit of value added.Addendum:One dialogue didn't sit with me after they killed off Didi, it's along the lines of: "She's a sex worker, she's a plague to society". EXCUSE ME SIR SEX WORK IS WORK. IF SHE'S A SCAMMER USE THE TERM BUT SEX WORKERS ARE NOT PLAGUES OF SOCIETY. Anyways, that's just a small hunch of "????" from me.

Mallari uses almost every kind of horror there is to separate itself from previous movies, that primarily used religion to scare or to suspend belief, of which, there are many. Using local history and folklore always gives a unique touch to a film; Mallari even highlights JC Santos (who plays Lucas) using his Kapampangan fluency. However, the CGI used can still improve; I think prosthetics are convincing for such close-up shots. Also, Piolo Pascual, despite mentioning he had an‚Ä¶

Watched during the 2023 Metro Manila Film FestivalIf someone caught me being m*rdered by Piolo Pascual, then that's on ME, do NOT arrest him!Went into this thinking it would be a retelling or highlighting the murders or the actual Severino Mallari's process as a serial killer, so that one bit admittedly let me down, but I'm aware that's a me problem. *That aside, wow what a film. I truly went into it blind and admittedly I am not a fan of horrors so this is your pass to bash me or just take what I say with a grain of salt. I am a fan of the time-travelling aspect, so I appreciated seeing that in the film. It was really interesting to see the ties between two distant pasts and the present entwined with family ties, fate, withcraft and all that... I loved it! I think that Piolo was fucking amazing in his triple roles, we are so blessed to have him in such a role on the big screen today. JC Santos truly deserved his Best Supporting Actor win, he is truly insane in this.It's kinda unfortunate the jumpscare horror elements did not really lead to anything, I feel the film could've made do with less of that or made these horror elements mean something than just cheap thrills. To me, those bits just hindered the atmosphere-building and it bothered me. It was a bit funny to me too though that the scenes that garnered most audience reaction were scenes that just involved people. I am also not a big fan of the ending, but I'll keep it at that for you to discover if you, dear reader, will like it or not.(* Edit: Just heard from my mom that there will be a series adaptation of Fr. Mallari's story with Dennis Trillo leading? I will be there no matter what.)

The devil (heh) may care attitude of Mallari really went to a place of the unidentifiable in Philippine cinema. It got so smart with the fusion of genres and somehow, cheated its way in something that is very interesting and cheeky. The genre mechanics became as polarized and those who found value in it, cared no less and the silliness is a great add-on to its narrative.The thematic journey of defeatist films always has a lot to say about bad decisions and the value of good as non-existent. Case in point, Christian Tafdrup's 2022 psychological horror thriller film, Speak No Evil. Said film excessively warns the audience about the eventual demise of the couple, the acceptance of one's fate just sets in. Mallari though, tries to fight back with its barbs and your usual good should always win over evil.It's funny that the whole point of the film had an underlying message that is extremely familiar in the recent and current political climate in the Philippines. The characters are represented by people, factions, and the entire nation. It's a sight for social media and fantasy for the optimist. And despite its hitches in a number of its film elements, it's relatively forgivable with the messaging that it wants to convey..:smcityeastortigas>>

bias ko si johnrey sakanilang tatlo at tanginaka jonathan!it‚Äôs refreshing to see new formats of horror movies in philippine cinema, although there‚Äôs a lot of use of jumpscares in this film that were dependent on sound design, it still offered a new kind of scare that somehow haunts me at night. i just wish it was fleshed out better especially the lore of the cult and the lore of the monsters.

I wish it focused more on the serial killer aspect and Fr. Severino's mental illness. Could have been a great psychological thriller film.But I understand the decision to include Filipino folklore. I just hate how they made it look like Fr. Severino was helpless. As if he had no choice but to kill. As if he deserves pity from the audience.
