I want to say it‚Äôs BEST HORROR film of the year, but my thoughts are with: the BEST FILIPINO FILM of the year. The sound design and music score is breathtaking. The writing and direction takes you to a roller coaster ride in which you can hear the audiences squealing, screaming and nervous AF. A friend of mine said, ‚ÄúHindi ako mahilig sa horror, pero, gustong gusto ko ‚Äòto.‚Äô‚ÄùPiolo gave his performance of the year. A veteran actor that reminded us that our stars are so good. JC Santos and RAFFY Tejada, two theater actors, did not disappoint. But what amazes me is the jumping timelines, spearheaded by a Haunting-of-Hill-House inspired writing: and what threads them together is our dreams, to think that history repeats itself, and it only needs one protagonist to sleepwalk and realize that his worst nightmare has become the reality in his waking life.Even the set design is built from scratch. Mallari threads as our newest breed of horror, giving us something new to look forward with the Filipino indie-mainstream scene. I‚Äôd like to believe we are witnessing a renaissance for the elevation of standards of the Filipino film. Walang kupas. Wala silang tinira. Lahat ng takot mo, hawak mo pa rin kalabas. Mero mas nakakatakot and kasakiman ng tao kaysa sa malignong naninirahan dito.At gamang gama ni Piolo ang pagarte dito. Akala mo, ipinanganak ang role na ito para sakanya.

There‚Äôs a bit too much to unpack with Mallari, serving too many elements that it takes away from the main narrative, and in turn removes from the scare factor aside from mostly meaningless jumpscares. While we barely even learn of the true origins of the titular character, it‚Äôs the production value that really makes the film great, from the visuals, prod design, scoring, and what is probably Piolo Pascual in his best role(s) yet. Despite its setbacks (and unnecessary homophobia/transphobia), Mallari‚Äôs production remains to be an impressive standard Filipino cinema should aspire to continue.

Not much is known about priest Juan Severino Mallari, said to be the Philippines' first and only serial killer, but that was all it took to create a feature film for the Metro Manila Film Festival."Mallari" (2023) won four awards at this year's Gabi ng Parangal ‚Äî 3rd Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor for JC Santos, Best Musical Score, and Best Visual Effects ‚Äî and of those four it is the latter that appears unconvincing.No doubt that win is attributed to scenes in the latter part of the film as the so-called mystery unravels, but these effects come off as cheesy like the initial jumpscares that build the film.The score by Von De Guzman can be forceful and insistent at times, but it gradually allows the film's horror structure to take charge.However Santos' win is fully well-deserved, an extreme compliment as most of his scenes are with the more seasoned Piolo Pascual and yet he manages to give his character a believable descent.That is not to be hard on Pascual though as he is given the task of juggling three different characters; his charm just happens to be too strong for this foray into horror.There is one scene though where Pascual's dramatic chops shine so bright, and it is during a silent reckoning with his actions as he dances with Gloria Diaz's Facunda, she too committed to the cause of her character.Mallari's story is undoubtedly an intriguing one to tackle, however Enrico Santos' screenplay doesn't do enough to fully utilize that premise and the plotline he decides on.Full published review: www.philstar.com/movies/2023/12/29/2321996/mallari-review-jc-santos-outshines-piolo-pascual-mmff-horror

I can sum it up as ‚Äúall style, little substance‚Äù. Technically, this is a great looking film. The cinematography (my fave part of the movie are the transitions!), the styling, the sets, the grading, the SFX, visually the movie really is on point. However, the movie literally tried to do too much with so many different horror elements coming up that everything felt half baked. A slasher with a priest turning evil? Nice. Three different characters from three different time periods and how they are connected? Smart. But when all the supernatural stuff came in, the movie went so overboard with the story that it went nowhere. But if you wanna watch Piolo Pascual being hot af x3? Go watch it.

Instead of an interesting exploration of the Philippines' only priest-turned-serial killer, MALLARI devolves into a convolution of time travel, astral projection, and local folklore. It misses to touch on the dark psyche of what could have been a good subject in film. The use of horror and jump scares get in the way of the narrative; pulling the audience farther from what could have been a real terror: that of serial killer in an institution Filipinos revere.

A unique story that is a breath of fresh air for us pinoy horror fans. I also like how the film uses scoring to amplify its horror scenes‚Äî much like a lot of slasher films in the 80s. I would like to see more about how Mallari did the killings. Also, it can be too much since there are a lot of backstories but nevertheless, I enjoyed the juxtaposition of local folklore and sci-fi. This makes it more enjoyable to watch compared to its competitors this year.

SPOILER-FREEIncredible direction by Roderick Cabrido, stunning cinematography by Pao Orendain, with amazing performances from the main actors. Mallari is a film with three different storylines that met halfway and were easy to follow because the writing, direction, acting, and cinematography were all spot on. I absolutely loved it. The effects were still a little bit wonky but that was only a small part of the film. There were three scenes in particular that made me fall in love with the film, but I won't write them here as this is a spoiler-free review. My final thoughts are that I would definitely watch this again, it was all executed beautifully.

Diba, isang sumpa ang mag-mahal?this review is coming from someone who loves reviewing films as if it's a job. i had the chance to watch this on big screen. don't get me wrong, this movie is good and all it's glory. but why 2¬Ω/5?storyline wise, great! couldn't say anything more other than the fact that the transition from different generations was seamless.cinematography? absolutely yes. perfect color grading that matches the theme, not like those very muted filters they put on films.acting? honestly, wasn't very amazed with it. it's only my opinion, and i love judging other people's acting performance as if i'm a professional critic. i'm not sure if it's because the dialogue/script, because i felt awkwardness when they're saying their lines. but then again, it's piolo's first horror movie, so there is still room for improvement if he wanted to continue this path (i would honestly support him 'cause he's such a beaut on screen). jc was phenomenal! such a versatile actor!sound design? my god, a masterpiece! can't get enough of it! they did an amazing job choosing bgmusic/sounds! kudos for that!was it scary? wouldn't say so, coming from someone who doesn't get scared easily (i do, but only for movies that has exorcism involved in it lol, i always feel like i'm gonna be possessed too). the amount of unnecessary jumpscare is sending me off, there's that one scene that felt like my soul left me, other than that, i ended up predicting what's gonna come next (cause i like doing that, to minimize the jumpscare effect lol).anyway, this is still worth watching! i hope this movie will open up for more international collaboration (imagine my surprise when i saw " warner bros' " on the opening scene).

Mike Flanagan's cinematography meets Arrival meets Parasite.Kidding, it's not fair to the movie to talk about it on the basis of comparisons. The themes are certainly there: generational trauma represented by haunted houses, reflections of the past present and future, and a mangled commentary on class politics. This was admittedly poorly paced, like a run-on sentence. I wish prestige TV was a thing locally because this would have been better fleshed out in a 7-9 episode miniseries, a la The Terror or 1899. The poor pacing resulted in what should have been an interesting premise and strong themes turned to a hodgepodge of ideas.Gorgeously produced and well acted, but with way too much fat to trim off. But like I said in my Smaller and Smaller Circles review, if this paves the way for more serial killer themed local media, let's get at it!!!

MallariInitial Trailer POV: WB will distribute the film, mukhang may mapaptunayan siya sa buong Film Fest. Lumalaban sa matinong production design, cinematography at blend ng practical at CG Effects.Okay. Kahapon pa ako eager isulat to.I left the cinema with pure satisfaction. Everything went really well!The script is superb. Nabigyan nila ng flavor ang isang historical document turned fictional narrative by slowly weaving 3 important characters and importing supporting leads and powerful events who did their part to the overall story. Madami siyang elements pero na-intorduce nila ito in an effective way--nag gu-grow sa audience lahat ng ginagawa nila at mga nangyayari sa pelikula. Naitahi nila nang maayos ito para humantong ang lahat sa isang thought provoking and heart pounding conclusion. The technical choices were powerful. I spot little technical issues, but it doesn‚Äôt drag the whole film quality down. Almost perfect and cinematic storytelling nila.Yes, may mga sequences at events na feel ko sana nai-revise or naisama sa final cut. Also wished it was more gory.But overall, it has delivered! (Its way better from the production‚Äôs 2022 entry (My Father, Myself))Natakot, nagulat, nalungkot, nainis at nagcheer kami sa mga characters at events. May pinatunayan nga!Ang saya, sobrang satisfying.Gusto ko ulitin!

walang diyos sa gabi.the clock of the story diverges and converges steadily; it gives the characters a chance to tell their side of the story. it frightens, yes. but it critiques, too. the priests and the antiquated beliefs residing within the church. the notion of retribution and whether some monsters are worth killing.sometimes, however, it imposes what it wants to do. there are jumpscares that are too superficial to move the narrative. a trope subversion just for the sake of subverting something: agnes' scream of terror in the hospital that somehow turns into jaded haughtiness as she enters their new home. the end anticipates your disbelief so much that it looks into your eyes almost imploringly.

Mallari is a pretty ambitious film. It's a slasher, also a sci-fi because of the time travel aspect and also a period piece. It's a fictionalized story about Severino Mallari, a parish priest in Pampanga who is the first Filipino serial killer. First, I just wanna say that the visuals were pretty amazing. As a horror fan, I'm glad to say that we are now catching up. Andaming magagandang ideas at concepts sa mga local horror films natin, di nalang tayo paulit-ulit. Praise-worthy ang cinematography and production design dito. The score is amazing, it really fits to the tone of the film. Piolo Pascual really did served, one of his best performances, I like it when he plays characters outside his comfort zone. Also JC Santos is pretty good here, he really deserves that best supporting actor award. First time ko rin na mapanood si Janella Salvador sa big screen, finally she's in a horror movie that doesn't suck. The film does fall into the usual horror cliches unfortunately. First, the jumpscares, there are so many jumpscares here that are just so unnecessary. Ghosts appearing left and right accompanied by a loud sound, without any purpose or significance with the story and most of the time, they are just so predictable. Di naman kasi nakakatakot ang gulat eh, hinay hinay lang din sa paggamit.I also have problems with the script. It does overexplain a lot to the audiences. A noticed a lot of exposition scenes, this film is not for children, please let the audience think and piece together the mystery themselves or just show don't tell.Mallari is an enjoyable horror film with a pretty unique concept, despite doing too much, there are many things here that you will appreciate and as a horror fan, this MMFF is a great start to finally make original and good pinoy horror films.*Ang weird lang para sakin yung mga scenes ni Janella and Piolo, parang mag ama lang sila, sorry üò≠

Initially, I found myself being quite nitpicky and complaining about a couple of minor details, visuals, jump scares and effects choices. But as the movie progressed, it grew on me and eventually captured my full insatiable attention. The story pretty much revels in its intruiging mystery. It's bold and deliciously insidious. Its wicked irreverence reminds me of films like The Omen and Rosemary's Baby. Piolo taking on the three roles reminds us of how talented he is as an actor and is pretty much capable of stretching his range. The music is powerful and tickles the horror fan in me with how much it effectively marinated the movie. MALLARI has a spectacular appeal that I enjoyed, and I was also glad to hear, once more, loud screams and reactions from horror cinema audiences. In a really good way, it reminds me of those great Pinoy horror comicbooks from the good old days. MALLARI, judging from its overall package, was a solid entry, it was awesome and wickedly spectacular.

Short Review: Ang Alamat ng DinuguanI like it but not wholly - I think the two major plot concept of the film didn‚Äôt gel well for me. Actually, more of they can go separately as I wished this was more of a psychological thriller than a fictional thriller. Some thoughts:- Cast was on the spot! Everyone was really good - even the side characters. And they felt more fleshed out than I expected!- Plot was good ‚Ä¶ till it wasn‚Äôt. But there were really good direction here but somewhere somehow it became off. I think when it was started to do expositions.- There were too on the nose lines and on the nose scenes. The blanket realization irked me the most as it was obvious but the lead had to have a line for it.- Production overall was well made - but I don‚Äôt know why but PH media (regardless whether high budget or low) felt cramped/limited. It‚Äôs like the invisible wall in video games that makes it feel small.With that said, this had potential and I thoroughly enjoyed it! It will probably be one of my fave MMFF movies this 2023.

im so sorry u can sell to me anything that is folk horror üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ i loved many things here!!!!! another "everything everywhere all at once" film but idgaf because i enjoy horror, thriller, crime, folklore, religion, period and family drama. i love the many things they tried to do, and i think it worked!i just wish it was more of a "show" than "tell" film. dialogues also tend to state the already obvious. example: when john rey found out that he brought back jonathan's towel, he voiced it out as if the audience couldn't see towel in his hand. characters KEEP speaking out their thought process. it threw me off because (1) real people don't do that, (2) it takes away the mystery, (3) EVERY actor are talented enough, i am sure they can deliver the thoughts and emotions of their characters through their body language and facial expressions alone. mallari is a smart film (at least smarter than many recent filo films), but it sees its audience as stupid or ppl who needs to be spoonfed.THIS IS A PROOF THAT WE NEED MORE PHILIPPINE FOLK HORROR!!!!!!! we don't need to borrow from other countries' horror genre, no need for filipino versions of annabelle, saw, and carrie. our folklore is vast and more interesting!!!!!!

Is it justifiable when a human kills others in the name of justice? To eliminate the evil in this world? Does one person that you love most's life matter more than the lives of others? Are we able to escape the fate that has been sealed long before our parents existence? Is love really the biggest curse of it all? These are all the questions that came to mind as I was watching Mallari. Before I continue, I just wanted to point out that they executed the connection between the 3 generations of Severinos seamlessly. It was really impressive how they wove the stories of the different generations of Mallari into the final fate of the present one. He who determines whether a person is the sum of all his decisions or his mistakes. More than anything I adore films that evokes questions out of me. There's just this juvenile wonder that comes after witnessing a story unfold in front of you. Something about it makes my morale skyrocket. That, for me, is one of the factors I consider when writing about films I watch. In conclusion, I ask of you (to whoever may be reading this, anyone who doesn't have a short attention span like I do), to watch this film. It has a very intriguing plot, features great performances from the leads, tells the story fate or trauma being hereditary, and the gift and curse of love to humans. Also what the actual fuck... Piolo is jaw-droppingly gorgeous AND talented? I knew he was all that, but goddamn did this punch me in the face just how he is that! bitch 100%. JC Santos also absolutely devoured that role of being the blind worshipper and he rightfully won Best Supporting Actor ikdr.

they just missed the opportunity to make it a psychological thriller masterpiece. this movie has the best storytelling of multi-verse/time travelling, i have ever seen in a filipino movie. the biggest downside for me is the forced demonic possession and aswang plot which was very unnecessary to the story. this could have been one of the best filipino horror movie.

My rating is related to the horror aspect, which was what it tried to achieve. I am a horror/thriller sucker so I have really high expectations when it comes to this genre.This film is ambitious and derivative to its core, with everything going all at the same time BUT I think it was able to seamlessly tie all timelines together and Piolo Pascual's acting to each persona is just god-tier. With regards to the horror side, the CGI is just so bad, that 1 scene completely threw the audience off. Jumpscares are there but it's a blend of sci-fi, folklore and history, which was a bit convoluted. Now I understand why JC Santos won Best Supporting Actor; he's beyond scary, he was frightening to watch. 1 question I just had was why Piolo did not win Best Actor with his 3 role portrayals (4 plus the alter-ego). This has potential.

MALLARI (MMFF 2023)Mallari presents an intriguing premise and stunning visuals, complemented by stellar performances from the cast.Piolo has his moments in this film. Embodying three distinct characters is no small feat. Unfortunately, he struggles to convincingly portray the nuanced differences among these characters, leaving one yearning for an acting style akin to James McAvoy in "Split."On the contrary, JC Santos delivers an outstanding performance, effortlessly stealing the spotlight from Piolo.But despite this, the film still struggles to evoke spine-chilling moments. It relies heavily on jump scares that, unfortunately, don't significantly impact the overall storyline.Also, the narrative style of withholding key information, strategically aiming for impactful revelations towards the end, serves as one of its major pitfalls. While effective in building suspense, this approach renders characters‚Äîespecially Jonathan‚Äîsomewhat devoid of logical thinking, an odd characteristic given his role as a doctor.Despite these shortcomings, the film remains a worthwhile watch for those seeking a fusion of scares and suspense.SCORE: 2/5#MMFF2023 #MallariMMFF #MallariTheMovie #mallari

Set in three timelines, Mallari is inspired by the first documented serial killer, a small parish priest Fr. Severino Mallari, and how the next generations in his family are influenced by power and madness. The film gave us three Piolo Pascual who embodied three distinct characters from the three timelines and while Mallari surprises local horror fans with its twists and turns and interwoven timelines, the overabundance of cheap jumpscares and tonal mishaps made it too overwhelming and confused about its own identity. The overall production design, scoring, and Pascual's acting are the main highlights of the film. When the timelines switch, it genuinely feels like a different timeline. The nuances among the three Mallaris were all vividly portrayed by Pascual. And yes, even with the horrible-looking beard was justified. My biggest issue with the film is its confused identity. It pastes a pastiche of horror tropes that becomes too much sacrificing the narrative value of the film. Had it carefully chosen a fewer element and given a premium focus on it, the film would have been much better for me.

I rated Mallari 4 stars out of 5 because there are many things I like and one thing I don't.I love how the production played with the colors in Mallari's scenes. You won't get confused about whether you're in Fr. Severino's timeline or with John Rey and Jonathan. The story of Fr. Severino, the first documented serial killer, blended seamlessly with John Rey and Jonathan's narrative.Despite some disappointment with Jonathan's decision in the final part, if you reflect on the beginning and why he investigated Fr. Severino, his decision becomes acceptable.The one thing I dislike about this movie is the excessive jumpscares. Although there are too many, only 2-3 actually startled me. Nevertheless, it remains one of the best Filipino horror films.Piolo (Fr. Severino, John Rey, Jonathan) is a great actor and a strong contender for the best actor award. He truly embodied Fr. Severino, John Rey, and Jonathan. I've seen many of Piolo's movies, but this one truly stood out; he excelled in all these roles.Bro. Lucas and Agnes (JC Santos & Janella Salvador) are also standout performers in this movie. People were screaming during their scenes. JC Santos truly deserves the Best Supporting Actor award. I'm also rooting for Janella to win Best Supporting Actress üò≠ but why not her?Hoping for more Filipino movies like this, and I'm begging Mentorque to put Mallari on Netflix or Prime Video, pleaseeeee. Delving into three intertwining timelines and employing a time-traveling twist, "Mallari" presents an ambitious scope. While the writers were able to tame this beast with a narrative that manages to engage and leaving its audiences intrigued, the overreliance on jump scares and the occult fails to tie up effectively with the overall storyline. This heavy-handed (and unnecessary) approach to horror detracts from what could have been a refined, narrative-driven film instead.Dr. Jonathan Mallari de Dios (Piolo Pascual) embarks on a journey to his ancestral home in Magalang, Pampanga, in search of a hidden chamber from his childhood - a chamber purportedly holding a cure for his fianc√©e's (Janella Salvador) severe illness. Upon arrival, we're introduced to his ancestors: Fr. Juan Severino Mallari (Piolo Pascual), the notorious 19th-century Filipino serial killer, and Johnrey Mallari (Piolo Pascual), a chronicler of World War II in the Philippines for the Americans. As eerie occurrences unfold within the house, it becomes evident that his quest may bring more harm than good to his loved ones.In the realm of fantastical and supernatural cinema like "Mallari," stringent logic isn‚Äôt always to be expected. There's always a give and take involved as we're delving into imaginary stuff. Yet, the fundamental plot struggles to find coherence. Elements often feel forced, serving the narrative agenda without solid grounding. The biggest question for us is why is there a need to continue the legacy of murders across time? While the rationale is clear in the 1800s in Fr. Mallari's time, subsequent timelines lack this clarity and cohesion. The handling of time travel also raises eyebrow-raising issues, from small stuff such as our protagonists modern-day attire back in time without issue to seamless communication across eras to bigger issues such as the reasons how the Mallaris are able to go selectively go back in time.However, the film's glaring misstep lies in its gratuitous use of unnecessary horror and jump scares. The continuous barrage of ghostly appearances lacks purpose, serving more to frustrate than thrill. It's apparent why they put this excessive amount in "Mallari" and ironically it backfires by producing the opposite effect. Despite these drawbacks, "Mallari" maintains a level of entertainment. It's fundamentally flawed but manages to strike occasional emotional chords, buoyed by its visually captivating cinematography and commendable performances by Piolo Pascual and JC Santos in particular. Surprisingly, a degree of attachment develops with the main characters, though the film could have greatly benefited from more refinement and streamlining. "Mallari" assumes forced scares are necessary for a fulfilling experience, missing the mark on delivering a cleaner and better narrative in the process.Source: www.reeladvice.net/2023/12/mallari-mmff-movie-review.html

DISRESPECTFUL TO THE VICTIMS.HOW DID YOU MANAGE TO MAKE A FILM DEHUMANIZING A MURDERER MORE THAN HOW A NORMAL PERSON WOULD DEHUMANIZE A MURDERER IN THEIR OWN MIND.If you enter the cinema asking "Why would this murderer kill 57 people? How did he do it? Why is he a priest? What's the significance of his faith to this actions? You'd be left unanswered or simply, disappointed. A lot of the answer you'd get from the story of the first serial murderer in the Philippines ISN'T what you'd expect. Because the film...... ISN'T what you'd think it is, it's a completely boring film. You'd ask, maybe a thrilling reason to his killings maybe? A cold-blooded vigilante? Nah, this film manages to capture every joke of an excuse for a horrible pastor. In one of the worst showcase of fable based "true event" story, this film completely shocked me by how corny and ridiculously blasphemous their written/chosen tale is and how it was executed.First, how did i get "hyped"?1. This was produced by Warner Bros. So obviously, as dumb as i am, i assumed we had done something right cinematically or atleast screenplay-wise.2. Piolo Pascual plays several roles. Piolo's been one of the best at picking which movies to appear in and who's passionate to what they do. Being present in Lav Diaz's films, being the best actor (imo) in Erik Matti's On The Job 1, he is significant in starring and helping produce the most ambitious flicks out there. He is one of my fav actors in the industry and so, i expected such moving performance here and i was left disappointed.3. New director to me, obviously, filmbuffs watches films for directors and being a new director i expected an up-and-coming new prospect to the staling roster of today.4. The plot, i don't think there's no plot better and more interesting in a while.5. MMFF is BACK! They said, It will be FUN they said. Totally taking away a murderer and going fully to the stereotypically plot-twist engaged minds of Filipino cinema watchers. This flick does not move our overall filmography at all even being produced by such prestigious film production. I expected Warner Bros to teach us how to make a proper film, how to fix the wrongs that we do. Nah, they just gave us a big budget of which we wasted to VFX that Filipinos love and never do right, Unneeded plot-twist and the props/design of which is actually one of the few okay things they managed to do. So the visuals are good? Nah the cinematography, blocking, coloring and effort in framing overall just didn't help the film at all. The directing and editing is so abrupt at times as well, even cutting to improper angles or jump cutting without a hint of pace at all. The 3rd act felt so rushed yet so dragged by the end??? No sense of pacing, completely ruining their own thrill in the climax by rushing their cuts and scenes just to complete the slow and boring end to the story.Just an absurd choice of story, obviously this is from the tales they must've heard from the locals and connected it to what seems to be an engaging flick with its unique premise and even unique portrayal. But this just shows that those things are NOTHING without the talent of a director, the invisible string that'll try to make a joke have profound meaning. What the hell even is the physiological conflict in this? What's the profoundness supposed to be? It's a complete waste of a good topic or story to unravel. It's a complete mess in filmmaking and an emotionless try to make something intriguing. I don't recommend watching this (unless you're going to the cinema with the people you're happy with like i did so i left there feeling well nonetheless. How can they dehumanize such inhumane actions to the point that it doesn't seem inhumane anymore? It felt like a joke horror rather than a meaningful or cold story. Korean cinema would EAT this. Hollywood would KILL for this script. It doesn't surprise me that Philippine cinema is not good, obviously. But to ruin a what could be easily-engaging plot? That's just..... criminal.

Mallari is an ambitious film. Based on the story of the first documented Filipino serial killer, the movie could have been a gripping tale of horror and suspense. But it took a different approach and unfortunately, the execution fell a bit short in some parts.Don't get me wrong, the time-travel aspect is certainly interesting. But it left me feeling a bit disjointed and uninvested in the characters. Maybe it's just personal preference, but I prefer subtly eerie horror movies, slowly building up to the big scares that leave me on the edge of my seat and screaming my heart out. Instead, Mallari relied too heavily on jump scares and loud music that didn't quite deliver. It worked on the first few times, but it lost its novelty after a while. I left the cinema not scared shitless, but instead laughing at what just happened.But let's give credit where credit is due - the production value was stunning, sans a few VFX parts. It's easily one of the most visually impressive films from this year's MMFF batch. If only they had stuck to what they were good at and taken more risks than they could fully commit to.Overall, Mallari had so much potential that unfortunately wasn't fully realized. But it's still worth a watch for the visuals and unique take on the Philippine horror genre.Seen at SM City Dasmari√±as as part of the 49th Metro Manila Film Festival

An ambitious, centuries-spanning, horror film about the first Filipino serial killer. I don't think any other local film in recent memory has attempted to take on something with this grand of a scope.The film was successful in establishing a sinister atmosphere and setting up the intrigue of how the three timelines intertwine. The non-linear storytelling challenges its viewers and helps keep the suspense alive. Back this up with excellent production and sound design and you have a very promising first half.Unfortunately, the film was not able to sustain its fascinating premise. The infusion of time travel, questionable supernatural elements, and unnecessary jump scares made for a clunky second half. The unraveling of the mystery didn't really feel satisfying and the promise of "the first Filipino serial killer" was not explored to its fullest potential. I feel like this would have been more successful as a character study instead of focusing on the supernatural side.Some elements hold it back from truly achieving greatness but Mallari is a step up from previous MMFF horror entries not named 'Seklusyon' and pushes the boundaries of how good the technical quality of pinoy films could be.

I've been hearing a lot of good reviews about Mallari so I decided to give it a shot as well in this year's Metro Manila Film Festival.The concept of Mallari is very risky especially in the horror genre but it was offered to the viewers as simply satisfying by focusing solely on the story not the scares.The casts were obviously great, they were able to shine each moment they have within minutes and frames. Piolo Pascual had to internalize his characters in a good way since we see different personalities in different people and generations.A horror film that is so good to watch in which we should be proud of. Mallari does it the right way with the scares, philippine folklores, and the bits of history.

There are flaws here and there, and questionable scenes that negate or contradict the story, but hell yeah, I don't give a damn. I like how in the end the main lead's character came to full circle‚ÄîMallari is and was, a serial killer, and there is no redemptive way to change history. I'm sure that most of you don't see that angle but once you realize‚Äîas the mc broke the third wall, like what Damien did for The Omen‚Äîthat he decided to become what he is supposed to be, and he embraced it with his eyes wide open then, you'll probably find some appreciation for how this story was told rather than just do the usual "historical" route. Wasn't super scary, but it's a fun experience. Although it could improve more on the editing room.

In this time travelling horror mash up from director Derick Cabrido, Piolo Pascual plays not one, not two, but four different characters from three different timelines.In the first timeline, we follow the newly assigned parish priest, Fr. Severino Mallari (Pascual) and his mother, Do√±a Facunda (Gloria Diaz) as they both settle in the sleepy town of Magalang, Pampanga, circa 1812. Here, we learn what drove him to become the serial killer that we know today.In the second one set in 1948, we follow his descendant, filmmaker Johnrey Mallari (played again by Pascual) and his wife, Felicity (Elisse Joson), as he investigates the mysterious case of his ancestor, Severino, who has killed 57 victims.In the present time, Dr. Jonathan Mallari De Dios (Pascual) returns to his family's ancestral home in Magalang to search for a way to save his fianc√©, Agnes (Janella Salvador) from dying. He believes that the cure lies at the hands of his ancestors, Do√±a Facunda and Severino Mallari.It's admittedly an interesting concept, as the film presents itself as inspired by the true to life crimes of Juan Severino Mallari, Phillippines' first documented serial killer during the 1800s, predating London's Jack The Ripper by more than 60 years. However, all that potential is sadly wasted in this film.Penned by Enrico Santos and helmed by Derick Cabrido, this horror film feels like a multitude of films stitched together, thanks to its many story arcs and concepts. A big chunk of the film plays out like a slasher flick, as we watch Severino Mallari dispatching a couple of victims along the way. The film also plays around with the idea of time travel and astral projection. A portion of it also feels like a creature feature, while the remaining part is your standard ghost story, as the characters are occasionally terrorized by the souls of Mallari's victims.The film is enjoyable in some parts, but as a whole, it feels convoluted. At times, it even feels confusing. The script tries to make the merging of the overarching story arcs and timelines as smooth as it can, but it can't help but feel overstuffed and too muddled. Enrico Santos' screenplay also didn't fully utilize the concept, although I appreciate the film's outlandishness. Imagine, from a serial killer, we eventually get to see ghosts, witches and aswangs in one sitting. Although I did find the film's blatant transphobia a bit icky as it didn't sit well with me.Despite that, the film is undeniably worth checking for two things: its production value and the cast. The film looks very impressive, with Pao Orendain's slick camera work brilliantly capturing Marielle Hizon's highly detailed production design. You know they really spent time and money just by looking at those highly detailed set pieces and costumes, from that town church made from scratch to the period accurate wardrobe. It's only the CGI effects that looks pretty inconsistent. The film's sound design, courtesy of Immanuel Verona and Nerrina Salim, also gives the film a more immersive experience.On top of this, the performances of the cast are worth every peso. Gloria Diaz is committed from start to finish with her character as Do√±a Facunda, while Janella Salvador and Elisse Joson are both effective as Agnes and Felicity. JC Santos occasionally steals the show with his compelling turn as Brother Lucas, who helps Jonathan investigate his family's dark history. But it is Piolo Pascual who keeps the entire show running as he plays four different characters in the movie. His unforgettable performance here as Juan Severino Mallari, the latter's descendants Johnrey and Jonathan, and even an evil version of St. Bartholomew is definitely for the ages.It's not exactly scary, as it spends most of its time with jump scares that, while effective, are all forgotten eventually. It's no surprise that this one's pretty divisive, as your appreciation with the film will depend on how far you can take all of its silliness. But while it does fall short of its very high aspirations, this ridiculously bonkers and incredibly ambitious time warping horror mash-up is still worth every buck, thanks to its top-notch production value and its impressive cast, led by Piolo Pascual.

Was expecting a lot from this. I first heard of Fr. Severino Mallari in a true crime podcast and he was hailed as the first and only serial killer in the Philippines. I was just expecting a true biopic of Fr. Mallari and know his motivations for killing several people. I was not expecting some supernatural and time travel sh*t. JC Santos and Piolo Pascual are really good in this film, though.

The film weaves an intricate horror lore out of the flimsiest of historical material, as not much else is really known about the real-life serial killer Juan Severino Mallari. Exploring the motivations behind his murders, the movie spins an engaging tale of obsession, time travel, and blind filial duty that's made even richer with excellent use of Pinoy folklore, superstition, and Catholicism. The scoring and camerawork were excellent. The writing seemed heavy-handed at times, but the cast's stellar performances - particularly JC Santos' - more than make up for this!

god-awful (pun intended) CGI aside, this film could have been better with a lesser theatrical script. the lines exposed so much of the character and the story without leaving room for mystery. about 20 minutes in I was already cringing in my seat ‚Äì the script was just all over the place.the jumpscares got old quick, musical scoring was almost fine but it just gravitated between being loud and sudden to force tension into the scene. there were plenty of "duh" moments, too. at many points it felt like a play where the actor had to voice out his (very obvious) realizations. this film could really do with SUBTLETY ‚Äì it's horror, let the people fear the unknown. don't lay everything out that quickly.acting-wise, I was relieved to see JC Santos take on a character that deviated from the usual sad lover boy trope ‚Äì it's about damn time. Piolo was great, Janella looked promising (the script really botched her potential lol I mean what the fuck was that ending???), Elisse was also alright.costume and makeup were phenomenal, though. the plot alone (or the main actor alone) is enough to draw a lot of people in, but what i really liked about this particular story is how it alluded to a particular saint ‚Äì it's a strong artistic choice to make that story up for this film. i just wish the script delivered both more and less to make all of it come full circle. parang ang daming gustong mangyari ng writer (time travel, true crime solving, witchcraft/black magic, religious cult, filipino mythology, demonic possession...etc.). isa-isa lang, lol.

Ika nga ni Gojo Satoru, "Love is truly the most twisted curse of all."Watched this movie's 6:00 PM screening at SM City Cebu, and I was surprised at how long the ticketing line still is there. It's a pain to wait to buy a ticket, of course, but it just made me more excited to watch Mallari.First and foremost, I love horror movies. Literally one of my favorite genres ever. I am also one of those horror fans who have little tolerance for jump scares; it would scare me at first, but it'd eventually irritate me especially when overdone. This film could have scrapped some of those, since the way most scenes are shot already got the atmosphere to give you the creeps. The abundance of jump scares comes off like the film's underestimating the audience's perception of fear, and that aspect would have made me give this 2.5/5 stars.But the story it's trying to tell surely won me over, hence the 3 stars. Though the social commentary in the film is weaker and there are lapses in the fiction part of the narrative, it succeeds to tell how love is the main predictor for the curse that plagues the Mallari bloodline. It also successfully tells how in some cases, history is truly repeated if ignored. I see why Piolo Pascual was also others' bet for Best Actor, his acting really made the 3 main characters shine in their own ways (and his role as Fr. Pedro Pelaez in Gomburza is noteworthy too by the way, Papa P FATHERED). Out of the 3 stories presented, my favorite definitely has to be Johnrey's. Too bad that for me, his storyline doesn't seem as fleshed out as Severino's or Jonathan's, as he is the "tragic hero" of the movie.In spite of the film's blatant flaws, it's still a movie that deserves all the hype and the awards they've received from the Gabi Ng Parangal. Do see it in cinemas before MMFF 2023 closes, it's nice to scream with other people in the cinema!

"Sometimes, love is a curse and there's nothing else in the world that can break it."Got to watched this film in an almost jampacked cinema and all I can say that it is a good balance between suspense and horror. Well, for me, it brought me back to the old horror films filled with the typical jumpscares thag you'll still get surprised but it also gives you this suspense feeling like sitting at the edge of your chair wondering what could be the next thing that will happen in the movie.The transitions between the three eras were smooth that it was a little bit confusing at first glance but I loved how it incorporates the three timelines on a single important event of the whole story and presents you each on how they are intersected at that moment. It was definitely good on how they are able to play around the plot and not spill the whole thing on one go. I loved that portion and Piolo Pascual's acting is the best I've seen and maybe this is his best movie on his entire career. From the visual, to the acting, to the pronounciations that make the timelines distinct on their own helps very well on distinguishing the three different timelines of Severino, Johnrey and Jonathan. I would also love to add some praise for JC Santos. Being a theatre kid gains you so much and we've seen it through his performance.Just two things I did not love as much.1) The Manananggal Scene (did not resonated as much or did not do anything for the plot, I guess? And a little too corny for the well produced film)2) The Ending (I am looking for more information on how things end up like that. Like from JC's character to Janella's "memory" of who she is now after what Piolo did)But despite these things, I found Mallari to be a good film and despite not being a fan of horror films, this is one of those horror films at the top my list (as it was a good horro movie and because I can still sleep st night after watching this)

Sa pagpanood ko ng 'Mallari,' hindi ko maitatangging napabilib ako sa kagandahan ng pelikula. Ang ganda ng pagkakagawa at ang twist sa kwento ay talaga namang kakaiba. Isa itong obra na nagpapatunay na may talento ang direktor na ito sa pagbuo ng kakaibang karanasan para sa manonood.Ngunit, napansin ko rin na parang may allergy ang direktor sa mga happy ending sa mga pelikula sa ngayon. Sa kabila ng ganda ng cinematography at ang kahusayan ng pagganap ni Piolo at ng buong cast, hindi maikakaila na tila iniiwasan ng pelikula ang pangwakas na may saya.Ang mga pangyayari sa pelikula ay hindi lamang maganda sa mata kundi kakaiba rin. Ang mga eksena ay nadama ko sa bawat angulo, at ang husay ng mga aktor, lalo na si Piolo at ang buong cast, ay nagbibigay-buhay sa karakter.Sa kabuuan, isang kahanga-hangang pelikula ang 'Mallari,' bagamat may konting bahid ng lungkot sa pagtatapos nito. Subalit, sa kabila nito, hindi maitatangging ang ganda at husay nito ay nagbibigay ng marka sa industriya ng pelikulang Pilipino.Btw, ang sakit sa ulo na pure tagalog ang ginamit ko sa pag-komento haha!

I didn't expect much from this movie as I'd been hearing a LOT of negative reviews. I went in blind, and I happened to enjoy it!It was a horror movie that made sense (if you're open to peculiar storylines, of course). The first half was confusing and wonky, but the latter half at least made up for it by tying up the initially disconnected events together in a way that stimulated the audience's minds. Plot twists were revealed in this way when I didn't think there was anything more to expect. The movie was intentionally NOT subtle about the true culprit's identity because there were MORE IMPORTANT twists. Some bits of dialogue, especially in the romantic scenes, were cringe-inducing and unnatural. Even Janella's and Piolo's decent acting couldn't make it bearable. The insertion of key story elements (e.g., time traveling) could have been better with a less cheesy dialogue. Speaking of acting, JC Santos DESERVES the Best Supporting Actor Award. Piolo's acting was the weakest despite portraying the MAIN character; he was outshined by the supporting actors. There were multiple layers to the story that influenced the characters' complexity. Wikipedia would tell us that Fr. Juan Severino Mallari killed 57 people as a "cure" for his mother's sickness, which he deemed cursed. But the movie went all out: There was MORE to show within 2 hours. I loved the ending. Life's true horror did not come from stories about ghosts but from a person's adamance in committing mistakes that would negatively impact the people around them.

+:- plot-wise, it's def a richer, more nuanced, and more thought-out narrative compared to most PH horror na super predictable na ng plot twists + generic elements. i like what it tried to do with 3 diff time periods though ofc the time traveling/astral projecting was a stretch and maybe a tad too ambitious writing-wise. still a good effort tho- characters: all played well. i liked the juxtaposition between severino - a serial killer who didn't enjoy it and didn't actually WANT to be it - and lucas who DID enjoy being a copycat killer and WANTED to do it. jc santos deserved his best supporting actor award. - technical elements: production design goes so hard esp knowing they built some of the key parts of the setting. the score was also particularly good tho maybe im just biased for church/choral elements-:- im not a big fan of origin stories of "female monsters" when the presented origin is so male-centric. sure, in this case it was women who set upon the curse that started the monster - but why? just for someone else to do their bidding? i wish they showed more of the alarcons and why they did what they did. if the motivation is supposed to be wrath at the injustice done against ppl like them, then i wish they leaned into that more, kulang lang ng detail pa for that- mallari stopped being scary the moment it was revealed that his mom saw smth nieves led her to watch. dun palang i already knew severino would only be forced to kill, not that he wanted to himself. im not a fan of this either lol he'd be a much more sinister character if HE was the fanatic and saw himself as san bartolome on his own accord BUT i know that's not the point of the story so sige na nga- why naman di na lang niya niligtas si agnes eh doktor din naman si jonathan ... tapos pampanga yan in present time beh dami dami nang ospital tas may kotse rin naman si agnes mabilis kayo makakarating dun medyo nkklk- AND SPEAKING OF THE HOSPITAL: in the first scene na pinakitang nasa hospital bed si agnes, ang sabi ng nurse "end stage na po siya" so akala ko naman cancer or some life-threatening disease. ngayon pala stab wound amp pano yon end stage nakapagsalita pa nga and all ewan ko ba- and the ending ... i get it they needed a shot of jonathan like that, but i wish it was even more tragic. filipino writing is sometimes so hooked on expositional writing but sometimes that gets too annoying to listen to and to act out. i wish they didn't show agnes eating the chick. ok na sana that they showed jonathan smiling while holding up johnrey's head and the chick is coming out of its mouth - and then cut na agad to the mallari house and the secret room, where agnes is chained and jonathan is "lovingly" feeding her entrails while she looks like she'd rather be dead after killing him IDK. personally didnt feel like all that dialogue was necessary in the end but ok gets pa rin namanoverall tho, i hope this film encourages more horror filmmakers to take on compelling stories! our culture is SOOO rich for this literally andaming pwedeng material for horror and im so glad to see i can look forward to more daring horror films like this now in the PH

Mallari is a horror-thriller film based on the Philippines' first recorded serial killer hailing from Pampanga. With this in mind, the film attempts to take us on a wild ride of discovery, boldly mixing genres that, while commendable, more often than not gets derailed into different directions. MAZES AND DAZESFirstly, it's admirable how the story attempts to give Filipino audiences something different. It marries the familiar Philippine folklore horror elements with sci-fi and mystery thriller with dashes of history, comedy, and even family drama. The story unfolds with a non-linear structure, too, which makes it interesting.The issues lay with this very idea that it wanted to do so much with so little time. The first half of the film lays all of the mystery, while the second half picks up the pace and fully turns into a horror story.Jamming too many elements somehow took away from what could have been great points in the story if only they leaned more into them and chose: did it want to be more of a historical horror or a mystery thriller slasher cult modern classic?BRIGHT AND DULL SPOTSPiolo Pascual playing multiple roles across generations would've been a great feat for an actor of his caliber. But somehow, something was missing in his portrayal that left me wanting more. His characters felt like they were the same people, save for two distinct moments in the chapel and in the hospital towards the end.Undeniable standouts were JC Santos and Gloria Diaz. They were spectacular and generous in their supporting roles and stole scenes whenever they came up beside Pascual. They were delightful to watch. OVERALLDespite its major flaws, I like how everything was wrapped up. All of the mysteries and questions set up were resolved and given their end, no loose ends (which could've easily been the case given its ambition and scope).Mallari is an example of what happens when you allow filmmakers to be adventurous and bold in their ideas. It can lead to a bumpy and crazy, yet fun and adventurous ride.
a pretty solid movie! definitely not perfect but has the potential to kickstart a new age for filipino horror movies. 7.5/10!

watching this in the cinemas was definitely a fun experience especially when the audience (mostly strangers) also insert funny commentaries here and there that you can‚Äôt help but laugh at. the people behind our backs were especially funny i couldn‚Äôt help but to acknowledge how that elevated my experience. as for the movie itself‚Ä¶. first, i would like to point out how much i loooooove the musical scoring. i have no complaints about that. i also liked the acting especially jc santos like woah okay best supporting actor indeed! and also liked the fact that janella salvador is here like woah everyone‚Äôs eye candy is piolo pascual but mine is janella so there‚Äôs room for everybody! that said, what i didn‚Äôt like about the movie is how they didn‚Äôt explore much about the first filipino serial killer aspect more. i went in expecting that they would explore the story of the murders itself, the aftermath, the consequences, and how the priest was discovered as the murderer but i guess that‚Äôs on me for expecting something like that, something nbc hannibal-like? honestly, i just really wished they focused more on the murders since it is a mystery/thriller aspect in itself but i guess mallari wasn‚Äôt going for that. like hello, the first documented serial killer of the philippines was a catholic priest and that in itself is intriguing as a predominantly catholic country. anyway, i did like the time traveling aspect to explore the narrative but at the same time i feel like it wasn‚Äôt utilized well enough to really wrap up the story‚Ä¶ but props to piolo pascual for pulling off the roles well.

I can't remember the last time I really enjoyed a Filipino horror film. MALLARI is both gothic and cerebral---- my kind of horror film. This is brilliant filmmaking. Piolo serving us an acting masterclass.Much of the criticism about MALLARI is the abundance of jump scares, and I agree that they are quite tiring after a certain time. MALLARI works best during its moments of quiet dread: two scenes in particular (without giving much away) are my favorite.ONE, the film showing featuring some unwelcome guests.TWO, that Baile scene. Pao Orendain's camerawork is dizzying, maddening, which like the storytelling, is taking all of us for a spin.

Their cinematography was simple; numerous shots were repeated frequently. I‚Äôm not a big fan of their visual effects. But i liked the color. The performance of Piolo Pascual should have been better. JC Santos deserves the Best Supporting Actor Award. Overall, not bad for a Filipino Horror Film. Sayang lang talaga ang story. Hawak na nila ang best screenplay. They could have done better.

Horror, I guess, is truly the most challenging film genre, and you feel it in the struggles of PH cinema. Often, in our horror films, the story is either unclear or unintentionally turns into comedy due to poor visual effects. In this film, I don't quite get why the fear factor feels forced. There are numerous jumpscares that seem repetitive and not very surprising.Perhaps the film could still deliver (or even be better) if the horror vibes weren't forced (especially the manananggal scene, it might have been better off excluded). But it's still a 4-star rating from me because I did enjoy watching it. It gives off similar vibes to Seklusyon since both are horror and revolve around religion, making it inevitable to compare the two.There are few local horror films with a good screenplay, and this is one of those succeeding in that aspect. The disturbing ending was exactly what I wanted to spark discussions and curiosity about the life of Father Severino Mallari. Kudos to the filmmakers for the smooth transitions between scenes, and you genuinely feel the thrill.The score was superb (the bayle scene was chef's kiss), but there were times when the sound effects are annoying because it's too loud and hurts the ears. The editing still needs more improvement. The visual effects are far from perfect, but they're already good and a significant improvement compared to other local films, especially in the horror genre. What truly stood out here is the phenomenal acting of Piolo Pascual, with three characters portrayed, and JC Santos, who is truly deserving of his Best Supporting Actor award (they nailed it in their last scene together). I believe Piolo Pascual is the Brad Pitt of the Philippines because he never seems to age.There are many loopholes and points for improvement, but the film's concept is indeed impressive, and in some ways, it probably delivered the intended message to viewers. I'm happy because I see this as a launching pad for the progress of local horror films, and the trajectory is only heading upwards.

#Mallari is the jump scare of the year! This is another scary movie that's worth seeing. Its story, its riddles, its terror, and all of its aesthetically pleasing eras are cohesive. I appreciate how they told the plot without losing sight of the fact that you are still seeing a masterful horror movie. I was a little lost in the present day, but the plot's shifting texture gave the stories, folklore, and social constructs more substance. It‚Äôs easy to follow despite moving around inti three periods because its visuals made sure they compliment, and at the same time contradict each other.Piolo Pascual, your Best Actor award is in the bag, with Gloria Diaz and JC Santos are strong candidates for acting noms. Quite lengthy, but it lets you take a break from thrilling scenes. Again, slow clap for the artwork and visual effects. #MMFF2023

Rather than tell a straightforward slasher/police procedural story like in most serial killer-centric films, Mallari opts for a unique approach: focusing on a historic Filipino figure. Oh and time travel as plot device. The film certainly has great ingredients. The combined acting prowess of Piolo Pascual, JC Santos, and Ms. Gloria Diaz. The Enrico Santos-penned screenplay that combines Gothic atmospheres, Catholic traditions, (almost) Lovecraftian ancient evils, love and madness, and the dance between Christianity and violence. The visuals refreshingly don't look made for TV which, in my perspective, dominates Filipino visual media today. Y'know the overly lit backgrounds. Or sickening coloring. Sadly though, Mallari is overdone but not in the fun, unique way. It falls into the usual trappings of conventional big-budget films these days (it is a Warner Brothers affair). The jumpscares that define much of this film's genre are too one-note. A character enters a room and then there's a figure, either behind or in front, which slowly turns around, revealing black eyes, decaying skin, and mouth wide open. Dramatic score in the background to accentuate the fear. Watching it alone in a dark room can make those scenes scary, sure. But would it kill the filmmakers to create sequences that haunt, not merely surprise? Suspenseful equences that paralyze you for a minute, instead of five seconds of jumpscare? The score too, good Lord, would it kill to have silence? Let the dread creep in. Build on the minutes-long discomfort. I want to hear my own heart beating not let some loud Gregorian chant to do all the emotional carrying.

Welcome back, Philippine Horror Cinema! 1) The sequencing format is superb. Despite having three different timelines, it did not lead to confusion or a "wtf is happening" moment. The timelines were executed really well. 2) The amount of jumpscares, or even just the scary parts, is commendable. This is what horror movies should look like. 3) Piolo Pascual's Performance is really commendable! He was able to differentiate between each character he was portraying. 4) Setting / Production is great. Timelines were differentiated and can be easily identified. Areas to Improve:- Played too safe with the gore, hence it was something we don't really mind. The horror elements are enough. - 2 murders in the modern day could not justify the "serial killings", would be great if there were at least one or two more. - I, personally, did not like Janella's fate. Could've been better.

Mallari is an ambitious and technically brilliant hodge podge of creative ideas forcefully converged together. Its ideas feel like aesthetic decorations rather than themes that serve its story. I didn't like how it relied on useless jump scares in the first half as it really goes to unsettling territories in its second half. The pacing overall feels very clunky and the characters are stiff and almost dumb at some parts. A frustrating missed opportunity.

janella salvador willing ko tanggapin yang sisiw na yan para sayoü§ûok slightly srs review incoming !!(editing aspect) i cant believe the bad gma-inspired cgi still passes on even on the big screen. imposible talaga na kulang o limited ang mga mahuhusay na cgi artists sa ph. i read that most local tv shows scrimp on their sfx editors to allocate their funds to other needs or are generally on a tight budget but seriously hanggang dito ba naman? huhu sayang kasi its these little repetitive things that hinder the quality. in some scenes, imo mas maganda kung dinaan nlang nila sa sfx na makeup hindi cgi. to add sa editing nito, the transitions pleaseüò≠ yes to experimenting & gaining inspiration from creative transitions but please not in your entries for an anticipated film festival, and im not just talking about this movie but in the other entries as well. i really would have settled with a simple cut transition or a basic fade in/out huhu(plot aspect + cinematog + misc) idk i liked their twist to the og story of ph's first serial killer. it strayed from ur normal historical piece such as gomburza, heneral luna, etc. i really liked how there were scenes u would dismiss at the start and by the end, its so satisfying to revisit those scenes but with all the pieces finally falling into place. also hindi sila bobo ?? except sa dulo cguro pero di tanga tanga mga desisyon nila like the typical horror movie. just a bit weird with the out of place comedy (still enjoyable tho) tsaka ewan may moments na mapapa tanong ka lang kung controversial ba toh o oa lang ba ako... anw my last criticism would be on the jumpscares. again please we can do better than this!! ive seen better jumpscares and build ups than this in old horror films na napapanood ko sa cinemaone channel fr. okei tapos na ang pagdada ko & i, thank u

A decent one with intriguing concepts and elements that aren't prevalent in other horror-thriller movies. Some jump scares shouldn't be included, imo. The creepy scoring is more than enough to fit the screenplay; the pacing is a bit messy and could be improved, but the last stretch swiftly sums up how good the plot line is. Piolo's portrayal definitely showed the differences between the three generations; I have to commend how it was depicted. JC Santos' performance was top-notch; no wonder he won as the best supporting actor for this filmfest.I'm also impressed by how it includes Filipino folklore and mythology, how Christianity has severely influenced us all up until now, and the way they show how religion affects one's overall character.

My first film for 2024 and I would say I fairly had fun. I think the deciding factor whether one will like this film is the astral projection/time travel direction on the screenplay based on actual history. I definitely did not expect that going into this film, although eventually I enjoyed the plot as it went on. The film looks good. Both in terms of production design and cinematography. The film sounds good, both in terms of sound design and scoring. The film also manages to weave together the three narratives of three generations of the Mallari clan very well. I just wish that the narrative themselves were fleshed out and developed well. It felt like the film is trying to say too much that it ended up not saying anything at all. However, I do think that the film's epilogue is easily its greatest strength. Particularly, the hospital scene. The way it was shot, the way it was scored, the performances truly hooked me in that moment. I wish there were more moments like that in the film, but what we got were CGI-elongated faces of dead people followed by sudden hitting of notes in an attempt to produce scares out of the audience.

A lot of gen z lingo and humor felt forced throughout as well and the whole deal with the non binary person in the beginning felt unnecessary and the stereotypes used felt mean spirited and out of taste.

82/100‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê - Satisfactory (83-82)Negatives:-The dialogues were too sloppy. The film has three time frames and it didn't manage to be consistent throughout. The plot was oversaturated with great ideas with no sufficient developments.-With a lot of characters and plotlines to chew under a 2hr runtime, I find the some sequences abnormally fast-paced.-I just don't buy the time travel thing, it's nonsense.Positives:-Piolo giving another great performance as expected. The standout for me was definitely JC; I view him as the Barry Keoghan of PH.-The horror elements were definitely effective, the theater audience really elevated the experience. -Although it felt rushed, the film managed to tie together the different plots of the different timeframes properly.
Some scenes of the movie caught me off guard but the reason why I rate this 4.5 is because the musical scores instead of the story of the movie XD

A solid attempt at Filipino magical realism. Do not expect a historical horror film. The plot may diverge and expand needlessly but the core of the film is strong in its main character and thesis. This will be my go-to film recommendation for any foreigner or diasporic Filipino looking to learn about Filipino culture: religion and spirituality, community justice, generational trauma, familial dependency, colonial and post-colonial society, and folklore.
interesting concept with an uninteresting execution. i do love the catholic imagery, religious themes, filipino witchcraft and mythology combined with filipino history.

I watched Mallari without knowing anything, except the fact that the movie has its historical basis and majority of the people in my internet sphere said that it was good. I did not expect to come out of the cinema witnessing a movie which is basically an amalgamation of multiple genres.Mallari's strengths were its phenomenal acting from a star-studded cast, its great cinematography, and its pacing is okay.Mallari's weaknesses were its all over-the- place writing and personally, I think, the movie could've done better and not spoonfeed everything to the viewers and let them think for themselves. Also, it had tons of ineffective jumpscares that do not contribute anything to the plot and for some scenes, the scoring was kind of jarring and felt in-your-face.Overall, I enjoyed watching Mallari even though it's somewhat predictable. Also, we all could've saved two hours of our lives if only someone handed Jonathan a balut in the first place. Metro Manila Film Festival 2023 @ SM Megamall

ùêèùêöùê¶ùê¢ùê•ùê≤ùêö ùêöùê≠ ùêèùêöùê†-ùê¢ùêõùê¢ùê†; ùêíùêÆùê¶ùê©ùêö ùêöùê≠ ùêÅùê¢ùê≤ùêöùê≤ùêöùêÄ ùêëùêûùêØùê¢ùêûùê∞ ùêõùê≤ ùêâùê®ùê≤ ùêÄùê•ùêúùêöùêßùê≠ùêöùê´ùêö & ùêëùê®ùêùùêö ùêÇùêöùêßùê≠ùê®ùêßùê£ùê®ùê¨Noong 1800's, ang lalawigan ng Magalang, Pampanga ay saksi sa isang hanay ng mga pagpatay sa loob ng isang dekada. Isang tanyag na kura paroko na nagngangalang Juan Severino Mallari ang pinaghihinalaang pumatay sa humigit kumulang 57 katao.Sa pelikulang ito ni Direk Derick Cabrido, hindi lamang niya tinutukan ang buhay ni Father Severino bilang kauna-unahang serial killer sa Pilipinas, ito rin ay nagbibigay ng makabuluhang mensahe tungkol sa pag-ibig, bagamat isang nakakakilabot na representasyon ng pag-ibig, habang nilalakbay ang mga masalimuot na landas ng pagmamahal, kahit pa ito ay may kaakbay na panganib. Talagang hindi matatawaran ang pagganap ng isa sa pinakakilalang aktor sa bansa na si Piolo Pascual. Ibang "Papa P" ang makikita sa pelikulang ito. Iba't ibang pagkatao, iba't ibang emosyon, at iba't ibang kwento. Hindi madali ang gumanap ng tatlong persona kaya kahanga-hanga ang ipinamalas ng aktor. Isa sa gusto kong karakter na ginampanan niya ay si Father Severino Mallari. Nabigyan nya ng hustisya ang karakter na ito, makikita mo sa mga mata niya kung anong emosyon ang nais niyang ipahatid sa mga manonood. Takot, galit, at pagmamahal, walang duda, nakilala siya dahil sa kanyang angking galing. Gaya ni Piolo, ipinamalas rin ni JC Santos ang kanyang galing sa pag-arte na gumanap bilang Lucas. Isa siya sa pinakanagdala ng pelikula, kaya naman hindi nakakapagtaka na sya ang napiling bigyan ng parangal ng MMFF bilang Best Supporting Actor ngayong taon.Kakaiba ang atake na bitbit ng ‚ÄúMallari‚Äù dahil hindi lamang nakasentro sa horror ang pelikula ngunit sumasaklaw din ito sa iba't ibang genre tulad ng thriller, sci-fi, folklore, kasaysayan, romance, at family drama. Nakakamangha na napagsama-sama ito sa iisang pelikula. Mahusay nitong inilarawan ang kontradiksyon ng pag-ibig bilang isang biyaya at sumpa. Katulad ng sinabi sa pelikula ‚ÄúAng isang tao ay kabuuan ng kaniyang mga desisyon, minamahal, at mga pagkakamali," gaano nga ba kalalim ang kaya nating isugal para sa pag-ibig?

Presenting the Piolo Pascual Multiverse of Madness. Charot.Mallari commits to taking advantage of the Filipino lore to create a piece that can be exciting despite going all over the place for perhaps half of the time. The film wanted to be many different things all at once and truly attempted to connect the dots but not without shortcomings. There are justifiable parts, then there are ‚Äúwhat the hell is going on‚Äù ones.Regardless of the mishaps, such as the lack of cinematic fluidity and overpowering score, Mallari is an entertaining experience - thanks to Piolo Pascual‚Äôs constant reinvention as an actor. I personally appreciated the homage to our long history of integrating elements of religion, mythology, and superstitions that has been effective as early as the Spanish Colonial Period in the Philippines.

The Philippine Horror Movie scene has had a very interesting existence, to say the least. Our culture is ripe with legends and fables about supernatural beings committing atrocities, and many variations of these tales have made their way to the silver screen - whether that be a refrigerator eating an unwelcome houseguest, or centuries-old entities luring influencers to a ‚Äúcollab‚Äù to harvest their fresh flesh and blood. Sometimes, we get tales of a feminine spectre haunting a commonly-used thoroughfare in Quezon City, and sometimes we‚Äôll get a tale about the horrors that have befallen families simply because they‚Äôve set wedding dates so close to each other. One horror trope, which has not been explored much in Filipino cinema, is that of the serial killer slasher film. One film dares to go deeper into that sub-genre, an attempt that has elicited much anticipation and hype. The question is, does the film live up to said hype?Full review here: www.cinegeekspod.com/post/mallari-movie-review

An entertaining watch if only you would completely suspend your disbelief. Otherwise, it is an intellectual nightmare, which is perhaps the real horror this film brings.

Not sure what I was expecting, but this was not it. Haha. Look, the film was visually stunning from the cinematography, camera work, and transitions. I also didn‚Äôt mind the overbearing score and the acting was fine. I just wished the movie went on a different direction than this because the fantastical element - including the time travel, agawang sisiw, etc - while interesting, to some extent, felt too absurd and unnecessarily convoluted especially since this was based on a true story. The twists were frustratingly predictable and some of the jumpscares felt too heavy handed. I wanted something more grounded and what I got was a gorgeous looking Pinoy horror film that gave me nothing other than a bunch of eye rolls and confused look. Haha.

Jump scare galore. Mallari is a disappointing horror film filled with contrived jump scares. It's overly ambitious with a really thin time travelling plot and heavy handed screenplay that tried to tie all three generations but failed to do so. Should've focused on "first serial killer" instead of it being a fantasy because the tragedy in all of it felt wasted. This really felt like a passion project of a folklore/ghost enthusiast with so much ideas in their mind. Really felt like it's inspired by Ricky Lee's Amapola but just all over the place. Performances are also meh while the saving grace of this film is in its visuals and camera movement, and some of the set design is pretty impressive.

Wasted narrative potential for the first documented Filipino serial killer. The story felt more like a fiction than based on true events.Dialogues are cheaply written. So cringy! Felt it crawling through my skin.The time traveling is too ambitious. The film utterly failed. üòï

?!?!.Andami kong pwede masabi kasi nainis ako of how a lot of things didn‚Äôt work because of how forced they could feel but I also loved how technical the writing and even the editing was in having to pull off three different generations merging them as one story despite some generic dialogues with bits of random humor. But in the end, it felt like everything got too much and a lot of things became unnecessary already.Piolo and JC both shined in the film and delivered haunting performances. The production also made a hell of a film despite how the finished product can be divisive to a lot of people.

The concept of exploring the Philippines' only recorded serial killer was an excellent idea, but the execution was blown out of proportion. There was so much happening and too many themes were being introduced. While the intention was there, it was just too ambitious for its own good. Also, the jump-scare-galore type of horror made it less and less "scary" nearing the end.On the other hand, the inclusion of Philippine lore, the eerie sound design & score, and excellent acting (especially JC Santos) were the film's redeeming factors. Overall, it wasn't a bad film through and through, but it could have been better.6/10

The concept of time travel in storytelling is a nice approach. It was well presented how the 3 different generations of Mallari were portrayed, but it also showcased that‚Äîeven now and then, there‚Äôs a curse that has been happening in our country (in the context of societal injustices). ‚ÄúAng isang tao ay kabuuan ng kanyang mga desisyon‚Ä¶ minamahal‚Ä¶ at mga pagkakamali.‚ÄùThe Love lies at the core of all three varieties of Mallari. Two are driven by love for their spouses, and one is out of love for the mother. However, Jonathan and Juan Severino both have the trait of sacrificing others in order to save their loved ones. Johnray, however, gives his life to save everyone, even his loved ones. It all leads me to the question: to what extents are we willing to go for the sake of love?For the production, when it comes to horror, it‚Äôs either you go big or go home. This means that to be able to justify the concept of a horror film, you will need to exert a lot of effort in executing it, from cinematography, lights, sound design, production design, and wardrobe & prosthetics. I applaud the sound design that carried the whole jump scare, the lights that signified each scenery, the PD, wardrobe, & hmu, who emphasized the time frame, symbolism, and their story as a character.Though there are some unnecessary parts and certain areas that could use of improvement, but overall, I applaud how well they have shown the history, culture, and Filipino myths in this film. The messages they unfold about societal issues, needs to be recognized more; hence, they tackle serious issues such as the injustice killing which represents the EJK, and how the lgbtq community is still considered as part of the ‚Äúsalot ng lipunan‚Äù, and many more, that are still happening today.

ang ganda sana. so many interesting elements, derived from such an interesting story, but it was too ambitious. merong subplots that throw you off the main plot. hindi natahi nang maayos yung scenes in a way that makes the story clear; naging nakakalito lang. + too many jumpscares that didn't add anything to the plot. but i still appreciated a lot of things in the film. ang ganda ng production, ang galing ng performances (pleasantly surprised by jc santos the most). may scenes na nagustuhan ko talaga. and the themes, although too many at once, were still intriguing. i really wish we got to focus on just one.most of my complaints i've already discussed with friends right after the movie. ang paulit-ulit na term na ginamit namin: sayang.

Color grading and the shots felt like an international film. Overall, I love how they incorporate Philippine mythology and lore into this film and kudos to Piolo Pascual for acting three different characters and made them distinctive as well as JC‚Äôs excellent acting skills (deserve ang best supporting actor).

Making the Philippine‚Äôs first recorded serial killer a side character rather than the main lead was a miss. There‚Äôs so much lore and history around the character just for it to be overshadowed by present time‚Äôs Mallari and his spiral. If the movie was solely about the priest, it would‚Äôve been a fucking hit, but I admire the unique take on astral projection and time traveling.While I applaud Piolo Pascual‚Äôs talent in portraying three different characters, I can‚Äôt help but think if there would‚Äôve been a better way to introduce these characters and their stories. The constant flashbacks and sudden time jumps were bordering on overkill, I personally would‚Äôve enjoyed if the movie was sectioned into three parts instead to have a consistent story line because trying to decipher each time period‚Äôs plot made the movie feel longer than it actually was. Reading the wikipedia plot was more entertaining.Also, what the hell is this movie‚Äôs lightning problem? A majority of the jump scares are either the killer or ghosts in the background but I wouldn‚Äôt know because I couldn‚Äôt see shit. Speaking of jump scares, Philippine cinema needs to find new ways of scaring its viewers rather than the typical ~scary image~ with loud music. I admit, some of it worked, but the tension in teasing a potential jump scare is more memorable than a lousy 5 second scare imo. Or maybe I‚Äôm just used to the American horror movie industry and the likes of Blumhouse or A24.To cut it sweet, the parts I liked: the hospital scene at the end being shown in the beginning, each Mallari‚Äôs origins in how all three ended up being in one room at the same time shown throughout the movie, Janella Salvador, the manananggal reveal, generational Alarcon vs Mallari, Piolo Pascual‚Äôs acting, and the overall filmography of it all.Would I watch it again? Mhm, probably not. Did I still enjoy seeing Piolo Pascaul and Janella Salvador on the big screen? Hell fucking yes.
