Plot: No loopholes, everything was answered and nasatisfy ako until the end kasi it lets me think on what happens next pero at the same time I don‚Äôt need na kasi every part of the story is enough to keep you satisfied and kasi you already know what happens to the Mallari Family. ü§´üîÑ The storyline will flow with you and will answer all of your questions!Jump-scares: Medyo OA lang some scenes ng ibang ghosts hindi ko talaga bet haha. Para lang siyang in-add out of nowhere sa script to make it ‚Äúscarier‚Äù since plain nga lang talaga ang flow pag Serial Killers ang story. They added that ‚Äúoomph‚Äù badly pero gets naman na pinoy medyo need ng OA sa life char. When you rewind the clips siguro di talaga nakakatakot yung faces, nakakagulat lang pero ‚Äúeh‚Äù ang makeup, for me, + may OA din na SFX during jumpscares na di ko nabet-an. It‚Äôs too much.Acting: hands down to Piolo Pascual for portraying 3 DIFFERENT CHARACTERS flawlessly!!! Ang galing at walang bahid/mix ng other characters na Mallari. Siguro given na din na they‚Äôre from different timelines pero kitang kita mo yung difference ng character and harmony nila together as ‚ÄúMallaris‚Äù. Special mention to JC Santos!! Napakaganda ng execution niya with his character! + the women in the film Janella and Elisse very strong characters indeed!Cinematography: Seamless and Experimental Since the story has 3 different timelines, it jumps from one timeline to another and super clean ng transitions. Experimental in a way na they‚Äôve incorporated transitions to jump from one dialogue to another and from one Mallari to the next Mallari in another timeline!For the color grading, *chef‚Äôs kiss* it speaks for itself and bawat history ng family nila seamless ang colors. All in all, ganda ng execution!Camera Work: üëèüèªüëèüèªüëèüèª super love it di ko na explain watch niyo nalang very visible yung ganda ng camera work nila!!Production Design: THE BEST. Bawat details sa set ng timelines kuhang kuha!! It feels so alive na parang nangyari talaga siya in real life.Slasher Factor: At the end of the day, it‚Äôs a story about a Serial Killer, medyo nakulangan lang ako sa Serial Killer factor niya. With the slashing scenes, nabitin ako! Kulang sa patayan! Medyo heavily kasi nag focus yung story sa Filipino Theme na may added witchcraft, superstitions, folklore. Which is gets ko kasi it‚Äôs a Filipino Serial Killer it‚Äôs bound to be incorporated with Filipino themes. With the added themes, it‚Äôs too chaotic, in somewhat a good way? Hahaha. Though sana dinagdagan pa nila yung slashing and killings kasi bitin! For the gore, pwede na ilaban. ‚ú®Additional‚ú®Since this is Fiction, some scenes are familiar sa other Horror/Thriller Films that I‚Äôve watched kaya parang magegets mo na din yung scene or mahahalata mo na influenced siya with a certain film.Films like Mallari: Sinister, Insidious, Lights Out Sucker for history and true crime!!

MALLARI, MMFF2023: Based on Filipino Catholic priest Juan Severino Mallari (1785‚Äì1840), the first documented serial killer from the Philippines; Director Roderick Cabrido and writer Enrico Santos deliver a story that takes the premise of Mallari's serial killing and uses it as backstory to advance the horror elements of the film's three-timeline, three-Piolo Pascual act. Personally, I might be in the minority who thinks that, with reports of Mallari showing signs of mental instability around the same time of his killing spree, the film would have worked better as a psychological thriller, sans the folk horror aspect. The filmmakers seemingly took advantage of the paucity of verifiable records about the man's life ‚Äî so much that the liberties they took just screams 'WOW'. Mallari, in its sheer unapologetic glory, is a very interesting mess. As an alchemy of historical thriller and folk horror, at times it becomes too tiring, that audiences can be forgiven for expecting scares before they even appear onscreen. This marriage ultimately combusts in the end, leaving only one of the two as the last genre standing.And for that, flaws and all, I feel Mallari deserves a closer look for its guts to prioritize jump scares to frighten its audiences shitless; even if by doing so, it compromises history ‚Äî and the last ounces of accuracy remaining ‚Äî by putting it on the back burner.

Horror film na may kuwento at hindi jump-scares lang ang puhunan.Bago ang konsepto ng pelikula. Inspired ito sa totoong kuwento ni Juan Severino Mallari na hinaluan ng fiction. Simula pa lang ay may mga panggulat na. Mangangapa ka nga lang at malilito sa dami ng nangyayari. Pabalik-balik kasi sa timeline ng tatlong Mallari. Duda na nga ako nong kalagitnaan kung kaya ba nilang pagtagpi-tagpiin ang lahat ng bahagi ng walang sabit o plot hole.Sigawan ang mga tao sa sinehan lalo sa habulang eksena sa dulo. Kaya masasabi ko talagang effective sa pananakot ang pelikula. Marami ring plot twist na dapat abangan. May mangilan-ngilang plot holes nga lang at ilang rebelasyon na predictable pero hindi naman no‚Äôn maikakaila ang ganda ng pelikula.Sa huli‚Äôy natahi naman ng maayos ang bawat piraso. Gusto-gusto ko ang ending. Hindi ko ito inaasahan. Nakakagulat! Lalo akong humanga sa galing JC dito. Deserve na deserve ang best supporting actor. Nakakakilabot naman si Gloria Diaz! Mahirap makalimutan ang karakter niya dito. Nakakatuwang makakita ng ganitong klaseng pinoy horror. Kaya naman pala natin!

Aaminin ko. May inaasahan na ako sa Mallari dahil sa mga magagandang salita na nabasa ko. Pero hindi naging sarado para hindi maging sariwa ang pagkilala ko sa pelikula.Mabilis na ipinakilala ang karakter. Hindi sila nagpahaba ng paghihintay bago mo malaman kung tungkol saan ang pelikula. Ngunit sa simula pa lang, alam mo na yung inihahanda nilang ibunyag sa dulo ng pelikula.May mga panahon napabilib ako sa paraan ng editing at pagkuha ng eksena pero hindi ito naging sapat para mailatag ng malinaw ang istorya.May iilang eksena na hindi nakatulong sa pagkukwento bagkus nag-iwan lamang ng mga katanungan hindi na nabigyan ng kasagutan.Maayos ang ipinakita ni Piolo pero hindi ako tiyak kung ito ay kayang magpanalo sa kanya ng parangal. Pero gusto ko at nararapat siyang bigyan ng pagkilala sa maraming karakter na ginampanan niya. Kung pagbabasehan ang akting na ipinakita, SI JC Santos ang magbubuhat ng bandera sa gabi ng parangal. Mahusay at nararapat ang ipinakita niya.Medyo naguluhan lang ako sa mga manunulat kung anong kwento ba ang gusto nila para sa mga manunuod. May mga oras na mapapasigaw ka pero mas maraming oras na mapapahula ka kung ano nga ba tong pinapanuod mo sa sinehan.Ihanda ang mga tenga dahil sa sobrang lakas na tunog na ibinibigay ng pelikula. Hindi ko alam kung sa sinehan ba o sadyang ganun ang pagka-edit ng pelikula. Oo, isa itong pelikulang magpapatalon sa iyo sa kinauupuan gamit ang biswal at tunog ngunit napasobra ata ito sa lakas kumpara sa mga napanuod natin may ganitong tema.2/5 ang rating na aking ibibigay. May instensyon ang pelikula pero bigong mabuo ang kwento ng mas solido pa. Kung binabalak mong panuorin ang Mallari, baka sa streaming apps maari.

(Note: This review contains spoilers.)This is certainly one of the most bizarre films I‚Äôve ever seen.I entered the theater expecting a retelling of Juan Severino Mallari‚Äôs story in the form of a slasher film, but ended up witnessing something completely different. My expectations were completely subverted.The film took so much creative license and put some fantasy and supernatural twists on Juan Severino Mallari‚Äôs story, which is really inventive. But while I do appreciate this creative effort, I was not quite satisfied with its outcome. As much as I want to give lots of praises to the film, I believe it has some flaws, which, unfortunately, brought down its quality.Frankly, the film was too ambitious. It tried too hard to present a complex and mind-boggling concept but ended up executing it poorly. Hence, when I left the theater, I felt that something was missing. The film didn‚Äôt turn out to be as impressive and groundbreaking as I expected it to be.Perhaps, they should have just focused on the time travel aspect, because that was done brilliantly. Fusing it with Juan Severino Mallari‚Äôs story and excessive supernatural elements ruined what could have been an amazing time-travel historical film. The foundation was already there! It would‚Äôve created something truly impressive and groundbreaking, until‚Ä¶ the poor execution of the story‚Äôs very ambitious plot.Also, the dialogues were clunky. Many of the conversations between characters who are supposedly close to one another felt forced and awkward. An example is when Jonathan suddenly shouted at Lucas after the latter butted in on his conversation with Agnes. His shouting came out of nowhere, and it felt so forced. Sure, he was angry at Lucas, but I didn‚Äôt feel its emotional weight due to how forced it was. (I‚Äôm aware of the reason for Jonathan‚Äôs anger, it‚Äôs the clunky dialogue that‚Äôs the problem.) There are more instances like this throughout the film, and it really bothered me. The timing of the dialogues, as well as the choice of words, were really off.But despite my gripes with the film, I‚Äôm gonna give it three stars because it has some redeeming qualities. Among these are Piolo Pascual and JC Santos‚Äô impeccable performances.I was absolutely impressed with how Piolo was able to portray three different characters while putting certain nuances to each of them. The three characters are really different from one another, and you could tell that based on their individual demeanors, personalities, and body languages, which Piolo fantastically depicted. I really hope he wins an award for this, because not many actors could pull this off.And JC Santos‚Ä¶ man, he really deserves his Best Supporting Actor award!! Even though I was able to predict it easily, I had goosebumps when his character, Lucas, turned out to be the killer in the present day. JC pulled off the Jekyll and Hyde persona so well. He should do this type of role more often!Furthermore, the film did well when it comes to building suspense. Although it is not as scary as typical horror films, the jump scares were still frightening. Additionally, the score and sound effects were spectacular ‚Äî they fitted every scene perfectly and greatly intensified the eerie atmosphere of the film. And the pacing was surprisingly good! In contrast to most long films, I wasn‚Äôt bothered with the runtime of this one. Most scenes were paced appropriately.Overall, disregarding my criticisms, I enjoyed watching this film. It had a lot of wasted potential, but it still gave me a nice cinematic experience.

Sorry to say this, but this is just a 130-minute-long glowed-up version of a Gabi ng Lagim episode. Staying awake was a struggle.Its astounding cinematography cannot salvage this film from the utter ludicrousness of the story. Its premise was interesting. After all, it was supposed to depict the Philippines' first serial killer, Fr. Juan Severino Mallari, a talented calligrapher-turned-murderer priest in Pampanga.Yet, it tried to outsmart its audience by hyping up a confused intergenerational Mallari curse. What came out was a mess littered with pathetically otiose jumpscares, lazy narrations, historical inaccuracies, overstretched fictionalization, and the implausibility of astral projection and time travel. To make matters worse, there were hints of transphobia, racism, and glorification of extrajudicial killings flying all over this film.JC Santos and his deranged act as a killer stood out in this film. And don't fret; that "twist" was given away in the first 15 minutes. Gloria Diaz was great. Piolo Pascual succeeded in crafting three different personas. All weren't enough to make this good enough.

Came into this expecting to know more about the actual Fr. Mallari, but should've known from that title card that the movie was going to end up exactly how it did.The rare silver linings were how Kapampangan was spoken throughout the film and JC Santos' performance, but I agree with popular sentiments: it was promising but overambitious, which resulted in a half-baked film with visual jumpscares that looked like TikTok filters.It also felt like the crew involved hated its future audience, getting ahead of themselves with "pa-woke" references and poor depiction of a LGBTQ character. I know the movie was about folk spirituality gone awry, but I guess I just expected more compassion from a movie related to religion.What a waste of a talented cast only to end up in a film that didn't know what to do with them.

No matter what other people say, i think this is a great horror filipino film I have ever watched. The way they infused and inspiration in filipino history and meshed it with filipino folklore and catholic saints to make it a theme over a theme was smooth. Writers have really sewn these together and made such a good horror film. Would also commend how Piolo depicted 3 different characters becoming slowly insane was something I did not expect at all. All the more, it was well executed; would watch again.

This film may had left a lot of things to be desired but I liked it. It has tons of jump scares (and I liked it that way, I guess) and for that, it somehow deserves some kind of appreciation, I guess. However, I felt that the other elements, particularly the time-travelling (or astral projection) part, were so underutilized because I felt that maybe this angle might have been used more to drive the story forward (it would have been fun to see more time altering consequences here). Also, it would have been more fun if the body count was a little bit higher, I guess. To add to the things that were left a lot to be desired, the ending fell flat for me, when the main character in the 2023 timeline ended up doing the exact things he was trying to prevent. Like dude (can't believe I share a name with the character), really now? Even your ancestors were disappointed.

Mallari is a good thriller film if you are craving some thrills. It gives adequate tension for most scenes, with entertaining plot twists for everyone watching.However, it suffered from bad writing and dumb choices. There was an attempt for a relatability in Father Mac's character, but it was too much it feels shoved into the film. Wonder if they paid license from Sueisha and Pierrot for that character that is just used for comedic relief. The marketing of the film is waaay waay off the actual film plot. It tried to incorporate a lot of elements: family, isekai, love, occult, Philippine folklore, and common horror tropes but executed quite badly. It was a clickbait/watchbait to say it is a film about Severino Mallari, but more of a fictionalized character of him (adding the Disclaimer about using St. Bartholomew as a plot device didn't help at all). The music is too much to aid with horror; it helped me anticipate the jumpscares.There is also a missed opportunity in painting the moon red for trying to tie it into blood moon as well, you know, when blood is involved here.But Piolo and JC Santos carried the film. They both provided some wide range of character. They somehow saved the film. I can also see Piolo in Melvil Poupaud. He somehow styles like him and has aged well.In short, Mallari is like me, quite confusing to discern its main purpose because it went off-tangents and digressions.

okay im gonna brain dump cause im writing this at 2 amAlright, this was pretty ok.It wasn't bad by any means, but this movie tried waaaay too hard to be scary. Too many cheap jump scares and the sound design ruined some of the moments. Some of the cgi was horrible too and I wish they used practical effects instead. Speaking of effects, the gore in this movie was weird. It's like they're not afraid to be graphic but they're also not showing how graphic the kills are? Then there's the plot. Lots of misplaced exposition and unanswered questions. Unanswered questions are a good thing but the questions we really needed answers to were never answered. Despite all of these, Mallari had a lot of things going for it. Piolo was great, JC was great, I bet Janella would've been great too if she was given more screen time. I respect their decision to add a more complicated twist to the material at hand, but this would've been better if it was a period piece and focused more on what happened back in 1812. Overall, a good watch but could've been better. What I like best about this movie is the fact that studios are giving stories like these a chance to get the big screen treatment. It gives me hope that this could open doors for more movies like this to get made.

An interesting premise wasted with mediocre story, cinematography and direction. The idea of a Filipino serial killer, and him being a priest, could have been a thought-provoking film about the hypocrisy of Catholicism that preaches good values but protects child molesters... instead we got a God-apologist film that attempts to nod toward "woke culture" by strawmanning a caricature of what conservatives think queerfolk are. Which honestly is very telling of the thinking of what the film is clearly intended for.‚Ä¶

Walang Diyos sa gabi.It‚Äôs refreshing to see Piolo Pascual do quadruple duty with his role as Father Juan Severino Mallari, Johnrey Mallari, and Jonathan Mallari de Dios. The film weaves three timelines, allowing the past and present to come full circle.Mallari goes beyond the historical account it is based on and adds a sense of supernatural and spiritual element to the mix, which in some parts worked, and some didn't. The story can go into familiar territory, settling with horror elements from the films in the past, and struggling to reach the film's full potential for the genre. However, much can be said about the film's magnificent and terrorizing score, cinematography, and production design. These aspects elevate the film even further, which is enough to make up for the story's shortcomings.

One of the most anticipated films of this year's MMFF is about the curious case of Father Severino Mallari, a real-life Filipino priest who is also the country's first-ever documented serial killer. What makes people even more excited is that this is lead actor #PioloPascual 's first horror film to date, after being tried and tested in romance/drama/comedy genres. This is among the final batch of films announced to be a part of the festival shortlist, which now has 2 entries more than its usual 8. In this film, Pascual plays three distinct characters in different time periods: Doctor Jonathan (present time), war documentarian Johnrey (1940s) and the serial killer Fr. Severino (1800s). Individually, these key characters all face the fears of their respective eras, while their paths converge in one hidden room of the Mallari mansion. It is delightful to watch Pascual step up his game in portraying the triple characters with distinct personalities, perhaps one of the most memorable performances in this festival. However, #JCSantos brings out the real surprise of this film and there's genuine terror in his character's ultimate reveal! If only the CGI effects were polished and convincing enough, then its horrific atmosphere may have been consistent. The film sure took a risk in mixing a lot of elements that could be too much to absorb in one sitting. Honestly, I would've wanted it to focus more on the killer priest and explore his psyche on a deeper level - his internal battles and the impact of his killings. The concept of an astral time travel could be saved on another film, the blood relation of the three leads may already be used to explain their connection. They could've used the time building up the crime-horror-folklore angles rather than explain all the sci-fi.Still, Mallari is a good attempt at elevating our taste in cinema. May this inspire more filmmakers to experiment in the horror genre.3.5 OUT OF 5‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê¬ΩüìÉSTORY - 0.7üé•EXECUTION - 0.6üë•CHARACTERIZATION - 0.8üçøENTERTAINMENT VALUE - 0.7‚ú®LASTING IMPACT - 0.7

I think what makes many people disappointed at this film was because they assumed it'd be true to historical fact.I came in with no knowledge and expectations, so I loved the ride. It's amazing to think this is a local film. Great pacing, clear cut differentiation from each character/ timeline, and surprisingly the film was able to ease in sci-fi and supernatural concepts smoothly even if it was a bit out of left field. I honestly enjoyed the film, and it felt like going on a ride where you'd think it'll end soon, but turns out there's another part to explore and visit. It gave me the same amazement as I had with Parasite, with how the film felt like 3 movies in 1. So yeah, that was cool. I enjoyed it!

‚ÄúùôÑùô®ùô£‚Äôùô© ùô°ùô§ùô´ùôö ùôñùô°ùô®ùô§ ùôñ ùôòùô™ùôßùô®ùôö?‚ÄùHow far will you go for love? I believe this is the theme of the movie.Father Mallari is a real figure in Philippines history, the first documented serial killer in the country. The movie tells his story from the angle of love and madness. After some researches, I found that the real Father Mallari might have acted with love or he had mental issues.This movie is a fiction based on the real story of Father Mallari; it has a very mysterious background and I like the darkness it presented and how the story didn‚Äôt end with political correctness; however, the ending couldn‚Äôt have ended earlier.Nevertheless, there are too many jump scares (with unnecessarily too strong sound effect), which didn‚Äôt help pushing the plot forward and made it draggy.The acting range (and muscles) of Piolo are amazing; his has 4-style in the movie, if you watch close enough, there is a small detail for the style of Johnathan. Since Piolo has a mole near his left ear, to further differentiate the style of Johnrey and Johnathan, his mole was removed (likely by CG) when he plays Johnathan.JC Santos is really outstanding, he definitely stole the spotlight.The buildup of atmosphere is great, technical aspects are pretty impressive like visual effect, lighting and scores. However, editing seems to be another issue. For example, the scene where Father Mallari just returned home and almost encountered Johnrey and Johnathan, had repeated 3-time in the movie. Is it really necessary or audiences would be that absent-minded?I‚Äôm not sure whether relatively jumpy editing is the storytelling style of Director Cabrido, because his last movie ùòûùò™ùò¥ùò© ùò†ùò∞ùò∂ ùòûùò¶ùò≥ùò¶ ùòõùò©ùò¶ ùòñùòØùò¶ also has this issue.

Jusko ang panget. As in ang panget. Nasayangan ako sa 300 na binayad ko jusko talaga. Jusko!!!!! Kakairita kasi nag-expect ako kasi sabi maganda daw ganon, hype na hype pero ayon SOBRANG PANGET!!!!pakagulo ng story!!! Serial killer bigla naging werewolf tas may manananggal pa. Pinagsama sama ba naman lahat sa iisang movie, ayon ang kalat as fuck!!! Jusko feel ko mas okay to kung ginawa na lang nilang crime/thriller, hindi yung horror tas yung elements eh mga gamit na gamit na ng mga previous horror films ganon.Panget ng dialogue!! Panget ng delivery. May mga pilit na pilit magtagalog, tas may pilit din mag spanish. Jusko naman. Magagaling naman yung actors on their own pero bat ganon kapag magkakasama sila sa isang scene, ang panget. Panget ng directing, in short. Panget din ng vfx. Ang low effort. Natatawa ko sa mga films na shinushoot ni johnrey circa 1940s tapos ang framerate ay 60fps tapos pinatungan lang ng film scratches na filter. Jusko oh. Dinadaan sa booming sound fx yung jump scares, hindi naman talaga nakakatakot jusko. Wala ring build-up, hindi ka on edge ganon. Panget pa ng cgi sa mga multo. Naubos ata ang budget kay papa p.Isa pa, set sa pampanga toh, so expected na may kapampangan dialogue pero kakatawa kasi sobrang rare, parang siniksik lang ganon, masabi lang na kapampangan sila, napaka unnatural ng dating.Ayon pa pala, walang chemistry yung mga actors, esp si papa p at janella at elisse. Parang pilit na pilit yung relationship. Ewan shuta mas may chemistry pa ata si papa p at gloria diaz.Ang ambitious ng movie na toh, parang ang daming gustong talakayin na topics pero sa sobrang dami, ayon, underdeveloped lahat. Dat kase isa isa lang!!! Kung ginawa nyo na lang sana tong criticism ng church, baka mas okay pa.1 star kasi ok naman yung score, lalo yung sa ending. Sadyang panget lang ng lahat. Dinaan lang sa color grading eh. Bat ganto mga movie ngayon, puro aesthetics lang ata, kulang sa substance at ang gulo as fuck ng plot.Anyway, kung gusto nyo ng magandang horror film na about sa religion, panurin nyo na lang yung seklusyon. Creepy as fuck pa di tulad nito na mema lang.

(no context) the film is so good to the point that Im never eating BALUT AGAIN. Mallari is hands down one of the best Filipino films I've ever seen. The cinematography is crazy especially in the smooth transitions, with lighting and lines used. The film showcased into the nuanced relationship between religion, kulam, hierarchy, and also shows on how mental illness was once a taboo topic (till now lol). the story of the original juan severino from 1812, a 1946 Mallari who documents the post-WWII era through film, and a present-day Mallari doctor desperately searching for a cure for his fiancee's future illness. Piolo Pascual played all three Mallaris (fucking goated). A must watch! Dont forget to bring lotion and tissues

The storyline cleverly deceives you into believing that its plot is predictable, allowing you to anticipate scenes and revelations. However, the meticulous crafting of every detail ensures that, despite the apparent predictability, the execution remains so well-done that you'll still find yourself shocked and frightened. The film achieves this without unnecessarily complicating the narrative, maintaining its effectiveness in delivering surprises and scares."Mallari" masterfully employs a multi-sensory approach, seamlessly blending visuals and sound to provoke a powerful emotional response from the audience. The effectiveness of the musical scoring becomes evident as it skillfully crafts a suspenseful and frightening atmosphere, enhancing the impact of jump scares and intensifying the overall horror experience.The cast delivered compelling portrayals of their characters, infusing depth and authenticity that kept the audience engaged. Despite the anticipation of impending jump scares, their performances were so effective that even when expected, the audience found themselves screaming in response to the well-executed moments of shock.Contrary to the typical ending associated with this theme, where the protagonist usually finds redemption or breaks free from the negative thread, "Mallari" takes a different approach. The film allows the protagonist to embrace the path of becoming the villain, seemingly without learning from the events of the story, succumbing to darkness. This unexpected twist left a lasting impression, showcasing an innovative narrative where the conventional expectations are skillfully subverted, making the storytelling more impressive in its well-outlined and unconventional trajectory.Hats off to the Mallari Team for creating an outstanding film that truly deserves international recognition. Kudos to everyone involved!

A Mix of Hill House and Insidious in a Filipino Film.Yes. You‚Äôve read that right. If you liked the two media I have mentioned, I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôd love Mallari just as much as I did. It had the perfect amount of jumpscares (which I liked a lot). But in my head, a good horror movie is more than just its jumpscares. It has to have a plot. And this movie had. I loved everything about this film regardless of the complaint of the internet on that one particular reveal/scene. To me, that scene added up everything and completely made sense. Undoubtedly, Piolo is already a really good actor and he delivered in this film. This is honestly the latest Filipino horror film that I genuinely enjoyed. Actually, the latest horror film (including films produced in Hollywood). It had a hint of hill house and insidious, which are two horror favorites of mine so I was grinning the whole film as I loved and is amazed by our bahaviors.

- mallari is a horror + time-travel story about a doctor, Jonathan, who (spoiler alert!!) dreamt his girlfriend will be dying, and he began his search of what made his great-great grandmother live a very, very long life to the point that there was no document of her death. the storytelling is very intelligent, piolo pascual playing 3 different roles in 3 different eras - second as Jonathan's old uncle and documentarist, Johnrey, who sacrificed himself in attempt to stop evil, and lastly as Fr. Severino who used to be very kind but ended up committing murders for his mother to live long. it's such a good watch, no dead scenes, also with jc santos, playing as Lucas, Jonathan's friend who was the killer in the present time!! i just hated that Jonathan killed him, but then ended up digging the grave of Johnrey to get the evil creature and pass it to his girlfriend, Agnes (played by janella salvador) making her a monster. he just put his uncle's sacrifice to waste!! what a stupid man... and not to mention, Agnes did not approve it, he only forced it to her. good thing, their relationship is not the same after, that's a good ending.

A familiar yet refreshing take on Filipino horror.Mallari served as the frontrunner for last year‚Äôs MMFF months before the festival. Trailers were good and promotions were good as well, but what surprised me is the difference between the final film and these promotional materials. I was expecting Mallari to be Psychological Thriller or a slasher film but it was meddled with paranormal and time travel. You can already pinpoint who the killer is in the first 30 minutes of the film, which is a bummer. JC Santos gave a splendid performance but his character and the twist of the story could be done better. Magulo yung first act, it felt like marami silang gustong ilagay sa marrative. Lines were cringy and walang tao sa totoong buhay na ganon mag salita. The film also had unnecessary jumpscares na walang purpose sa story, very Filipino horror movie core.The second and the last act is where the story started to take ita shape and form. I was glued down to my seats with what I was watching. Magulo ang simula pero natahi nila nang maayos ang lahat ng elemento sa dulo which is what made me like this film despite its issues. Piolo Pascual showed how great he was in his craft. Sa pelikulang ito makikita mo kung bakit sought after si Piolo. Janella Salvador was also great in this movie, she can be the queen of filipino horror movies. Sound design and the set designs were my favorite, dito mo makikitang pinaghandaan at may malaking budget ang palabas na ito.Mallari has some of the elements of a bad and cringey horror movies but it also has refreshing takes on a newer form of horror and storytelling that uses a lore to expound on a subject matter.

Perhaps the most surprising aspect of Mallari is how the director Derick Cabrido managed to weave together a staggering amount of narrative threads and somehow still ended up with a cohesive story. Although the same thing cannot be said about its many thematic layers that often felt convoluted and reactionary, there is something to be admired (or at least respected) with how textually rich Cabrido aims his film to be.Albeit inferred only through the choice of time periods (1818/1948/2018), Mallari succeeds in tracing a historical and cultural perspective on the Duterte drug war‚Äìthat of a messianic figure (Duterte/Fr. Mallari) assuming the role of both judge and executioner of perceived "plagues" of society (the sinful/addicts)‚Äìand clearly demonstrates why this is problematic and is ultimately an act of self-preservation. The film takes a firm stance against mass murder, especially when it is enacted by the elites, and in the current Filipino socio-political climate this sentiment is well-appreciated.However, Mallari's portrayal of folk religion/mythology vis-a-vis Christianity is rather questionable. On one hand the film explores its anti-colonial capacity, that its integration into a Western notion of Christianity did not necessarily result into assimilation; indeed, through sinister shots littered with religious figurines (rooted in pagan worship) and the psychological corruption of Fr. Mallari's morals, the film shows that folk traditions' effects and influences have stood the test of time and could even be argued as the primary feature through which Filipinos practice modern Christianity.On the other hand, however, Mallari is still unable to resist the hegemonic assumptions that these folk practices are inherently evil; they may be anti-colonial but they're just as bad, maybe even worse. They function mainly to bolster the film's hypothesis‚Äîthat evil is the primary component of the world and that everything else exist only in relation to it.This argument is most explicitly shown through the construction of Casa Mallari as a liminal space, where different temporal (past, present, future) and existential (living and non-living) realities converge. This is also the reason why the scares, although seemingly imitating the effect of sudden shock, are deliberately designed to evoke diminishing affective returns; fear is not an anomaly in the film's diegesis but is rather the norm, further supporting the essentialist view of the world and humanity as evil.And although this position works within the confines of the horror genre in which Mallari operates, I remain not fully sold on such bleak and defeatist attitude. I'd rather believe that there exist other "manlalakbays" (time travelers) with the capacity to intervene and put an end to this cycle of violence.

Piolo Pascual has proven why he is still at the top of his game. He has departed from the romantic heartthrob roles and has taken on more challenging and diverse characters than we usually see him in. In "Mallari," he portrays three related characters across different generations. I enjoyed the diversity in each character and how they all have different fates, showcasing various kinds of love. As Severino, the murderous priest with a malicious intent to kill the bad seed in his community and free his mother from a curse, Piolo is very convincing as a serial killer. The transition scene in the church, where he was being convinced by the Patron Saint Bartholomew, was just a chef‚Äôs kiss.As Johnrey, Piolo transitions into a man willing to do everything to rid himself of the curse. And as Jonathan, who was willing to do everything to save a loved one, Piolo was so good that you might want to express frustration for all the stupidity and recklessness he portrayed.The ending scene, where Piolo is facing the audience as if telling them that he will be hunting them for the night, is just brilliant. This is a one-of-a-kind Filipino horror movie.

The performances were mostly great as expected, it has a very interesting concept, and the vibe was surely creepy and effective. There were several intense moments that I genuinely enjoyed. The makeup, productions, and settings were amazing, as well. The visual effects did not look promising, but at least there were not a lot of it. There were some cheap scares, too, and wasted scenes that could have been really terrifying. Some people might also find the storytelling a little confusing, but I doubt anyone would not understand everything by the end. There were decent twists, but one major one was pretty predictable. But all in all, I know I haven't watched a lot of Tagalog movies in years, but this is one of, if not the best one I've seen in a while.2023 RankedHorror RankedTagalog Ranked

Though there was a tendency to use the cheapest of jump scares, I‚Äôd have to say that this was otherwise a fairly effective horror that was pretty decent at atmosphere building. It did drag a bit long at times and there was some confusion with it constantly switching time periods, but I can‚Äôt say it was a bad time.Piolo Pascual is a solidly charismatic lead.It was a pretty solid effort even if I wasn‚Äôt totally happy with its execution. This film fumbles its creepy Filipino folklore concept. The concept had potential ‚Äì a creepy urban legend stemming from a small provincial town, it was an interesting background.The film tries to be complex, weaving multiple narratives and timelines together, delving into astral projects and whatnot. However, this complexity ends up muddying the story instead of enriching it. It feels like the writer bit off more than they could chew, lacking the clear vision needed to pull off a compelling horror or thriller.The tension and suspense, crucial ingredients for any horror film, are noticeably absent. The overall storytelling, from pacing to camerawork, shot selections and editing choices fail to build any real sense of unease, suspense or anticipation; falling short of the genre's demands.With a tighter focus, a clearer narrative structure, and a director with a stronger grasp of the genre, "Mallari" could have been a genuinely scary and unsettling experience. As it stands, it's a forgettable mess.

horrible. so dumb and annoying, i'm not kidding when i say i was frowning throughout and considered walking out within 30 minutes into this. one of those films i knew instantly i wouldn't like it in the prologue and title card, and was so deeply disappointed at having been conned by that synopsis. it's not a period psychological horror about religion and mental illness, which is what that description implies, but so much bullshit with astral projection and time travelling (you can't be fucking kidding me....) jump scares and spirits zooming into the camera. it addresses nothing about spanish colonialism, christianity, or the locals, but rings through the same cycle about the ~ugly poors~ and lower class being practitioners of evil and the dark arts. wow... okay, groundbreaking and sooo progressive. of course. but what i absolutely loathed and consider super juvenile in horror filmmaking were the jump scares and sound design. i HATED the way sound was used in this. disgusting, cheap, no finesse or subtlety, the kind of thing writers and directors with no creativity use to spook the audience cos they have no talent crafting an atmospheric horror with the background and environment of its characters. came back home and discussed it a lot and everything we talked about just got me angrier, seeing how dumb this film was. a waste of my time and money.

The dialogue is pandering. I consider the portrayal of the trans character problematic because there is a greater focus on their perceived immorality compared to the other victims of Mallari. The servants are the villains that the wealthy master needs to defeat.There is a love for the horror genre with homages to psycho, Rosemary's baby, the Innocents. A greater emphasis is on trauma similar to the works of Mike Flanagan. I think the story is a combination between midnight mass and haunting of Hill house.Piolo Pascual convincingly portrays three different roles. Elisse Joson's mid Atlantic accent was a surprising detail that definitely sets her character in that time and place.

This was a really good film. It shows three perspectives of three different characters played by Piolo Pascual. The nice visual effects were really nice, and I was not expecting the quality to be THAT good. Byfar the BEST Filipino film I‚Äôve seen.It boasts a captivating plot intricately linked to Philippine history and urban legend. The commendable acting skills of all characters significantly contribute to the film‚Äôs appeal. The pacing strikes a perfect balance‚Äîneither too fast nor too slow, preventing viewers from experiencing boredom, or confusion.Regrettably, the downside lies in the inclusion of unnecessary jump scares, creating an abrupt disruption in the flow of the film. This drawback proves to be a significant dent in the overall quality of an otherwise promising story.Despite this setback, it‚Äôs important to note that ‚ÄúMallari‚Äù still stands as a commendable horror film, especially when compared to the usual offerings in the Philippine horror genre. Its compelling plot, historical ties, and the commendable performances of the cast elevate it above many counterparts, making it a worthwhile watch for enthusiasts of the genre.
OVERALL 10/10 MAS NINDOT IF SA SINEHAN GYUD LANTAWON THE FOLKLORES, MUSIC, CINEMATOGRAPHY, ACTING, PLOT, EVERTHING WAS ON POINT A MUST WATCH MOVIE

Father Severino: Panganay na mama's boy forever Johnrey: The rationale middle childJonathan: The super spoiled na bunsong sabog ang priorities at decision-making sa buhayI honestly thought it was just a historical fiction drama with a slight side of horror and thriller, but boy I was surprised. I went into "Mallari" with a mixture of excitement and skepticism because of how well-received it was by Filipino viewers on social media. Regretfully, the film's execution left me feeling disappointed, and my expectations were not fulfilled. To bring the story to its best, the screenplay in particular needs to be significantly revised.On the one hand, the film's artistic vision is praiseworthy. It is creative and promising that the authors chose to examine several incarnations of the Mallari family in diverse eras. But the execution is inadequate. It's challenging to fully immerse yourself in the characters and their struggles because of the story's rambling dialogue and pacing.Despite being a crucial part of the movie, the big reveal feels hurried and doesn't have the emotional impact it needs. The final choice made by the protagonist, which is supposed to be a pivotal moment in the narrative, is disappointing and has no lasting effect. Additionally, there is no tension or surprise because the criminal killer's identity is revealed right away. Furthermore, the movie's depiction of Mallari's deeds and killings is a little sanitized, which lessens the story's overall impact. The final product does not justify the audience's reaction to the story, nor does it fully realize its complexity. It was a failure all around. Although it had promise, the narrative required a lot of work and changes. The morality of Fr. could have been the subject of the film. Mallari and how his actions' effects were still troublesome. The topic of murder and why it shouldn't be accepted or exalted could have been covered.Sayang!Props to JC Santos tho!

Hindi ko mawari kung saan o paano ako magsisimula. I read an article about the real Father Mallari and why, just why, was his story portrayed in this way? I am not going to talk into detail na about the structure or the scenes of the film basta 'yung feelings ko rollercoaster. Puntahan natin yung mahalaga. The film was supposed to be historic and cultural. No matter what kind of creative tweaks ang niluto nila, hindi ba't pangalan ni Juan Severino Mallari ang ginagamit natin dito? Where was his story? Sa pagkakaunawa ko, tila napunta ang spotlight kay John Rey at Jonathan kung sinuman sila. At tangina pa ni Jonathan. Hindi ito ang kwento ni Father Juan Severino Mallari. Ano kayang sasabihin ni Mallari kung bumangon siya sa hukay niya ngayon? His story is rich with moral dilemmas and gray areas and very significant and relevant topics such as psychological disorders that could have been interpreted and revealed to us in a way na may twist pa rin siguro? without adding those unnecessary fictional elements. This could have been the chance to talk more about the Church and our individual beliefs and how it clashes with each other but they didn't. In fact, bakit hindi na lang nila ginawang drama? Hindi na lang nila ginawang isang pelikula na sa mga susunod na taon ay magiging isang klasiko? Kontemporaryo? Isang mahalagang reperensya? Bakit thriller? Bakit Haunted Mansion style? For the last 20 years most of the Filipino films that have been released are all short-lived. Konting-konti lang ang nagsusurive ng maraming taon at pinapanood at tinatangkilik pa rin hanggang ngayon. This could have been the chance for God's sakes!!!!!! And, no, we do not need millions of budget to make masterpieces, no. God, wala na sumigi na ako. Hinding hindi maikakaila na lagong-lago ang imahinasyon ng mga taong nasa likod ng pelikulang ito. I liked or maybe loved the creativity that was poured unto to the making of this film. I needed some hope na mayroon pa ring mga sining na pinaghihirapan at hindi pineperahan. And, Mallari maybe gave me that hope, gaano man kaliit. Alam ko na hindi pa rin ito yung ginustong nilang maging katapusan ng pelikula. They were just so limited, perhaps, by factors such as censorship, pressure from corporations from investors? O, kaya, iniisip na lang lagi ng mga filmmakers natin na ang mga manonood ay yung mga casual moviegoers lang, ganon ganon. Ayaw kong maging masyadong harsh sa kanila dahil siguro nahihirapan din sila. Pero, ganito na lang ba palagi? Gustong kong may magbago. Gusto kong may maramdaman ulit akong tindig-balihibo hindi yung pilit na gulat.

Mallari (2023) Review:Mallari is a 2023 Philippine horror-drama movie directed by Roderick Cabrido. The screenplay was written by Enrico Santos. It‚Äôs produced by Allan V. Aldea, Ronalyn Bana-ag, John Bryan Diamante, Roxan Mendoza, Carl Yvan Dornila, and Gio Medina. The film‚Äôs production companies here are Mentorque Productions and Clever Minds Inc. It‚Äôs distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures and Star Cinema. It stars Piolo Pascual, Janella Salvador, JC Santos, Elisse Joson Vangie Labalan, Bart Guingona, Ge Villamil, Raffy Tejada, and Gloria Diaz.‚ÄúThe movie is inspired by true events. The story is set in three generations and follows the Mallari family: Juan Severino, John Rey, and Jonathan (all of whom are portrayed by Piolo Pascual). Juan Severino was a Catholic priest and serial killer during the Spanish colonial era in the Philippines in the 19th century. John Rey is a photo journalist and also the grandnephew of Juan Severino during post-World War II. Johnathan is his great-grandnephew and also a doctor in the modern world. Their stories interlink with one another.‚ÄùI was honestly looking forward to this film. Ever since I‚Äôve read about its premise, it immediately caught my attention. The trailer was solid. It has a pretty interesting premise. The history that aspects of its story have taken inspiration from catches my attention. If executed properly, this would be a really solid movie. I was eagerly waiting for its release on Netflix, and after finally watching it, I have to say that I was rather disappointed with it. I really wanted to like this film, but there are a lot of things here that are pretty dull.Mallari (2023) is a mixed bag. It‚Äôs decently directed, and it also has a solid cast. Visually, it looks great, and the music was excellent. There is some creepy atmosphere here, and again, the premise was interesting. Unfortunately, the film leaves a lot to be desired, especially with its script. It has a very messy, bland, and uninteresting story. The characters are wooden, and a lot of the dialogue was cringeworthy. The pacing is inconsistent, and the scares are very cheap. This film was mediocre. Here are my thoughts on the movie:Positives:- It‚Äôs a decently directed film. Roderick Cabrido did a fairly serviceable job with the film‚Äôs overall direction. There are definitely some moments here where I can see what they‚Äôre going for. As for the cast, I thought they were pretty solid. A lot of the performances here are good. Their chemistry with each other was also fairly decent here. Piolo Pascual‚Äôs performance certainly shines throughout the entire duration of the film. He‚Äôs performance was good.- Visually, the film actually looks pretty good. There are plenty of shots here that looks excellent, especially the final shot. Some of the camera work that they‚Äôve done here is also pretty good. Aside from its overall cinematography, the film also has a solid atmosphere. There were some moments where I find this aspect to be incredibly effective. The music composed by Von de Guzman is excellent. It fits the tone of the film, and at times, it was effective.- As for its premise, this aspect was the reason I wanted to watch it. The film has a very intriguing premise, and there are moments where I can see the potential. Unfortunately, the execution could‚Äôve been better (more on that later on). Aside from that, there are a couple of decent moments here and there. There are a couple of creepy moments, especially with the atmosphere. Its production is a mixed bag. At times, this aspect here was fairly decent.Negatives:- As for my issues, despite a pretty interesting premise, the execution certainly leaves a lot to be desired, especially with the script, which was rather lackluster. There are some moments here where I can see the potential that it has, but it often devolves into a generic and messy story. The structure here was all over the place. It doesn‚Äôt really help that it was also underdeveloped. It‚Äôs really disappointing how underbaked the premise of this movie is.- Not only is the story very lackluster, but the same thing can also be said about the characters themselves. Sure, the performances from the cast members may be solid, the characters that they are portraying, on the other hand, just fall flat to me. I didn‚Äôt really care about or find any of them to be all that interesting. The dialogue is also pretty terrible at times. It tries to be modern with its dialogue here, but it usually ends up being really cringeworthy.- Aside from that, the editing here is also pretty choppy. Not only from the overall structure of its narrative but also within its jump scares. Speaking of its jump scares, they aren‚Äôt good. Sure, the film can be creepy at times, but it‚Äôs not all that scary. The jump scares that it does here often end up being predictable and clich√©d. It did this weird edit that was really sloppy. It doesn‚Äôt help that the movie also bombards you with unnecessary sound effects.- As for its visual effects, they aren‚Äôt good either; they‚Äôre actually quite awful. Some of the special effects that it does in here look pretty cheap and noticeable. It could‚Äôve been a lot better. Pacing-wise, this aspect is very inconsistent. There are a couple of moments where the movie is a bit of a drag to get through, and other times, it feels incredibly rushed. It just felt messy. Some scenes here are also pretty lackluster, which affects the pacing even more.Final Thoughts:Overall, Mallari (2023) is such a mixed bag for me. There are aspects here that I really liked, and some that don‚Äôt really work whatsoever. It‚Äôs a decently directed film by Roderick Cabrido. The premise itself is pretty interesting, and there are a couple of moments here where you can definitely see the potential. As for the cast themselves, they‚Äôre pretty good. A lot of the performances are great. There‚Äôs also some fairly decent chemistry between the cast members in here. Piolo Pascual shines throughout the movie‚Äôs entire runtime.Visually, I think the film actually looks pretty good. There are a couple of terrific shots here and there. The cinematography also does a good job of giving the film a bit of a creepy atmosphere. Aside from that, the music that was composed by Von de Guzman is excellent. This also helps with the film‚Äôs atmosphere. The overall production here can be a little bit of a mixed bag, but there are some moments where it was quite decent, in my opinion. Aside from that, there are also a couple of pretty decent moments here and there.Unfortunately, despite an intriguing premise, the execution was just all over the place. The script is pretty lackluster in a lot of aspects, often making its story feel messy and underdeveloped. This was such a shame because there are some moments here where I can see what they‚Äôre going for, but the story just felt really generic at times. Aside from its story, the characters here are also rather bland, making me not really care much for any of them. Some of the lines of dialogue here are also pretty awful. They can be cringeworthy.Aside from that, its editing can be very choppy in some scenes, especially when it comes to its jump scares. Speaking of its jump scares, there‚Äôs way too much here, and none of them works. They‚Äôre just predictable, and there is also an overabundance of sound effects. The visual effects are atrocious, and the pacing here is very inconsistent. There are instances where the film is a bit of a drag to get through. I really wanted to like this film; I really do. But despite some pretty solid ideas, as a whole, this just leaves a lot to be desired.5.5/10What are your thoughts?

There were a lot of good elements but ultimately this movie fell flat for me. It just felt like the movie was trying to do too much and alot of it just ended up half-baked and under developed. It's supernatural horror, a slasher, a time travel movie, a murder mystery, a social commentary, a psychological thriller, it just feels disjointed and I'm left feeling disapointed because there were alot of good ideas that felt just felt jammed in there. I really didn't care much for the time travel plot which is unfortunate because it makes-up like 85% of the plot. I would have much loved to see how they would have approached the film if they went full on psychological horror cause the third act with JC Santos and Piolo Pascual duking it out was so great. Dialogue and Acting was so on point and the scene just felt so fleshed out compared to the rest of the screenplay. I would have loved to see an angle where the mallari curse wasn't real so Jonathan just feels like he's going insane for the whole film and maybe he thinks that he's the killer and the whole 3rd act scene with JC Santos just plays out. But yeah we got this instead.. I will say though I did like the final scene at the hospital It was probably the only supernatural scene in the whole movie where I actually felt unnerved but then they followed it up with the next scene which not only ruined the momentum but it was just completely uneccessary. We know that what jonathan did was wrong and we know the implications of his actions because we literally see it as clear as day in the scenes prior so why add another scene of the characters just talking about what we already know? Don't take your audience for granted we can understand what you're trying to say without you having to spell it out for us.Another issue I had with the film was the fact that it just wasn't scary. The "horror" in this movie just comes from an abundance of jumpscares and loud accompanying music stings. Of course if you're gonna throw something at my face I'm bound to react.All in all I really feel like this movie was a missed opportunity. The acting is great, production and sets were great. Maybe it was just too ambitious or maybe it wasn't ambitious enough.

a fresh concept, and i couldn't be more glad that it was piolo pascual who starred in it. however, we shouldn't forget jc santos's spectacular supporting performance during the unravelling of the story. i'm not sure whether to review the films based on the technicalities of the plot or the in-depth interweaving of the characters' relationships, but safe to say, both are well written. let me first start with the technicalities, which can be simply ruled out by semantics: baby jonathan calling johnrey "tito-lolo". jonathan isn't johnrey's son with felicity, given that he is his "tito-lolo/lolo-tito". and so, johnrey must have a sibling, from which jonathan came from. or if we lean to the "lolo" part, jonathan's direct relationship with johnrey is by johnrey's child with felicity. but then again, the same question arises with severino. being a priest, he isn't supposed to have descendants, which opens the possibility that the mallaris played by piolo pascual have siblings that aren't in the story, but had the chance to continue the blood line. given the time gap between 1812 to 1948 and 1948 to 2023, i assume that the ability to "travel" skips every one or two years in the mallari blood line. and if we were to get a spin-off film about those undisclosed generations but with their own peculiarities, why not? i enjoyed this film enough that i'd want a second one. as for the review about the characters' relationships, which i'd admit is a more informal review, i'll do in another entry.

this is the characters' review:if there is anything we know about the mallaris, it's that they're devoted to the people they love. father severino mallari, despite being the marketed center of the story as the first serial killer priest in the philippines, turned out to be a tortured character, who was flawed enough to make mistakes and have turbulent emotions about the people he loved. they gave father severino, a supposed serial killer, a heart, and a facet that made him undeniably human. personally, i like when supposed villains/evil characters show that human quality to themselves. severino, all distraught and maddened yet surrendered by the situation of his mother, still found the strength in his knees to dance his monster-turned-mother. sure, poke fun at him and call him a "mama's boy", but it's not like he had a choice in the matter. especially not when the choices were your own mother or your principles. and how many times have our mothers derailed our principles completely? severino's love was devout.moving onto the second mallari, johnrey: i couldn't say much about him that isn't about his intelligence, martyrdom, and commitment to the future generation. johnrey ended the curse by not choosing the same path severino did. johnrey was selfless, and his love didn't manifest in a way that would put others in harm's way. johnrey's love was kind.and to the third mallari, jonathan. amongst the rest, jonathan chose all the wrong choices. even agnes herself said it would've been better had jonathan let him die. jonathan all throughout the film was misleading, taking on the role of an unreliable narrator, or at least, an ambiguous one. if anything, jonathan's love is unrelenting. and to the special mention, lucas. lucas, oh, he could've been everything. had this been an alarcon-centric film, it would still be as interesting. lucas's motivations which eventually flowed into desperation almost sounded as if he wasn't only faithfully attached to jonathan mallari, but also a servant who loved his faulty master through and through. lucas calling jonathan "amo" was something else. i'm not sure whether i'm viewing everything through the colored lenses of queerness, but lucas's devotion to jonathan had undertones of romanticism and obsession that could only be explained if he were in love with him. and such display would make for good alternate universe writings about this story.

Ibang klaseng generational trauma naman 'to, teh.Kidding aside, Mallari had lots of potential as a culturally-nuanced Filipino horror film, but fell short on certain aspects. Fictionalizing the life of Fr. Severino Mallari ‚Äî reported to be the Philippines' first serial killer ‚Äî into a film that incorporates elements of folk horror, historical fiction, science fiction, and thriller was promising. It succeeded in drawing upon elements of folk religion and true crime to invite viewers into the life and motives of a creepy and murderous priest, and Piolo Pascual ‚Äî timeless of an actor he is ‚Äî nailed the triple roles of Fr. Mallari, Johnrey, and Jonathan quite excellently.The storytelling and production design were quite able to establish the settings in each of the Mallari eras, but the horror elements of the film were left to be desired. The jump scares felt gimmicky and did not serve any real purpose to the storyline other than to imply that Johnrey and Jonathan had psychic abilities. The suspense was present, though I wish Mallari had touched upon the concepts of folk religion and witchcraft a little further to better understand the sociocultural contexts in which the settings of the film revolved in. The motives behind Maria Capac's practice of witchcraft wasn't made clear, apart from maybe the implication that peasant folk like them just wanted to exact revenge on the elite. It would've been nice if the subversiveness of the practice of occultism had been given better emphasis within the contexts of colonial and post-war Philippines, but maybe that's just the sociological analysis-hungry viewer in me wanting more lol. There were also moments when I felt as if the depiction of occultism in the film was a little clich√©d ("impoverished househelp uses dark magic against the rich people they serve" felt a little telenovela-esque), but maybe that was intentional to reflect its generally taboo reputation. I did notice, however, similarities in the portrayal of the practice with what was shown in Lorcan Finnegan's Nocebo (2023), where Chai Fonacier played a vengeful mangkukulam disguised as a timid homeopathy-practicing OFW.But all in all, Mallari is a refreshing take on horror, especially for a MMFF release. It's dark, eerie, and adds to the foray of contemporary Filipino media that draws inspiration from real historical events and figures. I'm no horror enthusiast, but I do appreciate it when a Filipino film weaves our history and culture into its storytelling... especially when it includes the parts of our culture that are often left in the dark.

Hindi ko matapos-tapos  ºyung palabas. Sabi nang huwag kasi gagalaw Piolo Pascual e, malapit na nga matapos.Sa kabuuan, half disappointed/half okay-ish para sa akin. Hindi ko maikakaila, medyo nag-improve kahit papaano ang MMFF nitong nakaraan ngunit parang ni-recycle lamang ang mga materyal nito. May pag-asa pa rin ako sa takilya dahil kahit papaano, paunti-unti nang bumabalik ang interes ng mga tao sa panonood ng palabas sa sinehan. Balik na tayo tungkol sa palabas.Sa totoo lang, interesting talaga ang palabas na ito. Biruin mo pinagtagpi-tagping panahon, serial killer, at history ng Pinas, maganda nga siguro. Magandang ideya ngunit pakiramdam ko may mali dahil sa pagkawala ng originality ng palabas na ito. Habang nanonood ka, hindi mawawalay sa kaisipan mo na ihalintulad ito sa mga palabas sa Hollywood. Hindi na bago, gasgas na rin. Pero kung ididisregard natin iyan, makakapiga pa rin naman tayo ng katas sa kagandahan nito. Isa nga ring problema, sa mga linyang sinabi sa palabas na ito. Tambay ba sa Twitter ang writer nito? medyo hindi lang ako sang-ayon sa mga piniling salita at nagsasalita kasi pakiramdam ko ay pinipilit lamang ito para makisabay sa panahon ngayon. Wala ring saysay at hindi ako tinamaan sa mga huling kataga ng mga karakter, ang cringe bwisit. Magw-work pa rin naman ang palabas na ito kahit na walang mga multo. Magandang ideya sana ngunit naging isa sa mga sablay nito ang pagdagdag pa ng multo ng mga pinatay. Minsan epektibo ang jumpscares sa palabas na ito pero bakit ginagasgas nito dahil sa paulit-ulit at prediktableng pananakot. Hay, buti nalang nakuha ang tindig ng balahibo ko nung kinuha na  ºyung projector.Nagampanan naman nang maayos ng mga aktor at aktres ang kani-kanilang role. Lupit pa rin ni Piolo Pascual, first time ko siyang makitang umacting sa horror film. Para naman kay JC Santos, lupit ka rin talaga, puwede na maging Joker ng Pinas. Si Janella, okay lang, parang akala niya nasa Darna TV show pa rin siya.Mala-Christopher Nolan ampeg ang pag-edit ng palabas na ito. Ayos, dahil epektibo ang non-linear na pagkuwento. Sablay lang talaga siguro ang production sa VFX dahil napa-WHAT nalang ako sa isang scene (nakakasura after mo mapanood dahil mapapaisip ka kung 2 to 3 stars nalang ba ang mair-rate mo rito sa Letterboxd). Solido rin ang transisyon tuwing pinagtatagpi na ang noon at ngayon. Maliban sa iniiskip na frame para sa jumpscares, wala na akong reklamo. Medyo binigyan din ako ng chills sa score at soundtrack ng palabas na ito. Pasado rin ang sinematograpiya ng palabas na ito. Ako lang ata nakapansin na medyo shaky  ºyung camera nung isang scene haha.Ayun lang.Official yapyap ko sa palabas na Mallari.

Remarkable rin yung performance ni JC Santos.The first couple of scenes elicited gasps & ‚Äòwtfs‚Äô from me but I feel like it ultimately became a rather polished version of KMJS‚Äô gabi ng lagim special from the middle towards the end lol. May serial killer, may astral prjection, may mambabarang, cult-ish yung line of servants ng family‚Ä¶ by the time na naging manananggal si Gloria Diaz medyo bumitaw na ako ng very light sa plot. I‚Äôm a sucker for generational curses though, so I still enjoyed seeing three generations of Mallari men trying to save the one they love the most, kebs na sa eternal damnation, ganon. My favorite scenes were the interactions of Mallari men, and I loved the concept of being able to return to a specific time by carrying a Mallari keepsake with them when they sleep. What else‚Ä¶ oh, medyo tumatak yung acting ni Elisse dito ‚Äî the way she delivered her coconut line was smooth, believable yung implied background ng character niya. The jumpscares were pretty weak, the writing was a little all over the place, but most of the actors were good in the roles given to them. I feel like it could‚Äôve been a shorter film, though. I wish they chose fewer folk / supernatural tales to incorporate in the story. That would‚Äôve made the movie‚Äôs plot tighter and maybe, a bit more compelling.

I craved it all up as a horror fan, I just thought that it went all very crazy towards the end.It's fine that they used the based on real events backdrops on Mallari using the time travel stuff and I think that's enough for a fantastical addition to the story but as they aren't satisfied enough, suddenly all of these series of events introduced monsters such as manananggal and an aswang. It was justified for the story but it could have been done differently in a more thriller than a fantastical way. I just thought that for a revisionism from a real life serial killer is way too overboard. Add in the ghosts of the victims played for cheap jumpscares. could have reduced those into some few scenes than be played repeatedly.Talking about the ending. It switches its theme of the whole movie where it is supposed to be a serious horror melodrama but it ends into taken out of a Shake, Rattle & Roll ending where jt is all like campy and hits with a punchline. It was kind of funny but it does feel out of place.But this is still a fun story with a bunch of cool ideas crammed in to satisfy me.

Sa direksiyon ni Derick Cabrido at panulat ni Enrico Santos, isa itong pelikulang horror na tungkol sa isang doktor na si Jonathan Mallari De Dios (Piolo Pascual) na bumalik sa bahay ng kanilang angkan upang hanapin ang maaaring lunas sa sakit ng kaniyang fiancee na si Agnes (Janella Salvador). Habang hinahanap niya ito, matutuklasan niya ang sikreto ng kanilang angkan partikular sa buhay nina John Rey Mallari na isang dokumentarista at Fr. Severino Mallari na isang pari at pinaniniwalaang unang serial killer sa bansa.Mapupuri ko ang pelikula sa effort nito na tahakin ang ibang direksiyon sa halip na magtuon lamang sa sub genre ng horror na slasher o patayan. Sa kasamaang palad, sa sobrang gustong pagsanibin ang halos lahat ng mga elemento rito ng horror, naging magulo na ito. Kahit iyong paggamit ng konsepto ng time travel at astral projection ay magulo para sa akin sapagkat sa pagkakaalam ko, magkaiba ang dalawang ito. Mas nakagulo pa sa pelikula ang pag-eedit nito ng di-linyar na pagsasalaysay dahil sa ilang paulit-ulit na eksena na tingin ko, puwede pang gawing pulido sa isahang pagpapakita lamang. Hindi rin gaanong nabigyan ng linaw ang motibo ng pamilya Alarcon sa pamilya Mallari.Kapuri-puri din ang disenyong pamproduksiyon nito ngunit napag-iwanan naman ang visual effects nito gayong medyo bumubuti naman ito. Napag-iwanan kasi isa sa mga prodyuser nito ay Warner Bros. Philippines tapos ganoon lang ang inabot ng VFX? Ewan ko ba. HAHAHA! Bilang karagdagan, ayos din naman ang sinematograpiya at musika at tunog nito ngunit dahil naging paulit-ulit ang paglapat ng musika sa pare-parehong jump scares, ang unang karanasan na nakakagulat ay naging nakaiirita habang tumatagal. Sa tuwing may paparating na halatang jump scare, napapairap na lang ako at minsan, napapabuntunghininga.Sa pagganap naman ni Piolo Pascual, hindi ko nakitaan ng pagkakaiba-iba ang tatlong Mallari. Parang pare-parehong Jonathan lamang ang nakikita ko na nag-iba-iba lamang ng bihis. Marahil, nakaapekto rito ang kulang na karakterisasyon nina John Rey na nalimitahan lamang sa pagiging dokumentarista at Jonathan na nalimitihan lamang sa papel nito sa buhay ni Agnes. Kung mayroon man akong papupurihan kay Pascual, iyon ay ang eksena matapos ang una niyang pagpatay na lumabas ang kaniyang kakayahan bilang aktor sa drama. Bukod pa rito, iyong alter ego ni Fr. Severino Mallari na nakabihis bilang San Bartolome, mahusay. Medyo nasapawan nga rin siya ni JC Santos sa totoo lang kaya nakuha ko na iyong pagkapanalo niya ng Best Supporting Actor sa nakaraang Gabi ng Parangal ng MMFF 2023 dahil malinaw na naipakita ni Santos ang pagbabago sa katauhan ni Brother Lucas. Napaisip tuloy ako, paano kaya kung si Santos ang leading role? Sa tingin ko, naging disadvantage ng pelikula ang pag-promote nito bilang kakaibang horror kaya nadismaya nga ako. Sa ganda ng trailer nito, naging mataas ang inaasahan dito. Sa panonood ko nito, nakita ko iyong effort sa direksiyon at bisyon ng pelikula pero habang tumatagal, nagiging trying hard na ito. Kaya, masasabi ko na mas maayos pa ang pagkakabuo ng Kampon (2023) dito. Kampon > Mallari. That's it.-----Ranking ng MMFF 20231) Firefly 2) GOMBURZA3) Becky and Badette4) Kampon5) Family of Two6) Mallari7) Rewind8) Penduko9) Broken Heart's Trip

‚Äúdi ba, isang sumpa ang magmahal?‚Äù well, at least he‚Äôs right about that one thingi wanted to like this so bad. i even considered going to the theaters to watch it when it came out because of all the hype‚Äîthankfully, i didn‚Äôt. i kept seeing nice reviews about the plot and the cast‚Äôs overall performance, but everything felt lackluster.i was rooting for piolo !! but there was something about his performance(s) that didn‚Äôt sit right with me. i have the screenplay to blame for that.a movie about true crime, time travel, horror, and philippine folklore... was certainly a choice. so much was happening even when they shouldn‚Äôt have. they should‚Äôve just stuck to true crime. the story about the first recorded serial killer in the philippines, who happens to be a priest no less? already a rich narrative on its own.but alas, i suppose this does tend to happen in philippine cinema. filipino filmmakers just can‚Äôt resist adding something familiar with filipino moviegoers‚Äîin this case, ghosts and manananggals.this movie could‚Äôve been a game-changer had it been done right. it could‚Äôve been a stepping stone for filipino movies to move away from the same boring and redundant plots. this is why i barely watch filipino-made films. sayang.

"Directed by Roderick Cabrido, the Filipino horror film Mallari stars Piolo Pascual as the three main characters living in different time periods: Juan Severino Mallari, Johnrey, and Jonathan. The film is centered around the Mallari family from Magalang, Pampanga. In 2023, Jonathan, a doctor, returned to his ancestral property in Magalang to find the cure for his wife‚Äôs illness, and that was when the supernatural phenomena began. The film is inspired by the real-life story of Father Juan Severino Mallari of Magalang, Pampanga, infamous for killing 57 people. Mallari adds a supernatural element to the story and takes it up a notch. From astral projection to time travel, the film offers an elaborate explanation to connect the three timelines."Read the rest on dmtalkies.

Gave this one a try and that alone shouldn‚Äôt be too hard, right? Except it was.Mallari feels like a rollercoaster ride watching it where you are bombarded with too many things going on, too many information that isn‚Äôt put to light. It becomes very awry and sleazy as the film drags on, hoping to reach a certain angle that only becomes a disappointment especially for horror fans.There were so much that bothered me from this one especially as a horror and film fan. And it didn‚Äôt help knowing that Mallari is based on a real person. The lore of it all, the ‚Äúastral projection‚Äù being a dumb plot device, the time-jumps, the weird cuts that produced so many continuity errors, the visual effects, the many information that didn‚Äôt really work‚Ä¶consuming everything from this film is draining.The only merit I would give this film is JC Santos‚Äô performance that always has me in awe. He can play any sort of role perfectly that just suits him. Also the cinematography that had great camera tricks using the Dutch angles and that one scene using mirror between JC Santos & Piolo Pascual‚Äôs fight in the end.The point for this film was to follow the true story of Mallari, the Philippines‚Äô first ever recorded serial killer from the 19th century. Except it was all a ploy to lure people in, making its audience expect a biopic of some sort of a serial killer that only became stupid, fictionalizing almost everything there is to Mallari and making the audience see that serial killers can have good intentions. There are a few serial killer films/shows that actually lets its audience look further into the person‚Äôs story (or from their perspective), yet also distinguishing the fact that these people are villains and that you have to understand that you are seeing everything from the villain‚Äôs eyes. Or in this case, a serial killer.

Disappointing is the nicest word I could think of. Me and my friends were expecting a lot, some because they said it's "high production" and some like me who are fond of true crime. But all of us, in the end, were... disappointed. Near the end, we were not scared anymore, but clowning the movie for its predictable plot, cheap and quick suspense, and lost potential.1 star for casting and performance: Walang patapon. Masasarap as usual.1 star for videography: The cinematography was decent, with some well-shot scenes and good use of lighting. However, good visuals alone couldn't compensate for the movie's numerous shortcomings.Overall, "Mallari" was a letdown. Despite its high production values, it lacked the substance and thrill that make a true crime movie gripping and memorable. Save your time and skip this one.

Wow... I mean, the production is good. And I love the play with the story. Now, I shall use the next hour to know what was real and not with the movie. LOL.

The movie is based on the true story of the first documented Filipino serial killer, who happened to be a priest. The non-linear narrative, which involves time travel, can be confusing at first, but the film's eerie atmosphere and strong performances keep viewers engaged. Gloria Diaz delivers a chilling performance, and JC Santos is equally impressive. The casting of theater actors in supporting roles elevates the overall quality of the performances. The incorporation of Filipino folk mysticism, including the aswang, adds depth and quality to the film.

The camera angles of this film are insane. I also find the intricate and profound usage of the Filipino language blissful to the ears. If there‚Äôs an element in this two-hour film that kept me entertained, that‚Äôs it. The cast also gave very satisfactory performances. Kapamilya actors ftw.Unravelling the so-called mystery wasn‚Äôt thrilling. I am sorry but I find it dragging. Some jump scares aren‚Äôt even substantial if you really think of it. I guess those were just like fillers so you can feel its ‚Äúhorror‚Äù vibe tho I never looked at Mallari as a horror flick anyway lol. As the revelations unfolded and as it reaches the end, it morphed into something borderline absurd. But I appreciate the effort of this film in attempting to bring something fresh to PH cinema.And by the way, John Rey is a Baby Boomer, right?

Maganda naman siya production wise. The actors are also good. Concept wise, the plot could've been smoother and better if it wasn't so jumpy. So much time was wasted in explaining everything (bakit kailangan natin lagi ng dialogue in explaining the story? the first hour felt like a stretched introduction). The dialogue was a bit weird... Bakit paulit-ulit mga sinasabi nila? However, I don't agree with a certain FB post üßê that said na this was a waste of time and that the time travel concept was not good. Yes, it is long. Yes, it felt weird going through all three timelines the way the movie did. But, the movie held its own despite it not knowing kung ano ba talaga gusto niya gawin - maging love story ba ni Piolo and Janella? Bloodline ng Mallari? Bloodline ng Alarcon? Filipino Folklore? o story ba talaga ni Fr. Severino? I think that it is only a waste of time if you were expecting a Hollywood level horror story (even Hollywood horror movies are not that good). You know better than to expect that.(Steering away from the review of the movie itself but about na ito sa post...)One of the points sa review na 'yun is the cgi. It was not the best but it tried. We put the Filipino Film industry in such high standards that we're not allowing our OWN movies to make mistakes, learn better, and grow from it. The thing that I find weird is, we're all screaming for better Filipino films, but then we have one that is trying its best, and then we laugh at it. Saan na pupunta mga creators natin kung pati mga kapwa Pilipino hindi sila tinatangkilik? Kung kahit suporta man lang ay hindi maibigay?Hindi ko rin sinasabi na dapat laging maganda ang reviews sa bawat Filipino film na ginagawa. Pero kung mayroong ganitong palabas na sumusubok, bakit hindi rin natin subukan?
