When I first saw the trailer for this last MMFF I was onboard with it. I read ahead about what Fr. Severino Mallari was all about. Biopics are my bread and butter, and with every biopic, or in this case, an adaptation, I anticipate a degree of creative storytelling to make it more feasable for cinema. What was the films take on this? A Generational "curse" in the Mallari family. Interesting. The real Mallari was allegedly scizhophrenic; so I was hoping theyd explore that, a mental illness angle plaguing the family for generations. Much to my disappointment, the movie veered away from that and laid blame not into the serial killer but to an entirely fictional group of people who "used" this serial killer to kill. Severino (Piolo Pascual) was essentially forced to kill out of love. A theme which kind of fell flat because of how many things the film wanted to juggle. Was it a mystery? Was it a thriller? A supernatural horror? A sci-fi? Yes, sci-fi.Taking away Fr Severino's agency erases or paints the actions of the real Mallari as not his own choice; if it was indeed mental illness it wouldve made more sense but instead it was the malicious work of well meaning witches. Which, in an original story MAY work, but not in this. Its supposed to be BASED on a real story yet it strayed a little too much into fiction. A creative choice that MIGHTVE worked if only they didnt add astral projection and timey wimey shit into it too. OH plus origins of a notorious Philippine mythic creature.There were some creative shots here and there, I particularly liked this one shot when John was walking through a door and a dolly zoom boxed him in the corridor. However the scares were lack luster. It relied heavily jumpscares which became old fast and can be easily expected. While the makeup and visual effects were great, I dont think it utilized it enough to anything other than. ** SPOILERS FOR THE ENDING **god I hated ending. Heres DOCTOR John Mallari; granted hes a pediatrician (I think) with a FIANCE whose also a DOCTOR thats dying bc she got stabbed, his first response was NOT to bring her to a nearby hospital for first aid. And despite being on life support clearly conscious and capable of surviving given medical aid, MISTER JOHNATAN STILL DECIDES TO BRING BACK THE BIRD AND TAKE THE CURSE. WHICH IS THE WORST WAY TO GIVE AGENCY BACK TO THE MALLARI FAMILY when the previous 2 mallari's tried retreiving their lost agency by breaking the curse only for millenial Piolo Pascual to take it back.In summary, story is Messy. Acting is subpar, EXCEPT for JC Santos he stole the show. He was amazing and a twist I saw a mile a way but still welcome because of how well he acted. This movie couldve been something but ended being about nothing.

Maganda yung kuwento kaso hindi pulido ang writing. 'Yung mga linyahan sa umpisa, trying hard masyado para maging relatable sa audience, to the point na nagiging tunog artificial na. 'Yung mga eksena ng trans, sana mas pinag-isipan pa. 'Yung mga jump scares, hindi epektib maliban sa isa. I think kinulang sa creativity, kasi malaki ang potensyal ng kwento para manakot at manggulat. Kaso masyadong dumepende sa cuts at sound effects.Pero maganda ang concept. Nakakamangha 'yung second half nang nailatag na ang mga sikreto at misteryo. Complex ang kwento, kaya nakakabilib na maayos itong naihayag.Sa second half din mas nag-shine ang performances ng mga bida. JC Santos, deserving ng best supporting actor sa mmff. And Piolo Pascual, perfect casting. May isang scene na tumatak sa akin dahil sa performanceS niya. All in all, 3/5 kasi medyo na-outweigh pa rin ng flaws ng pelikula ang good aspects nito. May magagandang creative choices in terms of filmmaking, pero sana mas napagtuunan din ng pansin ang mga "scares." Goosebumps din sana pagdating sa ending, kung mas nabigyan pa ng justification ang mga desisyon ng bida. Pero in the end, very authentic ang istorya, with some all-timer performances.

Movie could've been great but as I was watching it, I got totally lost and confused as to what the movie was trying to achieve. The jump scares were so predictable and the CGI was just plain awful. What's with those CGI ghost faces?! The way they CGI'd Gloria Diaz was cringey as fuck. Not to mention those awful manananggal wings which literally made us want to stop watching the entire film.One major ick I have was Padre Severino's weird beard. Like couldn't they have made it more natural? It looked so fake I couldn't take him seriously. They honestly should've just invested on the cast's makeup or prosthetics to make everything look convincing. I honestly could not help but compare it to cult favorite Filipino horror movies like Feng Shui and Sukob. No CGIs there but it was definitely scarier and more realistic by a mile.I still gave it four stars because, okay, it was ambitious - I'll give them that. But it was too ambitious it failed to just stick to what people came to watch the movie for - Fr. Severino Mallari's story. I think a lot of people were expecting to watch and know more of his backstory and his motivation, but sadly this was a huge opportunity missed.

‚Äúdiba, isang sumpa ang magmahal?‚Äù‚Äîbago ang lahat, sana ‚Äòwag kayo malito sa astral projection ni piolo pascual at talagang subaybayan niyo para ma-gets niyo ng true kasi konektado ang lahat. aliw rin si amal at ng colloquialism ng film na ‚Äòto. ‚Äúpasensya na kung amoy kiffy‚Äù -amal bwahahahaha! putting jest aside, i came to a realization that this nail-biting Filipino film, inspired by true events yet interwoven with fictional elements, fundamentally springs from undying love. each character, driven by their own ambitions, had one thing in common: their actions were motivated by love. among Piolo's three portrayals in "Mallari"‚ÄîSeverino, Johnrey, and Jonathan‚Äîit was Johnrey i found as the most courageous character. his initial ambition to investigate the Mallari family's history and his selfless sacrifices, motivated by love, set him apart. meanwhile, Jonathan‚Äôs determination to keep Agnes alive demonstrated a different facet of this enduring theme. as for severino, i sympathized with him, recognizing that he never truly desired the tragic events that transpired. yet, he continued to submit himself in vicious killings to save his beloved mother which only reveal that desperate times need desperate actions. lason ang wagas na pagmamahal. lason ang pamilyang alarcon. lason ang sisiw. sadly, parang ang sumira nga lang sa patronage ng traditional philippine architecture ay dahil sa mga ganitong horror films. nevertheless, i give this film a 10/10! as it brings a refreshing justice in demands in the realm of modern Filipino horror cinema. lesson learned: ‚Äúang isang tao ay kabuuan lamang ng kaniyang mga pagkakamali‚Äù

Tumaas lang talaga expectations ko, ang promising naman din kasi talaga ng trailer when I first watched it way back in December. Ang ganda pa ng concept, something I would be interested to know so much about.This film truly has a great potential if only was written with a different and clearer storyline. Una sa lahat, nakakanginig ‚Äòyung mga linyahan haha akala mo mga nakuha lang somewhere on the internet just to match this generation‚Äôs language. Hay, na-dismaya lang ako nang kaunti pero ayos na rin. Nawalan na rin ng sense of suspense sa ibang mga scenes dahil nga ang predictable na ng mga susunod na jumpscare, halos sunod-sunod kasi at ‚Äòyung iba parang out of context pa. Despite all the shortcomings, cinematography still did its job.Kudos din sa casting, magagaling naman talaga mga napili. Especially si JC Santos, never fails talaga parang paghinga lang ang pag-arte sa kanya kahit na hindi gaanong suwak ‚Äòyung mga lines for his energy eh. Binuhat nalang talaga ng acting skills ni bes ko. Overall, this horror film definitely achieved its purpose to make the audience feel scared but just fall short to convey the concept‚Äôs full potential.

This is so rough. "Mallari" uses a fact-based story about the Philippines' only serial killer to tell a mess of a time travel, witchcraft, and folk creature story, and it's not even scary at all. The film follows Jonathan as he learns about his family's past to find a cure for his fiance. The three-timeline narrative is a bit too ambitious for what the film ends up being since the direction and production just could not create any dramatic tension. JC Santos is pretty good here and Piolo Pascual is okay, but the film is just a weak and dull attempt at horror.

Mallari was the movie I was most looking forward to out of all the MMFF entries last year, given it was the first movie distributed by Warner Bros (I could be wrong here), but sad to say it's at most a solid 3/5.While it tackles a lot of firsts, it's also a movie that uses the redundancy of the Filipino "timpla". Like, men are so stupid and unreasonable. Jonathan, darling, I get it‚Äîit's Janella Salvador, but really? Father, why is the wig weave showing like that? (Tatak Pinoy films to have bad wigs, I said what I said). JC Santos, that nose acting, bro. I'm so frigging tired. I don't even watch horror, but those jumpscares did nothing to me‚Äîthey are just jumpscares and didn't add anything to the plot.I think in this day and age, we would all rather die than be a maligno. I also would like to point out that he became a werewolf at some point, and the cinematography used shadows‚Äîand the shadows were cheap in form. I guess I want to say in the end, Filipino films' bare minimum is moving in the right direction.

a horror film that only relies on jumpscares and gore to scare you isn't really a good horror film, no?i had high expectations for this and they were just not met. the plot was all over the place, the dialogue trying to sound deep even when they were in the present time, the distracting CGI, the time traveling. i can go on but i think the main issue was the film failed to just focus on one thing and flesh out the story from there. the main plot about a priest who's a serial killer is interesting enough but they just had to add a bunch of other elements that resulted to a convoluted story. it's frustrating to think about what could have been.
